PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) will be absent from question time today. He is in Perth attending a memorial service for the victims of the helicopter accident. I will answer questions on his behalf. The Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) and the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel (Mrs Bishop) are accompanying the Prime Minister and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) will answer questions on their behalf.

—Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to advise the House that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is also attending the same service and that on an equally temporary basis I am acting for him today.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Wholesale Sales Tax on Motor Vehicles

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Does the Treasurer recall stating last Friday that the new wholesale sales tax on state car purchases will apply from the date of his first press release on this issue—last Tuesday, 11 June? Is he aware that, as a result of the government's failure to publish in newspapers today the public notice required within seven days by section 130B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act, any collection of the tax would be in breach of that statutory requirement? What action does he now propose to take to redress the uncertainty and confusion that this continuation of last week's shambles has created?

—There is no confusion whatsoever. The position is quite clear. Those vehicles which are purchased by any level of government for partly or wholly private use as part of remuneration are covered by the wholesale sales tax. The states have agreed to cooperate in identifying and collecting that. That was one of the specific terms. And the legislation will be introduced to ensure that occurs.
—I seek leave to table the terms of section 130B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act which quantify a little more precisely the amount of egg on the Treasurer's face.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government. Has the minister seen reports in the press that Professor Allan Fels of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is keen to see the ban on parallel imports of compact discs lifted in line with the 1991 recommendations of the Prices Surveillance Authority? Is it the government's intention to review the current situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He has a well‐known interest in these matters. Indeed, I have seen the reports and it is quite notable—and many members would know—that Australians pay significantly more for CDs than many other countries, particularly the United States. In the arts policy which was released prior to the election by my colleague Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, entitled For Arts Sake—A Fair Go! , we committed ourselves to looking for ways to lower those prices.

ANSWER.PARA: We said we would consult widely with both the industry and more broadly with the community about how that might most effectively be done, that is, to get to that aim of lower prices. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is in fact doing formal price monitoring at present. They are about to release their first report. We look forward to that report.

We believe that this is a priority issue for the government and we do want to find a mechanism where we can get better prices for consumers, but also provide a stable environment for the industry in which to provide its services. The government is determined to try to seriously address this matter, which has bedevilled the now opposition for some years, to find a meaningful solution.

I do not know if the honourable member has actually seen the press release by Shock Records only this week, but I am pleased to say that it indicates that they have just announced that they will reduce the price of the top ten CD titles in Australia down to $25 from an average of $31. Polygram Records have also followed suit. So there is some movement now in terms of prices for the top titles. The government welcomes that move, but as I say we will be monitoring it closely. We will be consulting with the ACCC and also widely with the industry to get to the position where the government needs to be to see lower prices for consumers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister, representing the Prime Minister. Do you endorse the Prime Minister's statement on ABC radio yesterday encouraging the community to debate a GST? Do you also endorse the call of the New South Wales National Party, made in your absence at the weekend, for the introduction of a broad based expenditure tax? Will you unequivocally rule out the introduction of a GST not only in this term of office but in your next term should you win one?

—What I remember about this mob in respect of taxation in the course of the last parliamentary term was their huge increase in fuel excise taxation which did so much to damage decentralisation in this country. At the time it was over and above the CPI, and they should hang their heads in shame for this. There will be no GST considered in accord with the Prime Minister's often given statement on this matter and I have nothing further to add.
—Mr Speaker, under standing order 151, I seek elucidation of an aspect of the minister's answer in accordance with your ruling yesterday.

—I made the point very clearly yesterday that I expected the supplementary questions to be irregular. As far as I could determine, the Deputy Prime Minister has answered that question to the limit of his ability. The question is disallowed.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House how the government is assisting demutualisation in the financial sector? What are the benefits of demutualisation for the consumer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. Demutualisation in the finance industry results in improvements in ownership, it introduces the market mechanism for takeover and it provides the opportunity for the raising of additional capital by way of equity.

ANSWER.PARA: I have recently agreed in principle to facilitate a proposal arising out of the demutualisation of Colonial Mutual. Colonial Mutual has purchased the State Bank of New South Wales and, as a condition of that, was required to demutualise. The acquisition has resulted in a merged business where the banking and insurance arms are of comparable size. There are regulatory advantages in allowing the two branches of the business to be run by the one holding company.

The takeover of the Bank of New South Wales by Colonial Mutual was done under a longstanding arrangement, a facility which allowed a holding company to take over a bank where the holding company was an Australian non‐mutual life. In order to take advantage of that policy, Colonial Mutual was required to demutualise and, in order to facilitate that demutualisation in the new structure, approval has been given to the holding company structure.

The government will introduce legislation at a later stage to provide a more direct means of achieving regulation of the holding company, but I want to emphasise that this is a one‐off exception made in exceptional circumstances. Before the Wallace inquiry into the financial system reports, we will not be allowing other holding companies to be set up to own current insurance businesses together with banking businesses should any of the six—or indeed seven—major players wish to adopt a similar structure. This is a one‐off in exceptional circumstances.

I make it clear, however, that the government welcomes competition in the financial industry. It believes that there are enormous advantages from new entrants into the financial industry. With variable mortgage rates, we have seen reductions as a result of new entrants and new competition, and the government believes that, by improving the opportunity for new entrants and for more competition, it will be delivering the best results to consumers, both to home buyers and to small businesses, who have red‐hot, full‐blooded competition in the financial sector which will ultimately be to their benefit.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister, representing the Prime Minister. I remind the Deputy Prime Minister of the coalition's election promise not to increase taxes and charges. I refer to the report today that the Queensland government has decided to slug my fellow Queenslanders $190 million extra next year through a household poll tax. Do you understand why Premier Borbidge felt betrayed by the Howard government at last week's Premiers Conference? Apart from that betrayal, doesn't this represent another tax increase by a coalition government in clear breach of your election promise not to increase taxes and charges? Can the Deputy Prime Minister answer this fully to the best of his ability?

—I will happily answer the question and point out that state government taxation initiatives are matters for the state governments. They can be provided for only by legislation of the state parliaments. On the matter of taxation—and since the 2 March election—I was hoping the supplementary might have been allowed because I happen to have a piece from a newspaper here which has as its heading `Labor split over GST'. As the left wing goes its merry way in the aftermath of your massive defeat, Labor ranks are split over the services tax. Indeed, you seem to have forgotten that your own caucus is very divided on the question of taxation reform. I say again: it is a matter for the state parliaments and the state premiers with regard to their taxation initiatives.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What progress did the minister make during his visit to the United Nations in furthering Australia's bid for a seat on the United Nations Security Council? How does the minister assess Australia's chances of election to the Security Council?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Kooyong for his question and indeed for his enduring interest in the important issue of the evolution of the United Nations. The Australian government is contesting one of the two seats available to the West Europe and Others Group on the United Nations Security Council. We are contesting one of those two seats with Sweden and Portugal, although I point out to the House that Australia has a cooperation arrangement with Sweden.

ANSWER.PARA: I took some time in New York recently to lobby on behalf of the Australian government for a position on the Security Council and I spoke to something like 100 different representatives of members of the United Nations, and I can report to the House—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised the Labor Party is so uninterested in the United Nations. Wasn't it Doc Evatt's big thing? You always used to be the champions of the United Nations.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Gareth Evans interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dare I mention it? You wanted to be the Secretary‐General, didn't you? I was constantly asked by the media whether we would support the member for Holt for the position of Secretary‐General of the United Nations. As the member for Holt quite rightly points out, I was very gracious. I always try to be gracious. I simply quoted the words of the member for Holt. I read them in a profile on the member for Holt when he said that he enjoyed being the shadow Treasurer and that he quite enjoys his time in opposition. I would not want to get in the way of that. If you would like to come and have a talk to me about one of the undersecretary‐general positions, we would be quite happy to consider that.

ANSWER.PARA: I am digressing, though, because the real issue here is Australia being elected to the United Nations Security Council. I am cautiously optimistic about Australia's chances. We certainly have very strong support from the Pacific island countries and the east Asian region, from the Caribbean and the Gulf Cooperation Council. We still have more work to do with African countries and more work to do in Europe, including central and eastern Europe. But the simple argument that Australia can put—that the other two candidates are both European Union candidates and Australia obviously is not—is, in my view, a very strong argument for us to put.

The European Union already has two permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, and it also has two of the non-permanent positions—the two for the West Europe and Others Group at the moment. For the United Nations General Assembly to elect two more EU members for the next two years to the non-permanent West Europe and Others Group seats I think would be a major mistake. I do not think the West Europe and Others Group representation on the Security Council should be dominated by the European Union—no objection to the European Union, but I do not think the council should be dominated by the European Union. It is very important, therefore, that Australia win this election, and the government will work hard to ensure that we do so.

In conclusion, this is like any election campaign: you do not know ultimately what the outcome is going to be. There are still some four months to go until the vote takes place, and we will need to work very hard throughout that time on the other members of the United Nations to get the requisite two-thirds vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister, representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the election commitment not to increase taxes and charges under a coalition government. I also refer to the reports today that Tasmanians will be slugged an additional $80 million over the next three years through increased taxes and charges, the sell‐off of the hydro‐electric commission and a levy which Tasmanians are calling the Costello levy. Would the Deputy Prime Minister agree that such an outrageous impost on Tasmanians is a clear breach of the coalition's policy that there would be no tax increases under them? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to say that our policies are clear cut, yours are not. I am happy to say that the taxation initiatives of the state governments and the state parliaments are matters for them. I am happy to say further that at the end of the day they agreed at the Premiers Conference with regard to this outcome. Perhaps I could do no better than to quote the member for Lalor, who said on 1 May:

ANSWER.PARA: I think we've got to completely reconsider our policy approaches. I think what we're all agreed on is that the 350 pages in our Labor policy books did not matter a zack after about 7 p.m. on the evening of 2 March.
Then what did he add? The National President of the ALP said this: `I mean, I wouldn't rule anything out; I wouldn't rule anything in.' Thank you, Barry Jones.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to welcome two distinguished governors from the United States, who are in the galleries this afternoon—Governor Tommy Thompson from Wisconsin and Governor Arne Carlson from Minnesota. A very warm welcome to you, gentlemen, and your entourage. May you enjoy your stay with us.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the minister seen a report that the opposition will not oppose the union disamalgamation provisions of the workplace relations bill? Would such a position be consistent with Labor's overall approach to the bill?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I must say that, when I read the reports this morning of further amendments from the Labor opposition, I could only come to the conclusion that the confusion continues within their ranks. I was interested because it was only a couple of days ago that the number of amendments we could look forward to was around 200, but this morning it has grown to the precise number of 291. I can only assume that their confusion is so great that they are now amending their amendments before they bring them into the House.

ANSWER.PARA: In this latest set apparently they are supporting superunions and amalgamations to achieve them but they are also supporting disamalgamations—so we have them getting bigger, getting smaller. They are supporting the retention of the conveniently belong rule, but at the same time if that does not work they want a complete open slather. They really are all over the place. They seem to have a lot of problems coming to grips with some of the essential issues.

If there is any problem in publishing their amendments, I think we would be prepared to help. The government's bill is on the Internet. We have had 60,000 hits on the Internet in terms of people looking at our bill. I think a lot of people would be interested to know about Labor's amendments. So I challenge the honourable member for Canberra, if he has some amendments, whether the number is 291 or perhaps 334 by tomorrow, to let us have them by 5 o'clock. If he likes, we will put them up on the Internet for everybody to see and we can pore over them.

More seriously, though, it is in contrast to the government's position on disamalgamation and coverage issues, where our policy position is based on two very commonsense rules—firstly, simply that workers have a right to be in a union of their choice and, secondly, that businesses have a right to have effective redress when their business is being threatened by unsanctioned industrial action. It seems from the reports that the shadow minister's view is that, if a business and its employees are being threatened by industrial action and where that industrial action may lead to unemployment, then as a result of a demarcation dispute the business must go to the wall, that there should be no effective means of redress.

That is even further confusion because it is usually the position of the opposition that the Industrial Relations Commission should be the umpire to decide these issues. Yet, on one of the shadow minister's secret and mysterious amendments, the commission would have no such power. He really ought to make up his mind: which way is it going to be; what exactly is his position? I think the best way for him to perhaps come to grips with some of these issues is to release these amendments so that there can be fair public debate about them.

Two other things need to be said which I think evidence the shadow minister's difficulty in coming to grips with these issues. He is wrong on a couple of points. He is critical of the idea of autonomy for union branches. But the fact of the matter is that that is not a new concept. If he knew his current act better, he would know that it was required by the Conciliation and Arbitration Act back in 1904 and, in fact, it was provided for in Labor's own legislation. Our bill simply gives real effect to that proposition. But it is, however, an old concept.

The second point where he is particularly wrong is in the proposals the government has with subsection 118(a) and the right of people to choose the union in which they are members. The section relates to coverage, not to membership. So it would be open, for example, for a worker at a site covered by a particular union to appoint another union as their agent to negotiate an Australian workplace agreement.

We, in fact, support the right of people to be in a union, and we back it up. But one of the real differences between our policy position and the opposition's policy is that we seek to protect the rights of individual workers. What they do is seek to protect union power to the disadvantage of workers. It is about time he released his secret amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you have acknowledged the presence in the gall ery of two of our good friends from the United States who would be aware of the fate of a former President who said, `Read my lips: no new taxes.'
—The honourable member for Charlton will move quickly to the question.

—I direct my question to the Deputy Prime Minister, representing the Prime Minister. I refer to that oft repeated claim during the election campaign by the coalition that there would be no new taxes and no increase in taxes. I ask the Deputy Prime Minister: in view of those amateurish shambles represented by the Premiers Conference which took place last week, and the fact that New South Wales residents will be subjected to a tax increase of $900 million over the next three years—and that represents an increase for every family of $300 over the next three years—does that represent an increase in taxes under this coalition government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —So far we have had Queensland, Tasmania and New South Wales. We are now going to get Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria to follow. The answer is the same: Labor has no credibility on the matter of taxation. Labor has absolutely no credibility. The reason for that is what you did after the last election.

ANSWER.PARA: I join with the member for Charlton in welcoming our American friends. Indeed, if our American government friends whom I had the privilege to meet a couple of hours ago knew the full story, they would advise the same conclusion; namely, in the 1993 elections, then Labor Treasurer Dawkins said that there would be no new taxes and no tax increases. The first budget you produced after the 1993 elections increased taxes in four areas, particularly with regard to fuel excise tax. It was your breach of promise on fuel excise tax which created the framework to enable us to win the election.
So you can keep trying, but the answer is the same. State governments and state parliaments will have to accept responsibility for their taxation initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. What are the advantages of ensuring neutrality in the application of wholesale sales tax to state and local governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me make it entirely clear that, as far as this government is concerned, if matters come to light where exemptions are being used improperly to avoid the application of the taxation system, we will fix it. In relation to the wholesale sales tax, I direct the attention of the House to a release by the Motor Trades Association of Australia which was put out on 11 June 1996. It said:

ANSWER.PARA: For many years, MTAA has adopted as its policy that steps should be taken to eliminate the use of sales tax exemptions for the purpose of minimising income tax. Representations to the previous Labor government on the matter did not even receive the courtesy of an acknowledgment.
The release continues:
This is a sensible and worthwhile reform of an area of taxation administration that has become the subject of very significant tax avoidance.

Not even the courtesy of a reply. You were a government that presided over taxation avoidance and you would do nothing about it. I refer the House also to part of the September 1995 newsletter by the Auto Industry of Australia entitled, `The unfair advantage for council car trader'. It says this:
The Chamber—
this is the Victorian Automobile Chamber of Commerce—

has recently been made aware of a bid by the City of Whitehorse, formerly Box Hill and Nunawading in Melbourne, to obtain a motor car traders licence. If the motor car traders licence is granted, the council will be selling vehicles it bought sales tax exempt and with fleet discounts.
You were prepared to preside over a system where councils were able to get motor car licences. The newsletter goes on to say:

A local newspaper report on the matter in part noted: `The council already makes a profit on the sale of many of its cars because they are bought free of sales tax and sold at the normal retail price while still in good condition. But the council estimates it can make an extra $2,000 to $3,000 profit on each car by selling them direct to the public.

No government could allow a situation where councils took out motor car licences to take advantage of sales tax exemptions to engage in motor car trading. As the Motor Trades Association said, this was unfair competition. This was an exemption which, in relation to the application of the taxation system, was unfair. This is an exemption which the Labor Party refused to do anything about because you loved this area of tax avoidance. I take it you are still opposed to closing it down. Is that right? Are you opposed to closing it down? You can't even announce a position on this because you know that to announce a position on this would expose the failures you had.

Any state government that takes the opportunity to raise its taxes takes that responsibility for itself, and it is responsible. If they want to say there is any federal contribution in relation to their taxation regime, they can lay the blame with the person who is really responsible—the Beazley black hole. As the Prime Minister said, a Carr tax out of Beazley.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at this.
—Order! I remind the member for Hotham that the display of newspaper advertisements or press is out of order.

—If you want to look for the federal culprits, look to the people who left the Commonwealth with an $8 billion deficit. Look to the people who got the Commonwealth into the trouble it was in. Look to the people who failed to close down avoidance opportunities and look to the people who were unwilling to act in this area.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a government that will act in this area. This is a government that will change the future in relation to the budget. This is a government that had the courage to take action, which you did not. This is the government which will take those steps that should have been taken so long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Deputy Prime Minister. Do you endorse the statement of your National Party colleague the member for Maranoa, now the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who stated last year, `For many people the Commonwealth Development Bank is the thread that keeps them from going completely under' and that without its $20 million subsidy from the Commonwealth `the bank could not afford to perform the role that it does'? Do you agree with the views of the New South Wales Farmers Association, who consider that the government taking, before the Rural Finance Summit, the decision to sell its 8.1 per cent stake in the bank and end Labor's $20 million subsidy to the bank is `pre‐emptive and arrogant'? Have you at any stage in your capacity as Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the National Party, publicly or within the government, voiced any concerns about the impact of these decisions on farmers and businesses in rural and regional Australia?

—The question is based on an incorrect premise, namely, that the Commonwealth Development Bank is ceasing to operate and that it is ceasing to provide the loans it has been providing. It is continuing, and it is continuing with a subsidy circumstance pertaining to the decisions made and announced in the last fortnight, which is a buy‐out of that facility. But I make it very clear that we are proceeding with the completion of the privatisation of the Commonwealth Development Bank. That, of necessity, meant decisions had to be taken with regard to the particular arrangements which existed between the federal government and the Commonwealth Development Bank. We have dealt with that as a government. I strongly defend the commitment that has been provided with regard to the loan arrangements of the Commonwealth Development Bank. Those loan arrangements will continue, not only in respect of farmers but also in respect of small business, and that is as it should be. To suggest otherwise is complete and utter nonsense.
—My question is directed to the Attorney‐General. Has the Attorney‐General seen the reports in the Age newspaper about the deportation of Mohamed Hassanien? Can he comment on the story?
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I think you will find that it is in breach of the standing orders to ask for a comment by a minister.
—The question is out of order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister for Finance aware of the promise made to the residents of Box Hill by the Minister for Health and Family Services in a personal letter dated 21 February which stated that `present Medicare rebates will not be changed'? Is the minister also aware that, while he was on the Sunday program refusing to rule out cuts in Medicare rebates last Sunday, almost at the same time the Minister for Health and Family Services was on the Face to Face program claiming to rule out cuts in those very same Medicare rebates? Who are we to believe—the Minister for Finance or the Minister for Health and Family Services? In the light of your own undertakings before the election and the promise by the Minister for Health and Family Services to the residents of Box Hill, will you today rule out any cuts in Medicare rebates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of what will be contained in the budget will be released at a later point in time. The very sad fact is that we have a difficulty with the current state of the budget as a result of Labor's 13 years of economic mismanagement. The Expenditure Review Committee will continue to work very diligently to ensure that those commitments we made to the people of Australia prior to 2 March will be factored into the budget and will be announced in August. We will continue to work very diligently to ensure that the most vulnerable in our community are the least affected by any decisions that are in the budget.

ANSWER.PARA: We will continue to ensure that those areas where there is economic growth are given due consideration in the framing of the budget, but the sad fact is that we have $8 billion to pick up. We now know—we were informed by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition—that the $8 billion debt that we have got was a deliberate policy choice. It is an $8 billion debt that blew out in the 19 consecutive quarters of economic growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, on a point of order: it was a very clear question about the Minister for Health and Family Services. The minister, in his answer, has not once referred to the question that was asked about the two TV programs.
—There is no point of order.

—I can assure you that I have no intention of speculating on any matter whatsoever or on any program. There will be speculation, as I anticipate, on a regular basis. I will not rule in or rule out any matter. My understanding is that the Minister for Health and Family Services did exactly the same thing last Sunday.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. What are the latest steps being taken by the government to more fairly distribute aircraft noise in Sydney? Can the minister assure the House that these steps will provide further substantial relief for residents living north of the airport who were suffering an unfair burden of aircraft noise under the Labor Party's punitive regime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Bradfield for his question. He has taken a deep interest in this issue and it is a very important issue for his electorate. Members will recall the opening of the new third runway in November 1994 and the subsequent outrage by residents of Sydney about the aircraft noise problems that were generated as a result of Labor's mismanagement of Sydney airport—outrage that led to some of the largest protests we have seen in a long time in Sydney and to a great deal of distress and discomfort for Sydneysiders. Members will also recall the fact that, in the latter part of last year—when in opposition—the Liberal and National parties made a number of firm commitments to try to ensure a more equi table distribution of the noise problem in Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the 2 March election, the new Liberal‐National Party government has been working as quickly as it can to deliver on all of the election commitments that it made. The first election commitment delivered was the reopening of the east‐west runway, which we promised we would do within 10 working days of being sworn into office. We did it within eight. Subsequent to that, there has also been a direction given to AirServices Australia to officially end the Bennelong funnel. That work is in progress as we speak.
In addition, we have also had a public meeting in the Hunters Hill Town Hall which the Prime Minister attended and spoke at. At that public meeting at the Hunters Hill Town Hall—

TALK.START.PARA: —Go to Marrickville.
—Order! The member for Grayndler!
—Come to Marrickville.
—The member for Grayndler!
—Come to Marrickville.
—I warn the member for Grayndler!
—a public meeting that our Prime Minister was prepared to attend—
—Go to Sydenham.
—I invoke section 304A of the standing orders. The member for Grayndler can take a walk.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The honourable member for Grayndler thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, at a public meeting at the Hunters Hill Town Hall, at which the Prime Minister attended and spoke, a further initiative was outlined by the government which would see a further diminution of the noise problems suffered by those people living to the north of Sydney's Mascot airport. It would achieve further our goal of a more equitable sharing of the noise problem over Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: Members of this House must remember that it was the previous Labor government that instituted the inequitable, unfair and distressing Bennelong funnel that caused so much distress in Sydney. That initiative was to take effect as of 15 June and was put in action on 15 June—last Saturday. It is designed to ensure that aircraft can land from the south, approaching Sydney's Mascot airport over water, on runways 34L and 34R—the parallel north‐south runways—whilst at the same time take‐offs can be operating on the east‐west runway in a westerly direction. No additional take‐offs are required to the west, but landings that would otherwise have been coming from the north will now be coming from the south on those two runways—34L and 34R—subject, of course, to certain weather conditions prevailing and also operating during certain hours of each day.

That initiative is a further fulfilment of the commitments the Liberal and National parties made in opposition that we are now delivering on in government. In addition to that, there will be further initiatives to be undertaken. The chief of those will follow the complete review of the airspace and flight paths around the Sydney basin area to ensure a greater usage of approaches over water, a greater usage of non‐residential areas for aircraft flying into Sydney and the possible use of military controlled airspace. All of these initiatives, the culmination of which will occur on 16 December this year, are designed to do two things: firstly, to deliver on our promises made in opposition and, secondly, to overcome the unfair and inequitable distribution of noise that occurred under a Labor government that caused so much distress and harm to people in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Given that the Minister for Finance has today, as he did on Sunday, refused to rule out any cuts in Medicare rebates, does the Minister for Health and Family Services stand by the comments which he made on the Face to Face program which, according to the Financial Review , effectively ruled out cuts in Medicare rebates? Does the minister stand by the promise that he gave to the residents of Box Hill that, `Present Medicare rebates will not be changed?' Do you stand by that promise to your constituents?

—I would suggest that the honourable member actually look at the tape rather than read the Financial Review for his information. If you look at the tape—and I am very happy to send you a copy—you will find that what I have said is not inconsistent at all. I have not ruled anything in or out. I will not do that until the budget—it is endless—and you can wait until 20 August to find out.
—My supplementary question is: does the minister stand by the promise to the constituents of Box Hill?
—The question is out of order.
—My question is directed to the Attorney‐General. Has the Attorney‐General seen the reports in the Age newspaper about the deportation of Mohamed Hassanien? Are these reports accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for his question. Yes, I have seen the reports. ASIO has, regrettably, reported that Australia is not immune from extremist groups as a range of ethnic, religious and cultural differences flourish in different parts of the globe. I can say that the deportation of Hassanien represents the conclusion of a successful operation which involved ASIO, the Australian Federal Police, the Victoria Police and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. This operation demonstrates Australia's deep and continuing concern to stop the spread of terrorism. Wide‐ranging cooperation with other countries helped provide the background needed to bring this case to a successful conclusion.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of that cooperation, information was received that Hassanien may have been in Australia. ASIO conducted inquiries to confirm that information and to locate Hassanien. The inquiries were extensive, involved a number of agencies and were made more difficult by Hassanien's use of false travel documents. Once his presence in Australia was confirmed, ASIO advised the AFP, and a joint operation including the Victoria Police and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs was undertaken, leading to a successful arrest. The government was kept fully informed of the investigation.

While this case demonstrates Australia's continued commitment to preventing international terrorism, I am concerned that the operational details were revealed in the media so extensively. I have spoken to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police and expressed my concern about that. The commissioner has undertaken to investigate the matter and ensure that appropriate procedures are in place to cover similar situations in the future. I do not expect to report on the outcome of the investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister confirm that China, Indonesia, the Philippines and Vietnam have all made official protests against the government's decision to axe development projects to be funded by the development import finance facility? Has the Chinese ambassador stated that your decision will `do no good to the Australian side in terms of our credibility and business interests'? In addition, has the Chinese government now made at least four representations at vice‐ministerial level seeking a reversal of the decision to scrap DIFF? How do you reconcile your stated commitment to extend and develop Australia's engagement with Asia with the serious regional backlash you are provoking, to the detriment of our international reputation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I reckon the Labor Party has had 140 questions since the election. You thought this issue was so serious that it took you 140 questions to get to it. The fact is that we made this decision before the last election.
—Answer the question.
—I will in a second. We made this decision before the last election, and it took you 140 questions to get to it; you thought it was such an important and serious issue.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have travelled around South‐East Asia and North‐East Asia and met foreign ministers and other ministers from those countries there and here, not one minister—be he a foreign minister or an economic development minister—has expressed any concern to me about the abolition of the DIFF program. Not one! If this was an issue of some deep and abiding concern to the few countries that you mention, as the Labor Party spuriously tries to claim, then you would have thought that they would raise it with me as the foreign minister. Or is it so important that they do not raise it with the foreign minister? That is the logic, is it?

Oh, come on, Laurie! You have a long way to go. You sat through those conferences in Washington for two days without uttering a word, and we now know why. You had nothing to say. The fact is that this suggestion that countries in our region are somehow deeply concerned about a $124 million aid program is one of the most monumental beat‐ups in history.

The fact is that of course some officials who are involved in the details of these programs have raised issues with my department, and you would not expect otherwise. But if this was a serious issue in our relationships they would raise it at the ministerial level. They would be writing me letters. They would be expressing their concerns to me. There has been not one raised. All I can say is that that torpedoes the totally spurious argument that the member for Kingsford‐Smith is coming forward with these days.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got a lot to learn.

—No, you do. Did it do you harm to reduce the aid budget, as a proportion of GNP, in terms of your engagement with the region? By the time of the last election campaign, the member for Holt and the former Prime Minister—that reminds me to say something about the former Prime Minister—were going around saying that they had had enormous success in terms of engagement with Asia, yet you had reduced aid, as a proportion of GNP, from 0.36 per cent to 0.33 per cent. What is the story? For that matter, we have not breached contracts with anybody. We have honoured all our contracts.

BREAK.PARA: I will say one other thing about this. You guys are making party political comments from your miserable position of opposition. The former Prime Minister does not have to, does he? Your former leader does not have to do that. I have noticed that as he moves from playing Labor Party politics to the role of elder statesman he has gone out of his way to acknowledge the success of this government's foreign policy, and the success, in particular, of our engagement with Asia. He did that just yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Giving him the benefit of the doubt.
—You're still here. I have noticed how quiet you are. Madam integrity is sitting over there. You pious one.
—Order! The minister will resume his seat.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I am aware that the minister did not hear from me in his time in opposition and I am not surprised by that. In five questions in two days he has disregarded the standing orders. He has not spoken through you. He has not answered the questions. He is at the stage of becoming an embarrassment to the parliament. I would ask you to uphold your opening remarks as to how you will run this chamber.
—I thank the member for Newcastle. I remind the Minister for Foreign Affairs about his obligations to address the House through the chair.
—Mr Speaker, I always fulfil my obligations as best I can.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I know in this particular context that the minister can get quite excited, but I find the language he directed towards the honourable member for Fremantle offensive. I ask you to require him to withdraw it, lest of course he starts to launch into some of the anti‐Catholic jokes he told in the United States.

—Order! There is no point of order. I am sure that if the member for Fremantle felt considerably distressed by the assertions she would seek to defend herself. I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—I was only making the point before the two points of order—one from the member for Newcastle, who is obviously fighting a preselection and has decided on a rearguard action to stay in this place by raising points of order—that yesterday in a speech by the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, which I thought was very interesting and another one of his foreign policy speeches which in essence I have generally approved of and thought were quite appropriate—

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I know that standing order 145 does not rule out pompous twaddle, but it demands that the pompous twaddle be relevant. I ask you to draw the minister's attention to that.
—Order! There is no point of order. The minister is rapidly bringing his answer to a conclusion.
—It is coming to a conclusion, Mr Speaker. Talk about the pot calling the kettle black. That is a bit rich, Gareth.
—Gary!

—They say you were called Gary when you were young. We should stick with Gary. I was trying to make the point that the Labor Party continually takes points of order. The former Prime Minister, I thought quite appropriately, pointed out with approval the successful policies of this government in terms of engagement with the region. If there was any suggestion of truth in the spurious question put forward by the member for Kingsford‐Smith, who allowed 140 questions to be asked by the opposition before he decided to get to this one, surely it would have been raised with me in all the meetings I have had. But no, it never has been. It simply proves how desperate you are to make some sort of cheap political point.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. I draw the minister's attention to the UNICEF report entitled The progress of nations 1996 . The report found that Australia has an overall child poverty rate of 10 per cent and that more than 50 per cent of Australian children in sole parent families are living below the poverty line. Can the minister detail what action the government is taking to address this appalling and shameful situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Makin for that question. The findings of the report are a damning indictment of Labor's commitment as enunciated by former Prime Minister Bob Hawke when he declared that no Australian child shall live in poverty by 1990. It is a fact that under Labor there has been a widening of the gap between the rich and the poor and a decline of 25 per cent in the number of households in Australia earning between $22,000 and $72,000 per annum.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is there has also been a doubling of the number of people earning less than $22,000 per annum. Unemployment and family dislocation are two of the principal causes of growing poverty and of growing social inequality in our community. Younger single people, some of whom live in neighbourhoods where unemployment has exceeded 50 per cent, now make up 25 per cent of all Australians living in poverty. This is not to mention those of the indigenous population for whom employment is not an option in many parts of Australia.

Now there is also Labor's legacy of 600,000 Australian children who live in families with income levels below $22,000 per annum. As the member for Makin has quite rightly pointed out, many of these children come from sole parent families—Labor's legacy. The report findings are a sad testimonial to 13 years of economic mismanagement.

By contrast, this government is committed to the most significant family tax initiatives this country has ever seen. This initiative is targeted at lower and middle income earners, many of whom found it increasingly difficult to make ends meet under the Labor government, as the UNICEF report has quite rightly pointed out. Our policy will mean an extra $21 per week for a single income family of five on average weekly earnings, with at least one child under five.

In addition, the Prime Minister has recognised homeless youth as a particularly vulnerable group in our community and has implemented the homeless youth task force to address this growing problem. This is a practical policy, a practical reform, that will reduce the vulnerability of those young people—and there are some 20,000 of them every night in this country who have to seek shelter and who are, essentially, homeless youth. That is an indictment of 13 years of Labor's policy. Our government's approach is action, not rhetoric and humbug.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister, representing the Prime Minister. I refer to reports that the mining industry is to step up its campaign for the retention of the diesel fuel rebate scheme after a weekend in which they failed to win assurances from the Deputy Leader of the National Party, Mr Anderson. Why is the government not prepared to honour its election commitment to retain the diesel fuel rebate scheme and give certainty to the mining industry? Doesn't the Deputy Prime Minister understand that such uncertainty is bad for business, and particularly for such a crucial part of our export performance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —May I remind the member for Maribyrnong that, firstly, he should get his tactics right—because he jumped in ahead of one of his frontbenchers. You can't even publish a list. When you do publish a list, you give it to our side of politics. We can give you some advice on being in opposition to help you because you are going to be there for a long while yet.

ANSWER.PARA: The member for Maribyrnong raises the issue of the diesel fuel rebate. That is an important scheme. All will be revealed in respect of the diesel fuel rebate scheme and other budgetary matters on 20 August. But the truth of the matter is that both this federal government and the state governments referred to earlier are having to deal with the fiscal problems caused by the recession `we had to have' a couple of years ago.

I remind you that it was your government that gave us that recession. I remind you of the quote of former Prime Minister Keating, `This is the recession we had to have,' and we are all paying the price for that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Recently a newspaper in my electorate announced that a fourth runway was imminent for the Jandakot airport. Could the minister give me an assurance that the Federal Airports Corporation and his department have no current plans for such a runway?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Canning for her question. She has drawn my attention to media reports in a newspaper in her electorate that put the proposal that a fourth runway could be constructed at Jandakot airport and the honourable member for Canning has raised this as a matter of concern to her. Can I say to the honourable member for Canning and other members of this House that the Federal Airports Corporation undertook a review of the future needs of Jandakot airport in 1989 and put forward a number of developments that would be, in their view, required for the future operations of that airport.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the proposals that was put was for the construction of a fourth runway at Jandakot airport. I inform the honourable member for Canning that a study was then undertaken and it was deemed that there was no need for a fourth runway at Jandakot airport at least until the year 2010. In answer to the question that she put, I can advise the honourable member for Canning that neither the Federal Airports Corporation nor the Department of Transport and Regional Development has any immediate plans to construct a fourth runway at Jandakot. I can assure the honourable member for Canning and other members of this House that any proposals for developments at Jandakot airport will be done in full public consultation with the surrounding community to ensure that those people who live there can be fully informed and satisfied of any plans that may be in place for developments at Jandakot airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the honourable member for Perth.
—I have been kind to you.

—We hope you will kindly provide an answer today, Tim. My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade. The Deputy Prime Minister will recall the government's election commitment to maintain and extend the export market development grants scheme and his categorical statement during the election campaign, `EMDG stays.' Does the Deputy Prime Minister recall meeting the Australian Publishers Association last year? Does he recall giving a clear and unequivocal personal assurance to the association that a coalition government would continue the EMDG scheme? Does the Deputy Prime Minister stand by his assurance or are his assurances worth as much as the assurance of support currently being given to him by his National Party colleagues?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fischer, Tim, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Final deliberations on this matter will be revealed on 20 August when the federal budget comes down. We have a clear-cut policy position and there has been no announcement to the contrary with regard to that. The government has the challenge of working through $8 billion of deficit that has been created, and we are doing that in the fourth consecutive year of economic recovery. That is the chilling point. Ralph Willis, the member for Gellibrand, knows only well enough that it is that dimension which is particularly of concern to any reasonable thinking person. Here we are in the fourth year of economic recovery facing an $8 billion deficit. We have to deal with that as a legacy of a federal Labor government, and we will deal with it constructively.

ANSWER.PARA: In the process we have had to rectify a few other things, not the least of which is our export trading effort with regard to Asia, and Malaysia in particular. I am pleased to say to the shadow minister for trade that we have had to pick up the pieces of that particular bilateral relationship and the Minister for Foreign Affairs has moved quickly to help bring that about.

The Prime Minister has met with Dr Mahathir and during this most recent fortnight I was able to negotiate with Minister for Trade Rafidah from Malaysia a sensible and modern trade agreement. We were able to initial that at Parliament House in Canberra to get the Australian-Malaysian bilateral trading arrangements back on the front foot—arrangements which you had put way behind the eight ball. We will deliver a very constructive budget which will be of great benefit for the future economic effort and future export effort of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, I have a constituent who is concerned that she may find her job conditions changed as an apprentice hairdresser. Can you please assure my constituent that the modern apprenticeship and traineeship system will have no effect on current traineeships or apprenticeships or in fact new ones in the same industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for La Trobe for his question. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to correct the misrepresentations which are being spread around the country by the members of the opposition. The fact is that under the proposals for the modern apprenticeship and traineeship system there will be no change to the employment conditions for apprentices and trainees. Employers will still be able to pay their apprentices and trainees on a weekly basis as they are able to do at the moment.
—Three dollars an hour.
—This is the misrepresentation you have been spreading.
—The same amount?

—Yes, the same amount. They will pay the same amount for apprentices and trainees as they are paying at the moment. There is no proposal to change those conditions of employment. This policy of ours fully implements the take-home pay guarantee that the Prime Minister gave during the election campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: The misrepresentation which the opposition is attempting to spread to create totally unnecessary anxiety amongst apprentices and trainees is based on the proposition that, under the modern apprenticeship and traineeship system and under existing training arrangements, young trainees will be paid for their productive time and not for their time in training. This is an area which created enormous confusion on your side when it was first clarified.

The fact is that it took some effort on our part to remind you that that was precisely the principle which underlies the national training wage. It is precisely the principle which underlay the Australian traineeship system. As the shadow minister for industrial relations made clear, no-one would question the principle that trainees and apprentices should be paid for their productiveness. Did you say that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not support what you are proposing.

—The shadow minister for industrial relations has accepted that principle on behalf of the opposition. Yet the more unscrupulous members of the opposition frontbench are going around the country trying to tell apprentices and trainees that somehow or other their payment arrangements are going to change and that they are no longer going to be paid so much, because they are not going to be paid for their time in training. All that is totally untrue. The fact is that they will be paid what they will be paid now. There will be no change, as we have said on numerous occasions—and the member for La Trobe can take this message back to his electorate—to the payment arrangements that they currently exist under because those arrangements are defined under the awards.
—What about new entrants?

—New entrants will be paid the full award rate for their time in productive work—precisely the principle which applies under the national training wage arrangements. There will be added flexibility to combine different mixes of training and productive work. You would do a much greater service to the young people of this country by telling them the opportunities that really exist for them instead of misrepresenting the government's policies and trying to create unnecessary fear and anxiety.
—Sadly, I must bring this to an end. Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Last Friday my office here in Parliament House was opened to provide access to a senator's staffer, to give that person full access to my office. I have been apologised to by the senator in question. I have reported this to the Serjeant‐at‐Arms. But I would request you, Mr Speaker, as a person of integrity, to have a full investigation into this matter and for a direction to be given to all government members, ministers and senators so that this does not occur again. I regard it as an act of trespass.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Prospect has raised a very serious issue, and in my time here I think it is the first occasion that this has occurred. I have today been advised that there was an unauthorised access to a member's suite last Friday. My understanding of the circumstances is that a government senator's staff member believed that a fax had been misdirected to the member's suite. One of the senator's staff approached security officers to gain entry to the member's office to recover the fax. The staff member was acting without the knowledge of the senator.
—Or my consent.

—Or that of the member for Prospect. The security officer arranged for a patrol to open the member's office for the senator's staff member. The staff member says that the security officer was requested to accompany her. The security officer had not obtained authorisation for access from either the Serjeant-at-Arms' Office or the member's office. This was a clear breach of procedure.

ANSWER.PARA: The patrol who opened the member's office believed access to have been authorised. This officer was called to address urgently another matter a short distance away and left the senator's staff member unattended in the member's office for a brief period. The officer returned within a few minutes to find that the senator's staff member had left the member's office and secured it. I understand that the misdirected fax was recovered from the member's office. As I understand it, nothing else was removed from the office.

This regrettable incident is clearly of very great concern to me and I am sure all members. I have directed the Serjeant-at-Arms and security controller to ensure that all access to members' suites is authorised through the appropriate procedures and that security staff are reminded of these procedures and that no variation will be tolerated.
Finally, I am advised that the senator brought the breach of security to the attention of the member and has apologised. I very much regret this most unpleasant happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, after hearing your remarks, maybe the Deputy Prime Minister might wish to bring to the attention of all ministers the fact that this is not the way the government should transact business. If they want access to offices of members of the opposition, they should seek permission.
—I think your points are most inappropriate in light of the seriousness with which we are addressing this problem.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Auditor‐General's audit report No. 28 of 1995‐96, entitled Performance audit: Jindalee Operational Radar Network Project: Department of Defence.

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) this House authorises the publication of the Auditor‐General's audit report No. 28 of 1995‐96; and
