SPEECH.PARA: Pension increases—from the member for Moore—124 petitioners

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The government's decision to slash Australia's overseas aid commitments to the detriment of our regional engagement and international humanitarian objectives.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I say at the outset how regrettable it is that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) has decided to absent himself from the chamber for this debate on what is an extraordinarily important issue for the parliament and indeed for all of Australia. It indicates a certain cavalier and irresponsible attitude on his part. I dare say it is entirely consistent with the approach he took yesterday in his thinly veiled attack on the integrity of Richard Woolcott, the Chairman of the Australia-Indonesia Institute.

SPEECH.PARA: All honourable members are aware that the United Nations has declared this year, 1996, as the International Year for the Eradication of Poverty. No member of this House should question the necessity for intensifying our international efforts and making every effort possible to eliminate poverty and to alleviate social injustice.

As the Australian Council for Overseas Aid declares in its submission on this year's overseas aid budget, the persistence of hunger and extreme poverty is the most profound moral and spiritual contradiction of our age. Despite 50 years of great achievement by international foreign aid programs, the gap today between rich and poor continues to grow. Today, in this age of immense economic and technological accomplishment, more than 1.3 billion people survive on an income of less than $1 a day and are denied their basic rights of health, education, shelter, clean water supply and sanitation.

Five hundred million of the world's 800 million most needy people live in the Asia-Pacific region; that is, they live in our region. I put it to the House that the problem of global poverty and social injustice is right here on our doorstep and we as a nation cannot turn our backs against it. It is against that backdrop that the Minister for Foreign Affairs last month established an independent review of Australia's overseas aid programs. In making his announcement, the minister rightly said that Australia has an overseas aid program of which all Australians can be proud. He put this on the record:

Millions of people around the world are now better off thanks to the help they've received from Australia. Our aid program, administered by AusAID and delivered by Australian companies, individuals, non-government organisations and academic institutions is highly effective.

They are the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs when he announced the review. For our part, the opposition welcomed the establishment of the review, chaired as it is by Mr Paul Simons, the former executive chairman of Woolworths. It is our view that, in ever changing international circumstances, the continuous review of Australia's overseas aid program is crucially important for maximising its effectiveness and for making sure that we maintain its primary focus of contributing to lasting poverty reduction whilst also serving Australia's international interests.

Although many individual Australian aid programs and projects have been subject to comprehensive review down through the years, it is now some years since the Jackson report on Australia's overall aid program. We readily agreed that the new review established by the government is an appropriate and timely one to take place in this International Year for the Eradication of Poverty.

What the Minister for Foreign Affairs declined to mention when he announced his review was that, as a consequence of the government's ruthless slash and burn approach to the aid budget, Australia's commitment to provide development assistance and to alleviate poverty in and beyond our region is about to fall to its lowest level in more than 20 years; that is, it will fall to below 0.3 per cent of one per cent of our gross national product. As I pointed out when the minister made his announcement, any review will be a farce if the job of the review team is simply to pick up the pieces after the government has taken the axe to our overseas aid programs. Alternatively, the real purpose of the review may be just that: to work out what might be done with a greatly reduced aid budget.

On our side of the House, we are proud that Labor increased aid spending in real terms in each of our last six budgets. In 1995-96, we provided just over $1.5 billion; that is, 0.33 per cent of GNP. That is a proportionate decline only because of the rapid growth of the Australian economy, but it is a real increase in dollar terms and a substantial improvement on the OECD average of 0.3 of one per cent. That is the truth of it.

Under Labor, Australia was one of only four OECD donor countries to increase its aid budget in real terms. We did it year after year and we are immensely proud of it. In the lead-up to this year's federal election, the coalition publicly reiterated its support for the bipartisan UN goal of applying 0.7 per cent of GNP to overseas aid. For Australia to meet our international obligations and show Australia's international good citizenship, the government must demonstrate a serious commitment to achieving the UN target with, at the very least, annual real increases in the aid program as urged by ACFOA.

The abolition of the development improvement finance facility program was announced by the coalition during the election campaign long before any fatuous talk about budget black holes. If the money saved by the abolition is removed from the overall aid program rather than redirected to other parts of the program, it will represent a 7.9 per cent cut to Australia's aid program. That will be the first time that we will have seen Australia's overseas aid program fall to below 0.3 per cent of one per cent. It will have fallen to 0.29 per cent of GNP. It will be the first time in history that our Australian aid level has fallen below the weighted OECD average. No responsible or moral Australian would regard such an outcome as anything other than a national disgrace and a grave embarrassment for a country whose closest neighbours in Asia and the South Pacific are overwhelmingly developing countries.

The foreign affairs minister has spoken at length about the need to respond to humanitarian concerns. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has promised to protect the needy against his government's budget cuts, but those words clearly count for nothing when the foreign minister has already axed the DIFF scheme without any reallocation of funds to other programs. Indeed, he is reported to have accepted the need for further aid cuts as deep as 25 per cent.

What is perhaps most astonishing is the preparedness of the government to proceed on this course of action, which is so contrary to its stated commitment to achieve lasting poverty reduction and is so detrimental to our regional engagement. The across‐the‐board axing of DIFF funded aid programs without any evaluation of the merits of individual programs or recognition of the serious consequences for Australia has received near universal condemnation. It has been condemned universally both at home and abroad.

Thanks to the government's actions, Australia now faces a major regional backlash and serious damage to our international credibility as our neighbours are forced to cancel important development projects, including programs for the provision of clean water and electricity in rural and remote areas. In many cases, the recipient countries have already invested significant funds themselves. Those investments have been made on the assumption of the good faith of the Australian government.

In eastern Indonesia, for example, 21 regional laboratories will not now be equipped with Australian scientific equipment for environmental monitoring, including water quality monitoring on five major rivers, despite the fact that the principal Australian supplier has in the last 18 months invested more than $1.3 million in the project with the written encouragement of the Australian government. The Indonesian government itself has expended more than $500,000 to upgrade the laboratories to operate the new Australian equipment.

Across the region, our neighbours are being told that understandings reached in good faith count for nothing in the calculations of the new Australian government. It is little wonder that China, Indonesia, Vietnam and the Philippines have all made official protests through their ambassadors and at our embassies throughout the region. As I pointed out in question time today, the Chinese ambassador has left the government in no doubt that the scrapping of DIFF projects in China will do Australia no good in terms of our credibility or business interests. Representations have been made by the Chinese government, irrespective of whether the minister admits it, at a vice‐ministerial level on at least four occasions. They have sought a reversal of the government's decision to cut over 50 per cent of Australia's aid to China.

Similarly, the Philippines ambassador has stated publicly that the decision to scrap DIFF creates a perception that Australia was not serious in its engagement in the region, while senior Indonesian officials in Jakarta have said Australia is `shooting itself in the foot' by scrapping DIFF. In eastern Indonesia this is most certainly the case. The 21 environmental monitoring laboratories that I mentioned earlier were to be equipped by Australian companies. That work will now almost certainly go to Japanese competitors.
Only yesterday, here in this chamber, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) said:
No country is more central to Australia's drive into Asia than Indonesia.

That is what he said. But with the axing of DIFF, Japanese scientific equipment will become the benchmark for environmental monitoring in Indonesia, and Australia will effectively be locked out of this key export market. So much for the often boasted engagement by the new government of the clever country of Australia in Asia.

It is very hard to see the logic of the decision to scrap DIFF. It is absolutely impossible to see the logic as it affects the 52 individual projects in the DIFF pipeline. The comprehensive effectiveness review of the program, the one conducted by AusAID with the assistance of independent consultants, released only in January this year, found that the vast majority of the projects carried out under DIFF contributed to the overall economic and social advancement of the recipient countries and met the primary objectives of our aid program.

Moreover, the review found that DIFF had generated substantial commercial benefits for Australia. Almost all firms surveyed stated that DIFF had been important to their business, with half stating that it was either crucial or very important to their operations. Combined with funding from the Export Finance Insurance Corporation, the 51 projects examined in the review—involving some $285 million of AusAID funds—generated direct project expenditure in Australia worth $709 million.

In addition, follow-up business already won by the companies and directly related to the original DIFF project was estimated at $263 million, and the firms predicted a further $397 million of follow-on business to be achieved over the year following the survey. Total business generated as a result of the projects is therefore estimated at $1.37 billion or almost five times the original aid expenditure. For many Australian companies a DIFF project was also their first overseas contract. As a consequence, they changed their focus from solely concentrating on our domestic market to including a significant export orientation in their activities.

For every dollar invested in DIFF, Australia received a fivefold return while contributing directly to long-term alleviation of poverty and economic development in the region. Unfortunately, however, DIFF is no more, though the government—and it is no surprise—has told companies that it may consider the establishment of a similar arrangement in the future. In the meantime, however, total Australian commercial losses on the projects in the DIFF pipeline resulting from the government's decision are estimated to exceed $67 million.

PARA.BREAK: In the case of the high‐technological environmental monitoring project in eastern Indonesia, no less than 67 Australian com panies—almost all of them small and medium size business—are counting their losses. Across the country some 600 subcontractors are estimated to be affected—a state of affairs which makes an absolute mockery of the Prime Minister's statement that the government supports small and medium business. There is little wonder that the decision to scrap DIFF has been universally condemned by Australian businessmen and by such commentators as Bert Evans of the Metal Trades Industry Association, who described its abolition as `foolish' and as `the most short‐sighted thing' he had seen in his career.

SPEECH.PARA: Under Labor, Australia had an aid program which produced win-win outcomes. We achieved real and lasting benefits for the people and nations of our region. We lifted living standards, provided long-term solutions to the problems of poverty, disease, malnutrition, lack of access to education and basic services. We gave substance to our growing regional engagement and contributed directly and substantially to our bilateral relations with our friends and neighbours. It was good for the Australian economy and good for Australian workers.

Now, tragically, we are caught in a lose-lose situation. Crucial aid projects are, at this very moment, being cancelled with grave consequences for the recipient regions and their communities. ACFOA hit the nail on the head in saying that slashing the aid budget and abolishing DIFF sends all the wrong signals to our neighbours. At the same time, the impact on Australian jobs has aroused condemnation from a coalition of opinion including business, aid organisations, union leaders, conservative state premiers and ordinary Australians who believe our nation should play its part and pull its weight. The government stands condemned for its short‐sighted and miserly approach on this important policy issue—the approach described very fairly by one leading foreign policy commentator as `dumb, dumb, dumb'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Andrew, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDREW THOMSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is one of the cruelest ironies of this debate that the gentleman who probably knows the most about developmental cooperation and aid matters is not here to lead this MPI for the opposition. Mr Gordon Bilney was the previous member for Kingston and Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, and as he sits on his yacht pondering the reasons for his defeat and who to blame for it, I wonder if his mind might venture as far as the honourable gentleman from Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton). The irony is cruelest in Mr Bilney's case.

SPEECH.PARA: This MPI is specifically about the abolition of the DIFF—the development import finance facility. In answering the honourable gentleman's allegations and criticisms, I point out very bluntly that yes, we said during the election campaign that this would be abolished and yes, it does amount to an eight per cent cut in the total aid budget. We said that before the election. We said it very clearly.

Let us look back at what the opposition's record was when it was in government, as far back as 1993, when Mr Kerin—a fine gentleman and the predecessor in the seat of my friend the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham)—was the minister responsible for the aid budget. He promised during the 1993 election campaign that the then government would lift the aid budget as a percentage of Australia's GNP from 0.36 per cent to 0.4 per cent during the period 1993 to 1996, where we find ourselves today.

We said at the time that such a commitment could not be believed or trusted and, of course, he denied that. But the fact is that, under Labor, the aid budget fell from 0.36 per cent to 0.33 per cent in the period from 1993 to 1996. If we go back to February this year, we find that Labor did it again. This time it was Senator Evans—Senator Gary Evans as he is to be known henceforth, or Mr Gary Evans, the member for Holt—who said in a prepared speech that he delivered on 23 February—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I understood that members of parliament should refer to other members by their title and not in any other form.
—They certainly should, and the parliamentary secretary certainly will.

—I thought the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) was the shadow minister for points of order, but you seem to be claiming some of his territory. I will henceforth refer to him as the member for Holt. He read a prepared speech to a forum put on by Community Aid Abroad—sponsors, I might add, of today's great national day of action. In promoting its national day of action and fomenting a protest in front of the national parliament, how many people did it attract? Twenty! There were 20 people at the Community Aid Abroad's national day of action protest outside the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Back to the member for Holt: he said in this prepared speech that he committed the Labor Party to increasing the aid budget, again as a percentage of GNP, from 0.33 per cent to 0.4 per cent by the year 2000—once again, the same target of 0.4 per cent—and in doing so he drew a distinction between a commitment and a mere aspiration. I quote from his speech at the time:

We retain the aspiration to continue real increases in aid to reach the UN target for official development assistance of 0.7 per cent of GNP, and the commitment to at least get to 0.40 per cent by the year 2000 . . .

That is a pretty clear commitment. But the problem that this poses is that, to fulfil such a commitment, the Labor Party in government would have had to find an extra $1.2 billion. It would have needed $1.2 billion extra money, unfunded, to meet that commitment of 0.4 per cent.

What is the man who made that promise doing now? He is my friend the member for Werriwa's immediate boss; he is the shadow Treasurer—the person who would bandy around that sort of a commitment in an election campaign without the slightest hope of ever finding the money. Three days later, once he realised the scale of this folly—folie de grand—in a speech before the National Press Club he had to retract the promise.

There you see a clear difference between what the opposition will do in an election campaign—make commitments it cannot meet and then quickly fudge them a few days later in a speech—and what the coalition on this side of the House does. The coalition is always quite plain about the commitments it makes. You will see demonstrated on 20 August, when the budget is brought down, that it will fulfil those commitments.

We make no bones about the abolition of DIFF. But it is worth drawing the House's attention to something that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) alluded to during question time today in his answer to a question posed by the shadow minister. He asked the House to ask itself how important this issue is to the opposition and why it was that the first question in this House about this scheme was made 98 days after this government was sworn in, despite the terrible consequences that the shadow minister alludes to—all this wailing and gnashing of teeth across the Asian region. This must have been plain from the moment we made the announcement during the campaign that we would abolish it. But no, it took 98 days and it was the 140th question. And the question, we are given to understand, was unscheduled.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even your own backbench thought it was a stupid decision. Talk to your backbench.
—The member for Chifley, who was so assiduous in drawing the chair's attention to standing orders, might observe them himself.

—Talk about those in glass houses. Why was it that it took 140 questions before the shadow minister for trade jumped up and asked an unscheduled question to the wrong minister? You know why we know about it? Because the staff members from the office of the shadow minister for foreign affairs rang Mr Downer's office last night to complain about it.

SPEECH.PARA: That said, let me talk a little more about why we settled on DIFF as what we were going to abolish. Quite plainly, you can sum it up in two words: fiscal discipline. Budgetary health is quite plainly the prerequisite for economic health and competitiveness in this region and the reduction of real interest rates. Having been in private enterprise for a while, I know that what a business has to pay for money is a serious cost to any business. The consequence of a country borrowing too much or a government being too profligate is always that the companies, the enterprises and the individuals within that economy must pay more for money.

It is plain to us and to the opposition, though they are loath to admit it, that we face very serious problems with the current account deficit and with our savings ratio. In order to arrest the trend of national dis‐saving, we have to take some hard decisions in making reductions to all portfolio areas of the federal government, bar the defence budget. In saying so, we are quite clear that the aid budget cannot be quarantined from this sort of austerity. There is no reason why, in trying to reclaim some of the next generation's assets that have already been spent by the previous government, we should spare the aid budget when we are making the same difficult and hard decisions in other areas, especially where it delivers political pain to Australia in domestic terms. So fiscal discipline is quite plainly necessary if Australia is going to engage effectively in this region and if it is going to be a strong and growing trading nation.

The honourable gentleman alluded in his speech to the notion that, in abolishing the DIFF, we are somehow doing away with an extraordinary fivefold increase in the trade benefits that accrue to the companies whom we subsidise under this program.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Richard Woolcott?
—Mr Woolcott, we should not overlook, is financially interested in this program. He was a consultant to Transfield—
—Are you reflecting on his ability or his integrity?

—Yes, I am. Because in the letter he wrote to me, Mr Woolcott did not disclose that he was a paid consultant of Transfield, a fine Australian company. It would have been the simplest thing for him to mention in the first paragraph, `As a consultant to one of the companies that stands to gain under the DIFF program, I make the following criticisms.'

SPEECH.PARA: If Nick Greiner or any other senior politician who has left office for whatever reason and taken up a directorship with an Australian company as part of their post-parliamentary career makes comments in the media thereafter pressing the concerns of those companies, they are always described as `Nick Greiner, a director of so-and-so' or `Bob Hawke, promoter of whatever it is in parts of Asia'. It is plain and transparent. Both Mr Downer and I were taken by surprise when we learnt privately from Transfield that Mr Woolcott had been a consultant to them during the period when they were seeking the contract in the Philippines for these ships. When the managing director, Paul Salteri, rang me up at some point—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying Woolcott gained financially from this?

—I would like to ask him to explain whether or not he was in line for some sort of bonus had this deal gone ahead. It was plain that he was paid to consult Transfield to promote their interests in the Philippines—
—This is a very serious allegation.
—It is not an allegation; it is a question. I want to know whether it is true.
—You think there was a bonus?

—No. I am asking whether there was one. I will go back to the idea that there is a fivefold benefit ahead for any company that is subsidised under this program. We were suspicious of that. We thought it was a rather shallow notion, so we showed the AusAID in-house review of the effectiveness of the DIFF program to Treasury and asked them to scrutinise it and find some flaws in it.

PARA.BREAK: And what did Treasury find? Sure enough, the adjectives they used to describe the review were `superficial', `shallow' and `somewhat flawed'. Among other things, they found that the review did not distinguish between gross expenditures made under DIFF programs and net benefits—that is, the review did not take into account the opportunity cost. No effort seems to have been made to estab lish the veracity of the survey data collected for that.

SPEECH.PARA: More particularly, the review did not ask whether or not DIFF supported activity was actually better or worse than other activity. For example, most of the projects in the DIFF pipeline—even in the latter days of DIFF—were infrastructure projects that took place in spoiled markets. Those spoiled markets are where companies, especially French, German and Japanese companies, competed for these projects with subsidies—subsidies which, in some cases, were not just from their federal governments but from their state governments. So it is fair for Australian parliamentarians to ask ourselves whether we should always be there with our cheque book in these spoiled markets.

In other words, why should we not spend this aid money on other types of developmental cooperation, or—and this is a terrible notion that the opposition has had to swallow—why should we not return it to the taxpayers by making an absolute reduction in the expenditure? When you look at other activities that take place as part of the aid program where we have to make a choice of what to cut, what should we cut? Should we cut the HIV‐AIDS programs for people in Thailand, Papua New Guinea or the Pacific? These, in my opinion, are of far more immediate consequence to Australians and deserve a higher priority than any form of mixed credit scheme. Or should we make budget cuts to programs which support the education of women and girls? Should we do that?

We have to set a list of priorities in this, and it is the problems of health, immediate poverty and sickness that strike us as deserving a higher priority than mixed credit schemes. That is why the minister said that, if there is room and if budgetary circumstances permit—that is, if we do our job in this year's budget and restore some rectitude to the federal budget—down the track, in the financial year after next, we may be able to reintroduce a form of mixed credit scheme and resume some of the projects that were in the pipeline. If it was the case that after the election we had been left with a budget that was in a reasonable shape, I have no doubt that there would be no abolition of a scheme like DIFF.

That said, let me also point out one other thing the shadow minister said that is quite wrong. He said that, as a consequence of our reduction of the DIFF scheme, Australia's ODA to GNP ratio would fall from 0.3 per cent to about 0.29 per cent. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on today's MPI, which is entitled:

SPEECH.PARA: The government's decision to slash Australia's overseas aid commitments to the detriment of our regional engagement and international humanitarian objectives.
The member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), shadow minister for foreign affairs, spoke in detailed terms on Australia's overseas aid commitments and our international humanitarian obligations.

I would like to focus on that part of the MPI which refers to the detriment of our regional engagement. It is clear that, so far as our aid program is concerned, not only are we looking at the notion of seeking to assist developing countries; we are also conscious of our place in the international arena and in the region and the sorts of benefits which come to a nation through having a sustained and sensible aid program. So far as Australia is concerned, that gets down to notions of trade and notions of export—not just export of goods but export of our expertise.

The development import finance facility, the DIFF scheme, has, in a sense, two bangs for the taxpayer's buck. The government has abolished the scheme. The two bangs for the buck are that the scheme is an effective aid program and it also brings very many benefits to Australia so far as trade and exports are concerned.

PARA.BREAK: As part of the government's response to its abolition of the DIFF scheme, so far as trade related matters are concerned, the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) has had the opportunity to explain to the House how this could somehow enhance Australia's trade and export performances. But he has ducked the ques tions, and we know why he has been ducking—because he has other things on his mind.

SPEECH.PARA: In his absence, his colleagues have been talking amongst themselves. We have found the following headlines in Australia's press in recent days—in the Sunday Age, `Crisis looms for Fischer'; in the Australian, `Sinclair turns the screws on Fischer'; `Heat on Fischer as MPs hit out'; `Embattled Fischer defies party critics'; in Monday's Sydney Morning Herald, `Leadership the topic which would not go away'; and, in the Financial Review, `Fischer faces party fire over gun stance.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would draw the honourable member's attention to the content of the MPI and suggest that he direct his remarks to that.

—I am directing my remarks directly to those aspects of the matter which go to our regional engagement, and I have always regarded trade as an aspect of that. The response of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) has been to do two things. Firstly, as he did in question time today, to say that the abolition of DIFF is a monumental beat‐up, that it is not a serious issue and, to quote his words back to him, it is specious to suggest otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, anyone who suggests that the abolition of DIFF is other than a monumental beat‐up, that it is a serious and not a specious issue, is blackguarded. We saw yesterday the Minister for Foreign Affairs blackguard the former head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Woolcott, and we saw the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Andrew Thomson) today continuing that blackguarding, raising serious questions about Mr Woolcott's integrity and credibility.

Let us have a look at when Mr Woolcott first raised the issue of the abolition of DIFF. He first did it to my knowledge a month ago, Wednesday, 15 May, reported in the Financial Review as `Loss of DIFF draws attack from Woolcott'. Mr Woolcott is recorded in the Australian Financial Review as saying:

There are some very good projects in the pipeline which ministers in Indonesia, the Philippines, Vietnam and China were expecting to go ahead . . . Scrapping them retrospectively could undermine Australia's credibility as a reliable supplier, and advantage our commercial competitors in the region, who may pick up those projects which Australian companies will not be able to proceed with . . .
It also means considerable wasted time and investment on the part of a number of Australian companies.

Those comments by Mr Woolcott were picked up in the Weekend Australian of 18 and 19 May. There is also analysis by Geoff Hiscock in the Australian : `Demise of DIFF a loss of face'. I quote from his analysis:

. . . Australia's competitors for Asian infrastructure projects will be shaking their heads in wonderment at our short-sightedness . . . What it will not save is Australian face among Asian friends . . . Japanese, German, French, Italian and Spanish companies all benefit . . .
He goes on to refer to an Australian Council for Overseas Aid statement which refers to the abolition of DIFF as sending `all the wrong signals'.

Mr Woolcott made the mistake of repeating these analyses of policy and criticisms of the abolition of DIFF in a letter to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs which was reported in the Australian of this week. In his letter, Mr Woolcott is reported as repeating his view that the abolition of DIFF will damage the credibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and of the government in Asia, that it will offend neighbouring governments, that it will undermine our national credibility, and harm Australia's competitiveness. The price which Mr Woolcott pays for that is to be blackguarded in this House by the Minister for Foreign Affairs—best seen in the Canberra Times report today headed `Howard's envoy decked by Downer', a report by Ian McPhedran which states:
The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer, launched yesterday an extraordinary attack on former senior diplomat and Howard Government envoy Richard Woolcott.

This is the Prime Minister's personal envoy to Malaysia. This is the man who organised the transit lounge meetings between the Prime Minister of Malaysia and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. This is the person who is well regarded as President of the Australia-Indonesia Institute.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs comes into this place and says that discussion on the abolition of DIFF is a huge beat‐up. Let me just very quickly go through some of the people who do not regard this as a beat‐up—people who now run the risk of being blackguarded by the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the parliamentary secretary in this place and having their reputations, credibility and integrity attacked.

Let us have a look at the comments of Mr Ian Berckelman, who is the Managing Director of Labax International. On the 7.30 Report in May this year, in an interview with Kerry O'Brien and Barrie Cassidy, Mr Berckelman is quoted as saying:
The DIFF scheme is the only tool that Australian business has to enable it to secure infrastructure projects in the developing countries in South-East Asia.

If the DIFF scheme is cancelled and we don't get the funds for our project, I think we'll probably call it a day in Indonesia, because we're specialists in this sort of work and it requires a specialist. So, I think we'll probably pack up.
This is a company that has been active in Indonesia for 20 or 30 years. Mr Berckelman goes on to say:

So, we spend $1.3 million; the Indonesians have spent about . . . it must be close to half a million Australian dollars. And nobody gets the benefit. The project doesn't go ahead. You know, this is nuts. Really silly stuff.
He goes on to say:
. . . I don't believe the Government actually understands what it's doing.
And in reference to our neighbours in Asia, he says:
These people are ropeable. They're not happy. They don't like written agreements being broken, particularly memorandums of understanding at a government protocol level.
He concludes by saying:

If these projects don't go ahead, our reputation and the rest of the guys doing the DIFF scheme projects, it won't be worthwhile going back to Indonesia again. They will not do business because they'll never trust the Government or the supplier again.
These comments have been echoed by people whom you would not necessarily expect to be blackguarded by the Minister for Foreign Affairs or the parliamentary secretary.

We have seen the Premier of Victoria calling on the government to reverse its decision: `Kennett opposes Howard over DIFF'. We could understand if the Treasurer (Mr Costello) were blackguarding the Premier of Victoria, but we do not expect the Minister for Foreign Affairs to do so. The Premier of Victoria has come out seeking that the government reverse its decision on the same grounds that were drawn to attention by Mr Woolcott—this is, this is not a sensible thing to do so far as Australia's reliability and reputation in the region are concerned and it is not a sensible thing to do so far as trade, export and Australian jobs are concerned.
The MTIA, Australia's manufacturing engineering and construction industry association, in response to Mr Kennett's call, released a statement saying, `Kennett Right—DIFF Must Stay':
MTIA Chief Executive Bert Evans said that Mr Kennett had correctly identified the major dangers of abolishing the DIFF scheme to the Australian economy.

Do we now wait patiently for Mr Evans to be blackguarded by the Minister for Foreign Affairs? Can we expect to see a government representative at the MTIA dinner later this year, Mr Evans's retirement function, blackguarding Mr Evans because he has had the audacity to point out what is actually commonsense, namely, the short-sightedness of the government abolishing this scheme? We have seen Mr Evans describe the abolition of the scheme as `the most foolish and short-sighted thing' he has seen in his career.

These comments have been echoed by the Western Australian State Minister for Commerce and Trade, Hendy Cowan, one of Mr Fischer's National Party colleagues. He criticised the abolition a couple of weeks ago and said that Australia is going to be the only developed country which will not have an equivalent of the DIFF program.

A comprehensive analysis of the abolition of DIFF was conducted by the foreign editor of the Australian, Mr Sheridan. By way of conclusion, I will quote from his recent article in the Weekend Australian:

The one decision that has been seriously stupid is the abolition of the Development Import Finance Facility. Its abolition is a spectacularly stupid and short-sighted decision. The new Government took the view that aid should not be mixed up with trade and should not be a disguised subsidy for business. As well as slashing the aid budget generally, they promised to abolish DIFF . . .
This decision is dumb, dumb, dumb!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman, Lou, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance, in a way, is a sad indictment of the opposition. I would have thought the opposition would have been very embarrassed to have its poor performance revealed in relation to its responsibility to the humanitarian programs which we all so much want to see effectively funded for the benefit of people, such as those in Thailand, Zambia and Zimbabwe, because of the huge problem with the HIV virus, and because of child deaths and maternal mortality problems in other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: What the former government has done is to say to the Australian people and to the aid organisations, `We will fully fund these programs and the DIFF program.' We know that former Senator Gareth Evans, now the member for Holt, made some very firm commitments on behalf of the then government before the election about the future funding of all these programs. I would like to point out that those promises could not have been funded.

What the opposition has done today, with its new shadow minister for foreign affairs, the honourable member for Kingsford‐Smith (Mr Brereton)—and I wish him every success in his endeavours in a very exciting and interesting portfolio—is to put the new shadow minister in the spotlight to account for the fact that his predecessor, the former minister, now the member for Holt, did not have a hope in Hades of funding the aid promises and the DIFF program that we are now being criticised about.

PARA.BREAK: I think it is a matter of humbug for the opposition to come into the House today and piously present itself as being concerned for these people. The opposition talks about the concern on the part of our regional neigh bours about our policies. The fact is that our regional neighbours have no respect at all for a country which runs itself into debt, which says to children in the next generation, `You can pay for our recurrent expenditure.' That is really what the previous government has been saying and doing over 13½ years. In fact, it is their fault that the programs that we are now talking about have had to be cut.

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Andrew Thomson) has said that the government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) hope that when we restore financial strength to this nation—as we will, by working together—we can restore some benefits to business activity in some of these countries. But for the time being, let it be made clear to the opposition that our position is that we put more faith in having to maintain, as far as we can, the humanitarian programs than in paying a great company like Transfield a subsidy of $150 million under the DIFF program since 1982.

I make no criticism at all of Transfield. It has my great respect. All of us know it is a great Australian company. But we are talking about people in countries such as Zimbabwe, the high mortality rate of children in these countries and Australia's ability to fund humanitarian programs compared with our ability to fund support and subsidies for Australian business in these countries. I do not believe we would be responsible if we were to say, `We're going to cut the aid programs to these poor children and their families; we're going to take away the support for these people who are suffering from HIV, but we're going to continue to provide subsidies to Transfield, while we're battling in the domestic economy to bring this country back to proper management again.'

That is what it is all about. You have to prioritise your position and say to yourself, `No, we can't continue to fund those programs to businesses overseas in these circumstances. But we will revisit those programs and introduce appropriate credit programs when we can. In the meantime, we will do our best to ensure we can maintain the humanitarian programs, despite the great difficulty in what we will be able to do, because of the way in which the previous government ran the economy into the ground, overspent and left us with an $8 billion black hole.'

BREAK.PARA: I would like to pay tribute to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) for their outstanding achievements in the first 100 or so days of the Howard‐Fischer government. Already, we are seeing the benefits of that. I particularly welcome the initiative of the minister in the inquiry that has been established—the Simons review, as it will now be known, into aid programs. It is a long overdue inquiry. The shadow minister was wise enough to give his endorsement to that review, as he should.

I think we have let the former government off the hook, because one could ask why a review was not carried out earlier. Maybe when the review is completed some of the reasons why it was not carried out will be revealed, because there may well be some findings that some of the spending of the Australian government in the past 13½ years has not reached the target.

The review is the first one since the Jackson report in 1984. The world is a very different place now from what it was then. I encourage the minister, the parliamentary secretary and the Minister for Trade to challenge the practices of the past, to ensure that the aid programs, on behalf of Australian taxpayers, are reaching the target and are effective, because it is our responsibility to make sure that they do reach the people who need them in a very effective way.

There is no question that many of the aid programs have lost their way. I think that is acknowledged on both sides. It is time for a comprehensive review. I congratulate the government for opening the book in the way that it has and for appointing such eminent people to head the review. I look forward to the results of that review and wish Paul Simons, the former executive chairman of Woolworths—an outstandingly successful retail organisation in Australia—every success in his endeavours.

I return to my opening remarks about accountability. When the opposition brings in an MPI, as it is its right to do, and opens up a Pandora's box, as it has, I think it is only fair and proper that the opposition be brought to account for deceiving the aid organisations in the community and also for misrepresenting the position of our regional neighbours about the AIDS program. That is why I hope that when they read the contents of this debate and discuss it at ambassadorial and other levels they will be aware that the present opposition is parading around trying to foment problems and trying to undermine the efforts of this government to get financial management back in place in Australia but was prepared to put this nation into further debt by making promises to increase the aid programs if it had been re‐elected.

To our regional neighbours, who are very astute people, that will be something that the Labor opposition will have to live with for a long time. Our neighbours will make a very critical judgment of the former government's performance in driving its own country into debt, spending more than it earned, expecting our kids to pay for recurrent expenditure debts and conning the aid organisations prior to the election in order to buy votes. The former government said it would do better in maintaining all these programs when, in fact, it was not able to fund them without massive further borrowings and increases in taxation.

If the opposition wants the government to be judged, the judgment will be that we will be encouraged by our regional neighbours for our forthrightness in saying before the election what our policies would be, for our initiative in having the review that should lead to very effective aid programs of the future and for being absolutely honest and pragmatic in saying that, in the case of humanitarian programs, when money is short, the Australian taxpayer wants the AIDS victims to be assisted first, before business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AMENDMENT BILL 1996Cognate bill:CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Customs Amendment Bill 1966 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1966. We support the Customs Amendment Bill 1966. In essence, it gives effect to what the Labor government proposed to do in the innovation statement toward the end of last year. We will be opposing the second bill, the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1966. The reason we are opposing it is that it introduces a consumer tax—a GST on imports—and represents a massive breach of promise on the part of the government that is now bringing it forward. Just to remind people of what that promise was, I refer them to what the now Treasurer (Mr Costello) had to say at the Press Club last year:

SPEECH.PARA: But what I am saying here is, we'll not be hiking the income tax rates or company tax rates or sales tax rates or extending the sales tax in any way that the government is proposing. That is not our agenda. It is not our agenda to introduce new taxes. It is not our agenda to bulk up the currently existing taxes. That's not our agenda.

I do not know how much more categoric one can be about what they intend not to do in the course of a parliament, but this is absolutely categoric. I might also say that in the course of the election campaign that oft‐repeated statement was made again by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer, `There will be no new taxes and no increases in taxes under a coalition government.' Yet today in question time we saw many examples of how those taxes are going to be increased under a coalition government. I will refer to those in a minute. I simply make the point that the reason we are opposing the element of this bill is that it extends the tariff concession order effectively to consumers which means an increased tax to consumers and, therefore, is a breach of election commitment to those consumers.

It is not the first time that the government has breached this commitment. There are least two other occasions on which the commitment of `no new taxes' has been breached so far, and we have not even got a budget. Those opposite went to the last election saying that there would be no new taxes, yet there have been breaches now on at least three occasions. What are those three occasions? The one we are dealing with today, which I will come to in more detail in a minute, introduces by the back door a GST of three per cent on all imports—a complete breach of the government's election commitment.

PARA.BREAK: The other breach occurred when they introduced a tax on building workers' travelling allowances. We know this government does not like trade unionists and that during the last election they promised that no‐one would be worse off, but by eliminating that exemption they effectively raised the tax of building workers. Members would be aware of significant demonstrations by building workers around this country because of that decision. But it is not just the building workers who are reacting to this. I understand from a newspaper report late last week that the Leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, Mr Collins, has written to the govern ment expressing concern about this decision and the impact that it will have in New South Wales. The simple fact needs to be underlined that these allowances were not taxed before this government came to power. They now are taxed and, apart from the fact that this breaches the government's promise of no new taxes, it also breaches the commitment that no worker will be worse off.

SPEECH.PARA: The other place where we have seen a massive backdown by the coalition on their election promises was in the farcical Premiers Conference last week. It was referred to by the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, as the greatest shambles of a conference that he had ever participated in. It was referred to by the Premier of Queensland, Mr Borbidge, as representing the duplicity and the deceit of the Treasurer in trying to put something over them that he had not had the decency to come to talk to them about before. All these people are members of coalition governments in other states, I might add. The Treasurer of Victoria said that the decision on wholesale sales tax on cars was a breach of an election promise. It was a breach on at least three fronts according to the Premier of South Australia, and on five fronts according to the Victorian Treasurer.

These people are not friends of Labor. You would have thought that they would have been allies of the current coalition government. Even they could not accept the fact that the government was seeking to introduce new taxes despite their election pledge that there would be no new taxes. I will repeat what they said during the election campaign and obviously well before it, `There will be no new taxes and new increases in taxes under a coalition government.' If one reads the reports in today's newspaper, what are the implications for the states after the fiasco that was the Premiers Conference last week? The coalition government failed to get its proposed tax increase through on motor vehicles because of the disastrous consequence it was going to have on the motor industry, quite apart from what it was going to cost the states.

A compromise was hammered out. Who is going to pay for that compromise? The people who are going to pay for that compromise are the residents in each of the states. In the case of New South Wales, we are looking at $100 per household per year being levied on council rates. Over three years—that is how long they are going to be collecting it—that amounts to $300 per household. This is Pete's poll tax. This is the Treasurer's poll tax.

He has said in this House on numerous occasions that there will be no new taxes. Because of the stupidity with which he approached last week's Premiers Conference and because he was sidelined from the final deliberations that resulted in the conclusion to the Premiers Conference—they had to patch up a solution—the consequence is increased taxes not just in New South Wales but also in Queensland and the other states.

The Premier of Queensland has to find $190 million, which essentially will come from a household poll tax. Queensland will also be levying Pete's poll tax to the tune of $190 million next year. In New South Wales it is $900 million over three years and in Queensland it is $190 million in one year. The government still tries to say that it has not breached any promises. You should go and ask the residents in those states, the people who will have to pay these taxes, who is to blame. The Premiers will have no difficulty telling them who is to blame. They will say that they had to do this because of the mismanagement of the coalition government at the Premiers Conference last week.

Victoria is looking at a $600 million shortfall over three years. We know that Jeff Kennett was the proponent of the household tax. He is going to use the shambles of last week's conference as the justification to keep it going in Victoria. They will keep the levy of $100 per household per year in place. It is a tax on every household. It will be the same in Tasmania. There is the possibility of another tax impacting directly on households.

We have had two examples, prior to this bill coming before the House, where the coalition has breached its election promise relating to no new taxes. We are debating in the House today a bill which will in essence see a new tax imposed on consumers—a GST on imports; a three per cent tax on a range of consumer items that previously did not exist. This is a deliberate policy by the federal government. They cannot claim that this is being foisted on people by the state governments. This is a deliberate policy decision and is in breach of everything they said and hoped people would believe before the last election.

As I said at the outset, the first bill essentially implements the innovation statement that Labor introduced at the end of last year. If you like, it is the innovation statement bill. It involves the removal of the market test as a qualification for receiving a tariff concession order. It involves the tightening of the project status arrangements for policy by-laws where only projects worth over $120 million can qualify for project status. To the extent to which the bill implements that which Labor proposed, of course we support it. I am happy to indicate to the House today that at the appropriate time we will be lending our support to it.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill is a completely different proposition. This bill proposes to increase the tariff concession and some policy by-law rates from zero to three per cent. Unscramble the jargon and essentially what this means is that where people or businesses previously paid nothing in terms of tax they now must pay a minimum of three per cent. It is a direct three per cent lift—three per cent on businesses and three per cent on consumers.

In the discussions we have been having with customs officers it is interesting to note that they refer to this as the tax bill. There is no doubt in their minds that it is about taxing things. The bureaucrats who will have to implement this legislation know it is a tax. It is only the government that comes into this place and tries to pretend it is something other than a tax.

It is not just customs officers who describe it as such, many authorities have been quoted as saying that this in fact is a tax. We have had many representations from industry concerning this being a tax. The National Farmers Federation says that it is a tax. In fact, the High Court of Australia has said that if anything is being done to tariffs it is a tax. Who is the only person who does not say it is a tax? Peter Costello.

The Treasurer will not concede that it is a tax because he knows that to concede that demonstrates absolutely that the promise he made during the election campaign about no new taxes is fractured. We heard him in the House a few weeks ago refuse to concede that it was a tax. He simply said it was a tariff. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) introduced this legislation—he is a minister in the same coalition government as the Treasurer—and he concedes that it is a tax.

On 12 April this year, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism said it was `totally correct' to say that the removal of tariff concession orders was an extra tax on business. No greater authority than the minister himself said that this was a tax. It is only the Treasurer that will not concede this point, but of course we know he is shameless. Because of the shamelessness adding to the shambles of last week, we are dealing with this legislation.

Not content, though, with imposing this tax on business inputs, the coalition has extended the measure to consumers. The bill will impose a three per cent tariff concession rate on a whole range of consumer items and have the effect of yielding $100 million a year from people's pockets.

Remember what they said in the election? `No new taxes.' If they think that $100 million to Australian families is nothing, then they should be prepared to get up and say that. One hundred million dollars is a hell of a lot of money—and that is what this bill will raise from Australian families.

In the course of the difficulty that the minister was going through when introducing this legislation, he had to deal with many disaffected businesses which realised that this measure would increase their costs. He actually went so far as describing the decision to eliminate the tariff concession order on business as `dreadful policy'. According to the Courier‐Mail on 9 May, the scrapping of the tariff concession scheme was `dreadful policy'. But the point is, what he thought was dreadful policy when it came to businesses became good policy when extended to consumers.

What sort of view is it when you have the government in here prepared to try to do something for businesses, recognising the dreadful nature of the policy and conceding that openly but, as part of the solution, shifting the burden to consumers, to families, to the battlers, to the people who cannot pass it on?

The reality is that businesses, one way or the other, will find ways of accommodating this. I see the minister coming into the House now, so I will be interested to hear, when he eventually sums up, how something that he described as `dreadful policy' for businesses now becomes good policy for consumers. Apart from the broken promises of the Treasurer and the whole of the government on `No new taxes', go and tell them why this is good policy for them. You will have to do a lot of explaining.

You have had the opportunity in this House, minister, to do some of that explaining but you have baulked at it every time. You have walked away from the dispatch box every time we have had you up there asking questions about this. You have walked away without giving any answer at all.

This is not just a consumer tax of three per cent. The most shameless act being perpetrated today in this legislation is the government's refusal to produce any list of consumer items which will be hit by the import tax. One figure puts it as high as 17,000 different items.

In this House we have asked the minister to produce a list. He has not. While waiting for the legislation, we have said that there could have been something in the explanatory memorandum indicating which items or lists would appear. That has not materialised.

We have put a question on notice in both houses. They have had plenty of time—almost a month—to come back with this answer. They pride themselves on lifting the standards in this parliament by saying that they will ensure that answers to questions on notice will come back much more expeditiously. Not only can we not get an answer in the House; we cannot get it outside the House—and all the minister does is laugh. It is not just a broken promise, it is a mystery tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mystery tax?

—People do not know what it will apply to because you will not produce the list, despite the fact that we have given you the opportunity at every stage to outline it. It is not just a GST on imports. By being a mystery tax it becomes, in essence, a lucky dip—or, rather, an unlucky dip. They are asking the parliament to now pass this legislation and find out what it applies to later. What sort of policy is that by a coalition government that holds itself out as raising the standards, as being more open with the people of Australia and having the parliament much more accountable? The executive of the government will not give the details.

SPEECH.PARA: I see government members in the House that will speak in this debate. Do they know what this list includes? I would be interested to know whether they had any greater satisfaction than us when it came to asking the minister. Of course, he comes in here and laughs at the suggestion that it is clever not to produce the list.But what will government members be like when they are confronted in their constituencies by people asking, `To what does this tax apply?' Three per cent on 17,000 different items, but at this stage people will not be told what it applies to.

For example, the sorts of things that will be picked up are: aerobic exercise equipment, baby walkers, basketballs, battery operated dolls, children's playground equipment, food processors, scooters, spotlights, squeaky toys, vacuum cleaners and, that last one, Christmas stockings unfilled.

I can tell you this: with this new tax on consumers, with this GST by the back door, there will be a lot of unfilled Christmas stockings at the end of this year, because this is a shameless slug on the battlers, on the families, on the households of this country which you did not have the honesty before the last election to tell them about.

As I said, this is in essence the reason we are opposing this part of the cognate bills—in so far as it imposes this secret tax, this hidden tax, this mystery tax on consumers. But the bill also sets some policy by-law rates at three per cent and others at zero. I do not know whether members of the House are aware of the policy by-law system, but essentially it was a fall‐back position for those who had failed to get the tariff concession order; they could effectively get an exemption under a policy by-law.

Under Labor, people were able to have that policy by-law set at zero. The government's approach is to raise that as well to three per cent in a number of cases. Let me give an example of this. Goods designed for the mining sector can be imported without a duty payment, provided they are part of a project worth more than $10 million. They can come in free. But machine tools for working advanced metals can get only the three per cent concessional rate. In other words, they have to pay something; they have to pay the three per cent.

So businesses that have $10 million‐plus can still get the zero rate. But with small businesses—the other clarion call of the coalition government during the election; how they are going to support small business—the impact of the policy by-law is to slug them. It is to put them at a disadvantage to the larger companies. This results in some very strange anomalies.

All this does is demonstrate the haste with which the bill was subsequently put together, given the huge difficulty that the minister got into not only with businesses but also with the private little clash he was having with the Treasurer. That was the clash in which he rolled the Treasurer; the one in which he has been given a tick in terms of performance along with some other ministers. I notice that the minister sitting at the table, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), did not get a tick, but neither did he get into the cabinet. I think we all understand why.

But at least the minister for industry got a tick. Why? Because he was seen to have rolled Peter Costello. He rolled him because he was able to take the pressure off business and shift it to consumers. Great achievement! That was a fantastic achievement! That was a circumstance in which you rolled the Treasurer but you made the consumers pay, you made families pay and you are making small businesses pay what they could have otherwise had an exemption from.

It is also very interesting, when we look at this issue of the small business sector, to see whether the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) explained the impact of this legislation when he called that small business summit together. I am sure there are a lot of questions raised about it. But, again, given that the small business minister will not come in here and answer questions either, it seems to me that small business would not have had much satisfaction.

By a very strange quirk, this bill seems to put a premium on failure. Firms that want duty-free entry under a policy by-law first have to fail in their application for the three per cent concession. So the silly position is that those who cannot make the case for the three per cent—in other words, the thing that they have to pay on—can then be capable of being rewarded with a free rate. You are rewarding failure. We hear all the government's arguments about efficiency, rewarding efficiency and rewarding success. This is a piece of legislation that rewards failure.

Our approach is to remove that red tape and to make the position much clearer and much more open in terms of what businesses can get. We propose that the tariff concession no longer apply to the business inputs, that importers of business inputs could seek a zero per cent tariff through the policy by-law system, provided that it involved those projects of $10 million or more. That is what the coalition supported. So what we are really doing with the amendment we are foreshadowing is to restore that component.

The effect of our amendment is to do two things. It is to say that this new tax should not apply to consumers. It is contrary to what the coalition opposition said they would do in government. They therefore have no mandate to do it in government. The other thing we want to do through the amendment is to ensure that businesses, having failed through the tariff concession, still get the opportunity for support through the by-law.

In relation to the proposal that we talked about during the election campaign, which was to eliminate the tariff concession order on business inputs, we said that we would consult with industry on the implementation of the measure and that we would effectively consider any hardship that came about. We would allow for additional revenue raised through our approach to feed back into help for industry through the policy by-law system.

The government should seriously reflect on the amendments that we will put. We are not saying that we want to hold up the revenue raising capacity of the government through measures associated with addressing the tariff concession orders. But we are implacably opposed to shifting the burden to consumers and making it harder for businesses that can present a real case to get a concession through the alternative route of the policy by-law.

If the minister is prepared to redraft the bill to take into account those two aspects, then we can still see this legislation passed in the course of this sitting fortnight. We are not here to obstruct the government's ability to raise revenue which they said they had a mandate to raise. They did go to the last election and seek a mandate to do what we were proposing to do—that is, to abolish the tariff concession order and to essentially raise some revenue from the business community. In essence that seemed fair because, with the massive loss of revenue to government through the reduction in tariffs over the years, this was a means by which some of that revenue could at least be restored.

We strongly oppose the move in the bill to impose the three per cent import tax on a wider range of consumer items—the government have no mandate to do that—but we will give them the chance to pass the bill in this session if they agree to certain conditions. They are set out in our second reading amendment, which proposes that the bill be withdrawn and revised so that consumer goods receiving tariff concessions continue to enter Australia free of duty and that no change be made to the duty rate which currently applies to policy by‐laws.

BREAK.PARA: If the government does not take up that option and if they continue to proceed with this bad bill as it stands, then we as an opposition will continue to oppose it. This bill involves a fundamental breach of the government's core election commitment. We said when we became an opposition that we were going to hold them accountable to the promises they made, and this is one example where we are doing just that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace, Elizabeth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 states an evaluation was conducted in 1995 into changes to the tariff concession system. The evaluation found that, while the system made concessions available for importers, Australian manufacturers were being adversely affected by its operation. The evaluation concluded that tariff concessions should be made only where there is no Australian manufacturer of goods substitutable for those imported. The aim of this bill is to align the operation of the system and make concessional entry readily available without adversely affecting the tariff assistance given to Australian manufacturers.

SPEECH.PARA: The policy by‐law system will be revamped to contain costs. The decision overcomes the unfair and unworkable proposal—put forward by the former government—to totally abolish tariff concessions on business inputs. Labor's proposal would have created an administrative nightmare. It would also have unfairly penalised Australian manufacturers by imposing higher costs on business inputs while at the same time competing inputs were to benefit from a reduction in the general tariff.

The coalition solution is a pragmatic response to the concerns of industry. It spreads the cost more widely and provides relief to key industries that would have suffered under Labor's proposal. For example, under Labor's proposal the car industry and the textile, clothing and footwear industry would have had to contend with an increase in tariff paid on imported components and materials from zero up to 15 per cent, even 25 per cent and in some cases 37 per cent.

The coalition solution ensures that these producers will pay no more than three per cent duty. In making our decision, we have carefully weighed the employment, investment and revenue implications of the change. While we have limited the impact of any additional cost to industry, we have been firm. Industry will still shoulder its share of the burden needed to meet our commitments and improve the budget situation.

The proposed revocation of the five policy by‐law items and the introduction of the revised criteria against which requests for concessions under these items will be considered will result in considerable revenue savings. It is expected that, in the 1996-97 budget year, these will be $29 million; in 1997-98, $32 million; in 1998-99, $34 million; and in 1999‐2000, $37 million. As from 1 July 1996 the trade concession system will operate at a concessional rate of duty of three per cent. The trade concessional system will still apply to both consumer goods and business inputs.

The changes in the tariff concession system arise from the government's election commitments and acceptance of tariff concession system reforms recommended in 1995 by the Department of Industry, Science and Technology. The most important change is the removal of the so‐called market test clause from the core criteria. The existence of the market test has meant that tariff concession orders have been granted to the detriment of Australian manufacturers, because it is very difficult for an Australian manufacturer to prove prospectively that the market for its goods will be adversely affected by the duty‐free importation of substitutable goods.

Once the market test has been removed, the substitutability test will be the remaining core criterion. Therefore, the Australian Customs Service will not grant a tariff concession order where it is satisfied that substitutable goods are produced in Australia. Concessions will be made only where there is no Australian manufacturer of goods substitutable for those which are subject to the tariff concession application.

In future the onus for demonstrating that there are no substitutable goods produced in Australia will rest with the applicant for tariff concession orders. Tariff concession order applicants will be responsible for researching the existence of Australian manufacturers of substitutable goods prior to their lodgment for application with Customs. Furthermore, the application will have to provide the name of the importer seeking the concession. These details will be gazetted to notify applicants of Australian manufacturers claiming they produce substitutable goods.

The present legislation allows the commencement date of a tariff concession to be backdated to 28 days before the lodgment of application. There is now no rationale for backdating tariff concession orders. Making orders operative from the date of lodgment of application should encourage importers to lodge their applications earlier. The bill will also enable Customs to commence revocation action for tariff concession orders where there are Australian manufacturers of substitutable goods and where the orders have not been used for two years.

The definition of `made to order capital equipment' will be amended to allow concessions for equipment made on only a one-off basis to meet a specific order, rather than being the subject of regular or intermittent production, and to exclude goods made as a result of production runs.

The amendments proposed in this bill, such as the removal of the market test from the core criteria and the new revocation facility for existing tariff concession orders and commercial tariff concession orders, will result in huge savings over the next five years. I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment to be moved by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1). The amendment asks the government effectively to take the bill away and redraft it in such a way that it honestly presents to the House legislation in relation to tariffs rather than an attempt to introduce a consumption tax—that is to say, a small form of a GST—into the taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: It really can be summed up as a rather dishonest attempt to introduce the tip of the iceberg of a GST into our taxation system. We would then end up with a situation where the Australian public would be faced with a consumption tax. Then, no doubt, given the rate at which promises are being broken by this government, more and more discussion would be initiated on bringing back the idea of a GST.

We are not prepared to allow, in any way, this dishonest exercise of trying to misuse this bill by bringing in a certain kind of consumption tax that would cover a significant number of goods which the Australian people certainly made clear in the 1993 election that they rejected. What we have here is a backdoor attempt to introduce it.

It is interesting that a quiet debate is going on within the government on this issue. This government consists—in philosophical terms—of people who are pragmatic and relatively moderate and then those who have absorbed the Fightback New Right agenda put down by the former leader and who are really trying to bring that agenda to pass. Even though John Howard, the Prime Minister, when he went to the Australian people, said, `We are not introducing a GST and we have rejected the key elements of Fightback,' what we are increasingly getting is policy after policy with elements of Fightback ideas coming in—and in this case a GST.

The leader of this dramatic movement is the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who has always had that New Right agenda. What has he tried to do? He has tried to bring it in in a number of ways: by creating this mythology of the $8 billion hole and using this mythology as an excuse to break all the promises which Mr Howard, as Prime Minister, made in relation to services.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!

—The minister has already started the process in his own portfolio by cutting the skillshare programs and other programs of Working Nation. Don't you talk about it being rubbish! You denied in this House that you were cutting skillshare. Within one week, you sent a letter out telling the organisers of skillshare throughout this country, especially in Victoria, that they were going to suffer a 30 per cent cut. Don't you talk about this being rubbish. We will see this horror budget that you are going to bring down on 20 August. That horror budget will be nothing more than an attempt by you to bring back this New Right agenda, which you have always believed in—especially the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp), who is sitting at the table, who used to write academic books about how good a GST is, even though it has totally failed in Britain and the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: We have the misfortune in this country of having key members of the Howard cabinet still believing in that New Right extremist agenda. They are now trying to bring in excuses to bring in that agenda. Here is another example. In this bill we effectively have the introduction of a consumption tax. It is totally unnecessary. We suggested the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) as a way of gaining some revenue in a responsible way. Instead of proceeding along the path suggested by the Labor Party, the government accepted part of the Labor Party's approach but then added on this other stuff—the consumption tax. Instead of agreeing to the original proposal, which even the honourable member who spoke on their behalf a little while ago said had reasonable elements to it in that business was required to give something back because they had received so much in tariff concessions—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a grab for money.

—You will get your chance to speak. That proposal, which had been put forward by the Labor Party, was sensible and targeted and clearly directed to business inputs. The government has taken it and expanded it so that consumers suffer. The old consumer is going to suffer once again from these proposals. If it had adopted the proposals we put forward, we would have had none of these problems. We would have had a very similar amount of money.

SPEECH.PARA: We have made it perfectly clear in our second reading amendment that we will not accept a backdoor consumption tax being brought in by this process.
