If this government wants to introduce a consumption tax, let it be honest about it. Let it bring a consumption tax package before the parliament. Let it break its commitment openly instead of by this dishonest backdoor method which it is proposing.

BREAK.PARA: This is typical of the approach that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, has taken since he took on his position. Look what happened last week in relation to his administration of the Premiers Conference. Why did we get into all those difficulties? Why was he forced to back off on his proposal regarding the imposition of new taxes? Leaving aside the fact that it was clearly a breach of a promise by the government that it would not impose new taxes, he failed in the most fundamental rule of administration. Even a junior minister would know that, if you are going to bring in something like that, there is a such a thing as consultation with people to see what the situation is. The Treasurer did not bother to consult in that process. There has also been insufficient consultation in this process, which was just dropped on the people when it was announced a little while ago. We are now getting government without consultation.
The extraordinary thing about last week's events was that there was a failure to consult even their Liberal Party colleagues. Five of the Premiers—

TALK.START.PARA: —What's this got to do with the bill? Come on! What's this got to do with the bill?
—I will tell you what it has got to do with the bill. This reveals the same arrogance and direction which was shown in last week's Premiers Conference. There are problems with this bill.
—You haven't read the bill.

—The bill has been through the shadow ministry and caucus. We know all about the key aspects of the bill. Our five per cent proposal was very clear and would have raised the money in an appropriate way. In an attempt to tell some sections of business that you will not actually impose this taxation burden on them, you have decided to impose it across a large range of consumption goods. Therefore, you are introducing, as I said, a consumption tax. We have clearly said in our second reading amendment that if you take that aspect of it out we will pass the legislation.

BREAK.PARA: This is a very serious proposal. It was discussed at length in the shadow ministry. We want your Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), who is a pragmatic person and knows about these things, unlike the Treasurer, to take our proposal seriously. When this proposal goes to the other place, we will be moving an amendment to it. We will move it not only here but in the other place. In the Senate, it will be made perfectly clear that we will not pass the legislation unless the consumption tax aspect of the bill is taken out.

This is no idle threat. We are saying to you that, if you want to gain that amount of money as defined by the original intention of this proposal, you will have to abide by the will of the Senate on this matter. It will depend on the views of the minor parties, but it is most likely that the section on the consumption tax will be excised from the legislation. Unless you are prepared to do that and to support another of our amendments, we will oppose your position.

I want to say something about the second part of the amendment, which deals with the policy by‐law arrangement. When we said that we would legislate, we talked about how certain exemptions would be made through the policy by‐law process. When you brought in your legislation, you dropped most of that consideration. Companies that had a case to put will not be in a position to do so as a result of you dropping that aspect of our original proposal. We have not been able to determine from all the material you have given us why you have done that. Why have you not kept that aspect of the proposal concerning the policy by‐law process?

We are putting a very reasonable amendment to you. The first part of the amendment relates to a consumption tax and the second relates to the policy by-laws. If you put both of them together, we will support the legislation and you will gain that section of revenue. We are not interested in taking gross revenue away from you. We are not interested in being obstructionist in relation to raising revenue. We are not going to allow a false approach, where you misuse this legislation to bring in, as I said, a backdoor consumption tax.

Both sides of this House are agreed on the general thrust of the legislation, which relates to business inputs. We have clearly explained that this sudden, unexplained broadening of the legislation is an attempt to impose a consumption tax. It is the wrong way to do it. If the minister were really interested in bringing in a consumption tax, he would surely put it up‐front, discuss it and debate it instead of bringing it in by this backdoor fashion, which is what is happening here.

It has been said that at some time in the past people from both sides of this House have talked about a consumption tax. However, they have talked about it very generally, in that people would be protected if such a tax were brought in. In this instance, there is no protection for people. It would just be dropped on people. There would be a three per cent increase on all these goods consumed by Australians with no explanation. The government will not say, `Let's look at the whole taxation system,' and own up to the fact that this is a breach of its promise not to introduce a consumption tax.

While the Australian Labor Party is in opposition, it will help the government as far as possible in its revenue raising. We are committed to that general proposition. Where the government is clearly breaching its promises or where it is clearly extending beyond its mandate in these areas or where it is attempting to introduce new forms of taxes when it clearly said in the election that it would not, we have an obligation to hold the government to its promises and its commitments. We will do that. Not only will we try to do what we can in the House of Representatives but we will use all of our forces in the Senate to ensure that outcome.

I know that the leaders of the government in the Senate have carried on about how obstructionist the Senate is supposed to have been on these sorts of issues. The reality is that the Senate has passed quite a large number of bills. We are trying to cooperate with the government in so far as it is trying to meet its mandate, but this is not the case with this legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Telstra? Like IR? Are you supporting the mandate?
—You have a look at our amendments to the IR legislation before you make any further comments. We are going to help the government ensure its basic financial base.
—You are saying on the one hand and then the other hand.
—We are not going to do it on the basis of broken promises and the implementation of new taxes—in particular, a consumption tax, which constitutes a backdoor way of introducing a GST.
—What rubbish! What rubbish!

—This is a central issue of division, as the shadow minister, the member for Hotham, has explained, between us and them. The honourable member for Mitchell has been interrupting the whole time. How does he justify the introduction of a consumption tax?
—This is absolute rubbish. I thought you understood these things.
—Order! The member for Calwell has the call. I ask the member for Calwell to direct his remarks through the chair.
—Obviously, for the benefit of the honourable member for Mitchell, I had better read the amendment. It reads:

BREAK.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"the Bill breaches the government's election commitment that it would not increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes and should therefore be withdrawn, redrafted and re‐presented in a form in which:
(1) goods for personal consumption to which Tariff Concession Orders apply continue to enter Australia free of duty; and
(2) no change be made to the duty rate which currently applies to Policy By‐Laws".

That is a very sensible amendment. This is the gist of our opposition. As I said to the honourable member for Mitchell, we are not opposing the general thrust of the bill towards business. We are saying that this bill, which deals with customs tariffs and is directed essentially at the business issue, should not be used to impose all of these taxes on consumption goods.

It may be said—and I am sure it will be said by one of the spokespersons for the government—that it is going to be too hard to differentiate between consumption goods and the other goods. Let us say in advance of that argument being put that we do not accept that. That is a nonsense argument. It is a technical argument that some bureaucrats are going to put to get out of this. It is wrong. We consider the onus to be on the government to produce the bill in a proper state. In fact, the government could even produce the whole schedule and differentiate the goods if that is what they wanted to do. There is time before this bill goes to the Senate to do that.

I will conclude with this very serious warning. If we can get the support of the minor parties in the Senate, there will be an amendment to this legislation along the lines that we have suggested. We give the government due warning that we expect it to do some work on this proposal and to re-present the bill in a proper state so that it can go through both houses and provide basic revenue—not revenue raised by a consumption tax. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite saddened by the approach of the member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) to this whole process because it is obvious that he is prepared to let all political stupidity override any commonsense or rationale that I thought he possessed. Let me go through a number of points with the honourable member, because I am sure that he has failed to understand precisely what the previous government did in regard to the five per cent impost compared with what the coalition government is now doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor government, in order to raise revenue—it was not a new tax in the eyes of the previous government—decided in 1995 to impose a tariff on goods and business charges which would have raised five per cent additional funds. The honourable member says that that is not a tax or a new charge because it was the Labor Party that thought of it but that if the coalition imposes the same sort of tariff that is something new, even though before and during the election campaign we said that we would do the same thing.

BREAK.PARA: Let me just remind the member: you were prepared to put a five per cent impost onto the business community, and a lot of those goods that would carry the five per cent surcharge are business inputs. They are used for making things. It does not appear to come to your mind that, if you increase the cost of making things, the ultimate selling price is going to increase proportionately. Therefore, if the opposition are going to argue an increased tax, their proposal was also an increased tax. But they are not prepared to see it in that light.

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept that side of it; it's the consumption side.

—Okay, I will come to the consumption side. What you were prepared to do was increase the cost by five per cent for all inputs imported into Australia for Australian businesses. That measure would disadvantage Australian manufacturers as compared with imported goods. You were not going to put anything on an equivalent good made outside the country and directly imported to the consumer. Therefore, you were prepared to tolerate a price differential of at least five per cent to the disadvantage of Australian manufacturers, Australian workers and Australian industries. You were prepared to promote that as a good decision and as a responsible decision. You were prepared to accept an additional five per cent input cost for Australian manufacturers and put them at a severe disadvantage against imports.

BREAK.PARA: That has been the life story of 13 years of Australian Labor Party government. Slowly but surely, as they proclaim the increase and betterment of Australian industries and Australian manufacturing industries, they ground them into the dust. For every year that the Labor Party proclaimed themselves to be the supporters of Australian manufacturing industries and Australian workers, more and more went bankrupt. Here was another decision in line with previous decisions of the Australian Labor Party where they were prepared to increase the costs for Australian businesses and disadvantage them as compared with imported goods.

I think it shameful of the Australian Labor Party that they would even contemplate disadvantaging Australian workers as compared with workers in Asia, in Europe or in South America. Their proposal in 1995 regarding tariff concessions was that inputs into the plastics industries, the auto industries, tool making and most Australian manufacturing industries were to be increased by five per cent. A five per cent increase along the line of a charge is then multiplied as that item, that good or that equipment and machinery is added into production costs. So a five per cent downstream input charge can finish up as a substantial increase in the finished price of the goods.

The Australian Labor Party were prepared to accept that. They were prepared to say that Australian manufacturing industries and the workers employed in those manufacturing industries were to have more lead put into their saddlebags and be disadvantaged further by this proposal. But they did not contemplate any process to rectify the increased price differentiation between imported and locally manufactured goods. So, on coming to office, we sought to introduce in an equitable way the tariff concession process that we were committed to during the election campaign.

If the Australian Labor Party had consulted or listened to Australian manufacturers, if they had really represented Australian workers, they would have known that there would be a roar of complaint from them. They saw very clearly what this tariff increase would have done to their industries. They knew that the input costs were going to rise for their industry. They knew that, if the Australian Labor Party's proposal had been successful, there would have been a serious price disadvantage for locally manufactured goods. That is the complaint of the whole of Australia. It is a complaint that people like Harry Wallace of the Australian Owned Companies Association and others from organisation after organisation bring to this place but which falls on deaf ears as far as the Australian Labor Party are concerned.

PARA.BREAK: It has been only the coalition that has been prepared to ask about the core of the problem. The core of the problem has been that time and again the Labor Party has been prepared to load the lead into the saddlebags of Aus tralian manufacturers either by taxes or by additional charges so that they become less and less competitive. They are not prepared to remove the barriers to competitiveness and prepare them for getting out and having a go and providing additional employment. The Labor Party has not been prepared to do that. The coalition has listened and is prepared to do that.

BREAK.PARA: There is a difference between the way in which the two main parties operate. There was no willingness on the part of the Australian Labor Party to look at the penalties and disadvantages in the industrial relation system. The proposals of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Brereton), on unfair dismissal wrecked business after business. The complaint right through the community was that business was disadvantaged in comparison with its neighbours. Labor's tariff concession proposals did exactly the same thing. They were prepared to penalise Australian manufacturers with an extra charge but they would not put a compensatory charge on all imports. They disadvantaged the price of goods that were manufactured locally and advantaged the price of goods that were manufactured overseas.

The tack taken by the Australian Labor Party that this is a new tax is very strange. This legislation is not a new tax. In 1978 the Fraser government put a two per cent tariff across everything with a few exceptions. Just about all imports to Australia faced a two per cent tariff increase.

That process remained in place for nine or 10 years. It was in about 1987 that the Labor government removed the two per cent tariff barrier, only to reimpose one a few years later, but with the sophistry and the manipulative process of mind to say, `This is not revenue raising, this has nothing to do with anything but the management of government, and this does not impose a tax or a charge on Australian businesses. We're quite entitled to put five per cent on Australian manufacturers. We took off the two per cent of the Fraser government.' At that time the Labor government had proclaimed the Fraser government's two per cent as an unnecessary burden on Australian manufacturers and Australian industry. It talked at that time about a level playing field. But it was only seven or eight years later that it reimposed a tariff at a higher rate and was unprepared at that point to call it for what it was.

But those opposite—having been aware throughout the totality of the election campaign that it was the coalition's commitment, its policy, to introduce the same tax—walk into the parliament today and say, `Well, we're not going to really block this measure in the Senate, but we're going to amend it in such a way that, unless it is what we agree to, it will be blocked anyway.' They claim that that is not blocking a process. They claim it is assisting the government.

The government denies that it is a matter of assistance. We would say that what the Australian Labor Party proposes is completely unacceptable. The coalition is proposing, firstly, an actual reduction in input costs for Australian manufacturing industries—Labor's proposal—and, secondly, a proper levelling of the playing field for locally manufactured goods compared with imports. It is a fair proposal. It is a proper proposal. It is not a tax increase.

This is a process that the Labor Party itself was prepared to introduce. However, because those opposite were not prepared to think through the disadvantages they were going to impose on Australian manufacturers, they are now saying to the government, `Unless you agree with this proposal then we are going to change what you are trying to bring in.' In trying to bring this legislation in, we are trying to rectify the stupidity, the short-sightedness and the crazy ideas that brought the previous government down.

This is pragmatic commonsense. It will work. It will not disadvantage Australian workers or employees. It will not disadvantage Australian businesses. It will not result in additional unfair charges on locally manufactured goods when compared with imported goods. I cannot see how the Australian Labor Party can even contemplate presenting the sophistry of, `This is a new tax, and because it is a new tax we are going to disagree with it.'

It is foolish to think that this sort of argument will gather any mileage anywhere in Australia. The entire Australian work force in the manufacturing industry knows that it was a stupid, futile and loaded proposition with which you came to the Australian people in 1995. The work force as well as employers know that this proposal from the coalition rectifies the problems created by the Australian Labor Party proposal. They know that it is not a tax. They have seen proposals like this come and go over the last 10 or 15 years. They accept that it is part of the process of government to either put on tariffs or take off tariffs.

Suddenly, the Australian Labor Party wants to call it a new tax. That will not wash either because tariffs, in the way they have been applied both by your government and the Fraser government and as they are now being applied by this government, are not being used as a taxation process. They are being used to establish a process which you instigated and which we have corrected and turned into a much fairer proposition. That is what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has done, that is what the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) has supported and that is what the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) has promoted.

You cannot come into the House now with some sort of speaker's list of experts in economic and political theory such as the member for Calwell and think you are going to gain mileage out there in the electorate. The electorate thinks that this is just more of the same old Labor Party stuff: punishing business and employees and turning it into a virtue while encouraging foreign manufacturers to take over Australian retail and Australian business and putting Australian workers out of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you're in government now, Alan.

—And we have changed it to make it fair. That is what you fail to understand. That is why you should never support this amendment. If you were to restore your previous proposals, you would be working against Australian manufacturers and workers.

BREAK.PARA: We have restored a balance between imports and locally manufactured goods. That is the theme of the government's legislation. That is what you fail to understand. That is why your arguments will not wash with people out there around western Sydney, western Melbourne or anywhere else there is manufacturing industry. They know the truth. They know that this proposal which originated in the Labor Party was bad for them. They know that the proposals here in the legislation, the changes that have been made by the new government, are changes which are worthy and fair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very much indebted to the Chief Government Whip, the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), for his contribution on the customs bills. In particular, I admired his sophistry in suggesting that to apply a three per cent tariff across the board is not a new tax.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not really had an opportunity to comment on the last election. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had a very handsome victory. I think it is fair to say that, notwithstanding his many years in politics, the people of Australia felt that over time he had perhaps changed and that this was a different John Howard to the one we had seen previously. Indeed, perhaps the people of Australia felt that this was very much a different coalition to the one which had presented in 1993.

I think it is true to say that the people of Australia accepted that they would not introduce a GST, that they would not hack public spending by $10 billion, that they would not introduce a youth wage of $3 per hour. When they said they would not introduce any new taxes and charges, it is fair to say the people of Australia truly believed them. How disappointed they must be for having extended an opportunity to the coalition to form the government of Australia.

In the debate on this legislation today, government members are saying that a tax is a tax; it is not a tariff increase. When I go back to my electorate and ask people, `What do you think is a tax increase? For example, if there were a measure to increase the excise on cigarettes or alcohol, would you see that as an increase?' they answer yes. Petrol—yes. Imports of consumer goods—yes, they do see it as a tax.

It is pointless for government members to suggest that this proposal, which will rake in $338 million in the first year, $358 million in the second year, $393 million in the third year and $413 million in the fourth year, is not a tax but somehow a painless extraction of money from the people of Australia when they purchase imported goods. I think those comments will be falling on deaf ears.

With regard to the suggestion we have heard from the Premiers Conference that the proposal to do away with duty-free purchases by state governments and local governments was not the imposition of a tax, again I do not think the people of Australia will have any sympathy for that point of view. With regard to the fact that the states have stared down the barrel of a $1,200 million tax grab by the Commonwealth from them each year every year, that is not consistent with the policies which the people of Australia thought they were voting for when they voted for the Liberal and National parties. I think the government will be very sadly mistaken.

It is entirely consistent for the opposition to acknowledge the mandate that the government has achieved. It is a very handsome and a very generous mandate. I might even say that to those on this side of the House it is very hurtful to see so many of our colleagues lose their seats and so many enthusiastic new government members take over those seats. But Mr Howard and the government went to the people of Australia in March this year promising no new taxes. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) referred during the election to the famous American presidential comment `Read my lips'. Indeed, the people of Australia did read the lips. They read the lips of the Prime Minister; they read the lips of the Treasurer (Mr Costello); in fact, they read the lips of all members of the Liberal and National parties who were successful at the last election.

I think they sincerely believed that this government would be responsible and that having said they would not introduce any new taxes they would not. How can we say that extracting $338 million in one year, $358 million in the second year, $393 million in the third year and $413 million in the fourth year is not a tax grab? That is what government members would have you believe. But I have absolute confidence in the people of Australia. I think they were right in 1996, but I warn you that you cannot take them for granted. A government will not survive by sleight of hand.

These tariff concession system changes impose a three per cent tariff on a range of imported goods. I am happy to read out the list of goods if any member is in any difficulty as to exactly what they are. In fact, I have told all the families in my electorate exactly what sorts of goods will be affected. For example, they will pay this three per cent tariff on basketballs, bicycles, bicycle speedometers, dice, cymbals, cots or pram rockers, cot lights, voice operated coin operated pinball machines, electric hair clippers, electric power drills—the range of goods is endless. It is an extra tax—in a sense, a GST on imported consumer goods—which this new government has levied on the people of Australia, yet in doing so they have said they are not increasing taxes.

There has been a very adverse reaction to this in my electorate. I was making the point that the government had promised there would be no new taxes. I noticed that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) suggested increasing the HECS charge. Students, upon graduation, become liable for payment of part of their fees, about 20 per cent, when they hit certain income levels. Senator Vanstone is contemplating increasing that HECS charge. I think it is quite devious of the government to suggest, `We can increase the HECS charge on students but this is not increasing a tax.' HECS was imposed as a specific, highly targeted tax on students. I have to say it caused a lot of difficulty within the government at the time, but we did it for the sole purpose of increasing student places.

The then opposition came out during the election and said, `No new taxes,' being very critical of Ralph Willis, the then Treasurer, when he would not give an undertaking on the tax fear but said that what the Labor government promised to do was to maintain the same level of taxation—not to increase the level of taxation. But the then opposition did not say that. They said, `No new taxes.' Yet they are suggesting that they can get away with, for example, increasing the HECS charges or, alternatively—as in this bill—moving to put a three per cent tariff on a whole range of domestic goods.

It is no wonder that, when the people of Australia are asked to rate certain professions, politicians are, I regret, sinking lower and lower over time. Mr Deputy Speaker, you might feel that there is a degree of glee on this side of the House that the government are so clearly breaking an election promise. But their lack of probity in this matter, their lack of honesty, is harming us all as members of this House. I think we all have an obligation—as, indeed, the new Speaker has suggested; as the Prime Minister has evinced that he would like to see in this House—to lift the standards. When you get a mandate like yours, if you want to lift the standards, be consistent with what you told the people of Australia.

You told the people of Australia back in March that there would be no new taxes. Here we are today debating a new tax, a new three per cent tariff. The suggestion from the Chief Opposition Whip was that a tariff is not a tax. As I have said before, you are raising so many hundreds of millions and, if you go to my electorate of Chifley and to the electorate of the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), the shadow minister for health, and ask the people in those electorates, `When you pay more for a whole range of consumer goods when the government is collecting over $300 million extra, is that a tax or isn't it a tax?' overwhelmingly they are going to say that it is a tax.

Increasing the government take from the hip pocket nerve is a tax. It does not matter whether it is a wholesale sales tax, whether it is income tax, whether it is company tax, whether it is tariffs or whether it is an excise: when people are paying more out of their hip pocket, they see that as a government tax. When you get the budget revenue committee sitting down, as doubtlessly they are doing right now, what do they look at? They look at income tax, they look at company tax, they look at excises and they look at tariffs. That is what makes up the government revenue. That is what ordinary people consider to be taxes.

It is absolute humbug, absolute tripe, to come into this House and suggest that when you impose a three per cent tariff—when there was no tax, no excise, no tariff there before—it is not a tax. It is a tax. The people of Australia, I am afraid to say, will see it that way. They will see any denials by government members as so much sophistry, as so much obfuscation and, in a sense, as so much political dishonesty; and they will punish you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lindsay first.

—As my friend the honourable member for Dobell said, it could be Lindsay; it could be tomorrow in Lindsay. I ask government members: do you want to go into a by‐election in Lindsay and suggest that, when you collect $338 million in year one, $358 million in year two, $393 million in year three and $413 million in year four, that is not a tax? Do you really expect to win in the electorate of Lindsay by running on that platform? Do you think the voters in a by-election in Lindsay are going to accept it if you say, `We promised we were not going to introduce new taxes but we are going to increase HECS?' Do you think they are going to accept that government grab that will punish students—not to provide extra places, mind you, because you proposed to contract the number of places, not to increase them? Do you think that when you go into Lindsay and say, `We are going to increase HECS,' people will not see this as a tax grab and that they will not punish you? Of course they will. You went into the election and you won it handsomely, as I have acknowledged, but you said, `No new taxes,' and the people of Australia believed you.

SPEECH.PARA: It is little wonder that the opposition has moved an amendment—I think a very good amendment—which seeks to draw you back to your election commitments. I can say with absolute confidence that every member on this side of the House will be voting for that, notwithstanding the fact that it was a very handsome win. We will be voting for it because we believe that if you make statements, whether it is the opposition or whether it is the government, to the people of Australia, you are duty and honour bound to fulfil them. In putting this bill up, you are breaking it. You are breaking it in the first year of government. I think that members of the coalition just have no understanding of what a calamitous path this is to be breaking election promises on taxes so early in their government.

I know that speakers have talked about the $8 billion black hole. The truth of the matter is that the Prime Minister—and I regret this—has never tabled in this House a costing by Treasury or Finance of his election promises. I think it is fair enough to suggest that we did not leave a balanced book—I do not think anyone argues that on this side—but the truth is that it is nothing like $8 billion. But in trying to assume the moral high ground, the government of the day has never had the decency to live up to its suggestion implicit in its charter of budget honesty that it would table the costings of its election promises. Mr Deputy Speaker, you know, and I know, and most members of this House know, that that approximates $4 billion.

I do not think it is good enough for members of the government to be running around saying, `We're forced to break our election promises of no new taxes. We're forced to introduce this bill that breaks our election commitment of no new taxes,' because it will not wash with the people. There is an old saying that you can fool some of the people some of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all of the time. It is true that the people have given the government and the incoming Prime Minister a very generous honeymoon period, but just as they have been generous in their mandate and generous in the extent of the honeymoon period, deceiving the people of Australia, trying to dupe the people of Australia, is not a good long‐term strategy. I regret to say that I am totally confident that the people of Australia will not treat this very lightly.

In conclusion, I take up the suggestion of the honourable member for Dobell. If and when there is a by‐election in Lindsay, let us campaign on this. Let us have a referendum on whether it is appropriate for governments to break their election commitments and whether it is appropriate for a government to say, `There'll be no slashing of government expenditure.' Let us contrast what those on the other side said during the election period with what they are doing in government. Let us contrast their commitment to no new taxes with what they are doing in this bill and what they are proposing in the budget. Let us have a referendum on that in the electorate of Lindsay. That is probably very unfair to the honourable member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), but it is an appropriate test. It is an early opportunity for the government to get feedback on their actions. As the honourable member for Dobell has suggested, I invite you to do it.

I am appalled by this bill because of the damage it does to all of us as members of parliament in breaking election commitments. I strongly support the amendment that has been moved by the opposition. As I have said, the amendment merely seeks to redirect the government back to its original election commitment and to ensure that it does not break its promise by having a bill which imposes a new three per cent tax on consumer goods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter, Bob, Jnr, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on the Customs Amendment Bill 1966 and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1966, I have the honour of representing the electorate of Kennedy which produces probably $2,000 million annually in export earnings from mining and a further $1,000 million—arguably, $2,000 million—from agriculture as well. If we are talking about $3,000 million a year in export earnings from that very small proportion of the Australian population, then clearly we take very seriously the imposition of an extra three per cent cost upon our industries and their international competitiveness.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at our mining and agricultural industries in Australia today. The sad fact is that in the four years leading up to 1989‐90 there was a growth in agriculture of 14 per cent over that period. Similarly, there was a growth of 25 per cent in mining. Over a four‐year period these two giant industries increased by 14 per cent and 25 per cent respectively. If you go back through time, they are the average figures that you will find in those two industries. Every four years there is an increase of about 10 per cent to 20 per cent in our earnings from those two sectors of the economy.

Over the last four years leading up to the 1993‐94 financial year, instead of getting a 14 per cent increase for agriculture all we got was a 1.9 per cent increase. In other words, growth in the agricultural sector has stopped completely. Instead of getting a 25 per cent increase in production and income from mining, all we got was a 3.6 per cent increase. In real terms there has been a decline in income from mining and agriculture over the last four years—one of the very rare times that has happened in our history. I daresay you would have to go back to the time of the Great Depression to find a precedent for that situation.

I do not wish to canvass tonight the reasons for that dramatic collapse in our export industries. I point out to the House that our former Prime Minister, Mr Keating, used to make scathing reference to Australia no longer being an extended quarry or a giant sheep run. These comments, of course, were untrue. I simply refer to the heading `Exports of major commodities' which appears in table 2 on page 3. If you go through the list of those commodities you will find that the income from agriculture is 29 per cent and that from mining is 64 per cent. In other words, the much maligned extended sheep run and giant quarry that Mr Keating so happily used to refer to are supplying 93 per cent of the nation's entire income. But that income is drying up. Instead of an increase every four years of 14 per cent and 25 per cent respectively, we now have an increase of 1.9 per cent and 3.6 per cent respectively. I urge the government to please understand that saddling these industries with extra cost structures is not the direction in which we should be travelling.

TALK.START.PARA: —True.

—It would be fairly hypocritical for you to say true when your mob had a five per cent increase in the pipeline. I would not be butting in and provoking me if I were you. One of the ways exporting industries in Australia are punished is through punitively high interest rates—they are still around 12½ per cent for business loans. We find ourselves competing against countries like the United States whose business loans last time I looked—that was some time ago, I must admit—were around six per cent. The net result of this enormously high interest rate is propping up the Australian dollar. When you are trading at a loss of nearly $2,000 million every month and the value of your dollar is rising there is something very wrong with the way the economy is operating.

SPEECH.PARA: I am known for not hesitating to make criticism where criticism is due, but I do not in any way wish my remarks to be construed against the Treasurer (Mr Costello) because it is very early days yet. I think it would be irresponsible for him to take precipitate action, in terms of his portfolio responsibility, as early as the present moment.

I urge the Treasurer and the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), who is in the chamber, to point out to the frontbench that we have very high interest rates in Australia. For over a decade we have had an enormously high interest rate regime which has artificially propped up the Australian dollar. I am on record applauding Mr Keating when he floated the Australian dollar. We knew it would sink, and sink it did. It sank from around 100c in the American dollar to 59c in 1986.

That enormous collapse in the Australian dollar scared the hell out of Treasury. It raised interest rates to enormously high levels—in excess of 20 per cent—and it started buying Australian dollars on the world market. I am not saying that there was not a case for propping it up a bit at the time. When the Australian dollar was allowed to free float, it immediately sunk to 59c. That was when this country had a debt of around $60,000 million. This country now has a debt many times greater than $60,000 million. It is some three times that figure.

BREAK.PARA: If when the debt was only $60,000 million and we were trading a lot more successfully than we are at present—our current account was nowhere near as high as it is now—and the Australian dollar still sank to 69c, then clearly if it were allowed to free float when we owe nearly $200,000 million and our current account deficit is nearly $2,000 million a month it would sink well below 59c. I do not think anyone looking at the figures would seriously believe that the Australian dollar, if allowed to free float, would rise any higher than 50c.

Since the dollar is hovering just below 80c that means that all of our exporting industries are being cheated to the tune of about 50 per cent of their present incomes. We are talking here about huge amounts of money. In the electorate of Kennedy, if we assume that we are exporting in excess of $3,000 million worth of product a year, that means we are being cheated out of $1.5 thousand million per year. If the dollar comes down to 50c then we will receive 50 per cent more for our product than we are receiving now. Heaven only knows, the cattle producers and the wool producers of Australia could desperately use that money.

The copper industry is facing upheavals as a result of the machinations of speculators in the international marketplace. There have been a lot of articles about what has happened in the copper industry. One copper mine in Mount Isa earns some $1.3 thousand million a year. That mine would have an increase in its income of around $500 million or $600 million a year. A town like Mount Isa, which has suffered a lot of pain over recent years, could desperately utilise that money. I always make the point that if the unions are doing their job then that money should flow down to the average worker and employee in Mount Isa and circulate in the economy of that town.

When we look at the western parts of Australia, particularly Queensland and New South Wales, we see so many towns in a desperate state of decline, so many industries on the ropes after the body blow imposed upon them, yet we have a tool at our disposal right now to help them which is simply a reduction in interest rates. That would bring down the Australian dollar. If they got a fair go and if we stopped a practice that is grossly unfair to the exporting sectors of the Australian economy, which is based in regional Australia—that is, this constant propping up of the Australian dollar—it would result in an increase in income to every single western community of some 40 or 50 per cent.

One can argue that the customs tariff bill only imposes a tax of three per cent on a small percentage of the cost structures of our mining and farming enterprises in Australia. That is true. We saw an increase in fuel taxes of some 20 or 30 per cent in real terms over the last decade imposed by the ALP government. We saw a 100 per cent, and in some cases a 200 per cent, increase in land rates for our pastoral industries.

Each of these small cost impositions is eating away at our international competitiveness and imposing cost burdens which are rendering these industries non‐viable. We see today that probably one‐third of our pastoralists in Queensland, our cattle and sheep men, are in an almost terminal situation financially. We look forward to the coming debt summit which will try to help us. I emphasise the point that, while each of these little items may be small in itself, taken collectively, they indicate a huge increase in the cost burden placed upon rural industries in Australia.

To turn to agriculture for one small moment to compare our cost competitiveness in Australia with that of our major international agricultural competitor, the United States, let us go through each of the cost input items to farming. The first one is a sad reflection upon the industry, because the biggest cost input to farming is interest rates. As I said before, the last time I looked, the United States farmer enjoyed interest rates of around six per cent, and our farmers' rates are 12 per cent.

PARA.BREAK: The next cost input item—and I am proud of this fact, not ashamed of it, as it is an excellent thing—is labour costs of $10.50 per hour in the state of Queensland. I imagine they are roughly the same in the other states of Australia. California, the biggest agricultural state in the United States, enjoys labour costs of $4 per hour: less than half the cost in Australia. That is not something to be asham ed of; it is something to be proud of. All the same, it is a 100 per cent higher cost imposition than that in the United States.

BREAK.PARA: The third cost input item in the state of Queensland, and also, I think, in New South Wales, is water. Again, in the largest US agricultural state, California, water cost $3.90 per megalitre, the last time I checked up on the figures. It costs $29 per megalitre in Queensland, a nearly 1,000 per cent difference. The fourth item is fuel and, even if we take the tax off fuel, it costs 42c per litre in Queensland—or in Australia, if you like. In the United States, fuel costs 26c per litre. Finally, the fifth major cost input item is fertiliser. In the United States, urea costs $206 per tonne; in Australia, it costs $396 per tonne.

Every single one of those cost input items is between 40 and 1,000 per cent higher than those of our competitor, the United States. People say that we should do something about that, but it is impossible for the farmer to do anything about the cost of water, since the government sets the cost of water. It is impossible for the farmer to do anything—not that he wants to—about the cost of labour, because that is set by the government. It is impossible for the farmer to do anything about interest rates, because they are set by the Reserve Bank.

I would argue very cogently that our failure to legislate for the oil industry is the major reason that there is such a huge cost difference between ourselves and the United States, where they enjoy the benefits of the really wonderful anti‐trust legislation introduced by Theodore Roosevelt specifically to smash up the oil companies in the United States. We do not enjoy such magnificent legislation in Australia. That is why we pay 42c per litre for our fuel and the United States farmer pays 25c per litre for his fuel. I would say that similar anti‐trust legislation—or anti‐monopoly legislation, as we call it here in Australia—for the fertiliser industry would also see a dramatic reduction in the inexplicable difference between the cost of fertiliser in the United States and the cost of fertiliser here.

One can see why we are non‐cost competitive in agriculture. I know that the budgetary problems for the government are very serious and very significant but, seeing us imposing another three per cent, I must come here tonight to put the argument and the case for our exporting industries—the agricultural and mining industries of Australia—which are reeling on the ropes at the present moment.

The biggest town in the electorate of Kennedy, Mount Isa, has suffered a population decline of probably a third of its population. Most certainly it was over 30,000 and now it is hovering around 20,000. The reason for that is that Mount Isa Mines has just had to adopt almost skeleton staffing levels because times have been very, very tough in the mining industry. One of the reasons times are tough is the cost impositions applied by government in this country.

We keep screaming about the subsidy levels in other countries and there is no doubt about the subsidy levels in sugar, which is a huge commodity in my electorate. We compete on the world market against the world's biggest sugar producer, and biggest sugar exporter as well, the European Community, and the farmers in the European Community enjoy subsidy levels of 192 per cent. It is incomprehensible to me, but even in Thailand farmers and industry enjoy subsidy levels of nearly 100 per cent, which is extraordinary, but that is the reality. They enjoy a price that is twice as high as the world price of sugar, and that is paid to them by the government.

There is one other issue that I wish to canvass tonight. Government is searching for revenue. You can say it is the eternal quest, something like the quest for the Holy Grail, one of those things we search for but never find: the happy taxing arrangement. Someone putting me down recently likened me to Billy Wentworth. Ironically enough, I am a great admirer of old Bill Wentworth and I think that he was one of the finest intellects that proceeded through this House. I most certainly saw his work in Aboriginal affairs, and he was one of the very few ministers for Aboriginal affairs that ever achieved anything significant in that portfolio. Mr Wentworth has been very strong, as has Mr Santamaria in his column in the Australian newspaper, on the issue of primage. All of the federal government's income until the First World War came from primage.

Surely an across‐the‐board tariff, which is GATT neutral—I can quote the section from GATT that says that this is allowed—of seven, eight or 10 per cent on everything coming into this country would enormously help the Australian economy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on this very interesting customs legislation and I support the amendment moved by the opposition. I thought that for once I could have found support for the previous speaker, the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), when he spoke about the impost on mining and agricultural machinery. Indeed, it is going to be an impost there, but he must have misunderstood what I was going to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to his wide‐ranging contribution. I suggest that the $4 an hour paid for people working in California could well be for the Mexicans who are illegally—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is true.
—So that is a problem now. A lot of those that were getting the $4 an hour are probably illegal immigrants anyway.
—They still get it, so they are still at a disadvantage.

—They may still be at a disadvantage, they may still get it, but they should not get it because they are illegals. I do not want to see illegal migrants coming here. It is bad enough when you are going to give the youth $3 an hour here, let alone giving the illegal immigrants $4 an hour. Anyway, that is outside the range of—
—It has been a broad ranging debate but it is too far out on the back paddock at the moment.

—Before you occupied the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, with all due respect, I was just responding to the previous speaker, as you tend to do in the parliamentary tradition. I always come in and listen to the speech that is delivered before I am going to deliver my speech, and I think that in the Westminster tradition, which we do not always uphold in this parliament, part of the art of debate is to pick up the points that the preceding speaker has made and make comment on them.
—Indeed it is.

—No‐one pulled the honourable member for Kennedy back into line when he talked about the wages paid to illegal immigrants in California. As is my right, I made a brief passing comment to it. Having cleared up that issue, let me say that it is amazing how this government thinks that the electorate is gullible. As you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, this was the government that said that there would be no new taxes. Although the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) referred to the `read my lips' line, it is not quite the same as `read my lips'. Indeed, some might suggest it is far worse, because it is yet another broken promise from this government with its 100 days of broken promises.

SPEECH.PARA: Much was made of that promise in the electorate. When I went around the electorate during the election campaign, I was told that the then opposition had embraced all the policies that Labor had been embracing for 10 years, and the one thing that was constantly put to me when I went around to workshops and other places in my electorate was that this government was the government that was going to have no new taxes. However, it has many new taxes.

In the days of the election campaign, the then opposition members, especially the leader, now the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), were running around the country, appearing nightly on television and being quoted in the newspapers promising no new taxes. As I said, there is going to be a tax that was not there. It is a tax of three per cent on something like 17,000 items. It is a GST on consumer imports, but the government will not tell the people, or indeed us, just what items are going to be slugged with this three per cent tax.

So not only is it a consumption tax, but it is also a mystery tax—a little bit like Russian roulette. The consumer buys something and, bingo, he gets a prize. Sometimes he does not get it, but sometimes he gets the mystery prize. What does he get? He gets an additional three per cent tax. It is a bit of a mystery and the prize is the three per cent tax on the items.

The government's decision to extend the changes to the tariff concessions will mean that all consumers will now pay the government three per cent more on the purchase of a vast range of products—some 17,000. It is a very wide‐ranging list of items, including electrical appliances, sporting equipment, and even gym equipment. Those who go to the gym here each morning to exercise, such as the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and others, would find that if those items were being purchased now, there would be an additional three per cent tax on them. Musical instruments, domestic hardware and a whole range of things are included on the list.

As I keep saying, and as other members have said, it is important to remind the people of this. The Prime Minister, when he was Leader of the Opposition, and the now Treasurer (Mr Costello) gave a categorical assurance to the Australian people that there would be no new taxes, no increase in taxes and no changes to the tax mix—and that last one is very important. Within three months, the government has blatantly broken that promise with what, in effect, is a GST on imports. Every time families go to the toy store or the domestic appliance store, they will find the Treasurer's hand in their pockets.

It is very interesting how this change came about. When it was first mooted, it was going to be a tax on business. There was an outcry from the business groups to change the decision to remove tariff concessions from business imports. Indeed, one of the coalition ministers actually admitted that it was dreadful to tax business. The government decided not to tax business, but it is going to tax the consumers instead. The mates are going to be supported, but the poor old consumer is going to be hit again and will have to pay this tax.

A range of items is going to be taxed—some 17,000. Although these 17,000 goods will have a three per cent tax on them, there will be no tax at all on some goods coming through customs at Australian ports. I refer specifically to drugs, pornography and firearms. Why will there be no tax on them? It is because at ports such as Port Kembla, customs services have been drastically reduced under this government. Brian Toohey summed it up very nicely in last weekend's Sun‐Herald. He referred to nine‐to‐five smuggling when he outlined how Customs officials prevented $10 million in cocaine reaching the streets through the port at Hay Point near Mackay.

This is very important because we are going to have officials in Customs checking on some goods to make sure that three per cent is paid income. However, other ports such as Port Kembla, which is one of Australia's busiest ports, will not be so lucky because the customs officers there have been decreased from 12 to five as part of a review of shift work designed to save money. Customs officers will no longer work on weekends or at night time at Port Kembla or Newcastle even though ships are often unloading at these hours. A reduced number of staff will be on duty at Sydney wharves. As one customs officer put it, `You'd have to be dead unlucky to get caught bringing something in during office hours, let alone at the weekend.'

The minister has said that the new Customs Service will work through high quality intelligence and surveillance that will happen outside of office hours. They will have some sort of surveillance camera. But what will happen if someone comes in on a Friday evening? The surveillance camera will capture it but the customs officers will not be able to pick it up until Monday morning at 9 a.m. So the surveillance camera will capture unidentified people leaving the wharf on the Friday evening, but it will not be until Monday morning that anything can be done about it.

There has been much talk here and in the media about the credibility of politics and politicians. Former opposition members had a very strong platform throughout the election campaign that there would be no new taxes. There is now a question regarding their credibility. Do they take the people of Australia as fools? How can we, as politicians, have any credibility when we tell people that there will be no new taxes and then break that promise? Some members of the government have said today that this is not really a tax. When is a tax not a tax? If it is not a tax, what is it? It is a slug, a slug which will bring in something like $400 million each year. What is that? Is that a windfall? Those opposite can call it what they will, but to me it is a tax by a different name. It is yet another broken promise by this government. I very much support the amendment foreshadowed by the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has always said that he wants to establish a relationship of trust with the Australian people. He has said that he wants to establish a bond whereby the Australian people can rely on his words and his promises. This customs bill and scores of other broken promises have shattered that trust. This bill and scores of other broken promises have shattered that bond. This bill is another broken tax promise. It is a three per cent tax on consumers. We know it is a tax because the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) has said so. In the Sydney Morning Herald on 2 April Mr Moore conceded that it was totally correct to say the removal of tariff concession orders was an extra tax. There it is from the minister's mouth that this is a tax. That ends once and for all any question as to the status of this particular measure.

SPEECH.PARA: As a tax, it is completely contrary to the coalition's tax promise. They were the party prior to the election that would never introduce a new tax. They would not change the tax mix; they would not increase any tax. But barely 100 days into the Howard government we have a broken tax promise before the parliament which will place a three per cent tax on consumers. All those valuable items in the households, in the pubs and clubs and on the sporting fields of Australia are to be levied with an additional three per cent tax. This government has decided, contrary to its election promise and what the former government was intending, to place a three per cent tax on consumer goods imported to Australia where similar goods are not produced within this country.

The government is, in this debate, again trying to construct its alibi for a breach of faith with the Australian people, an alibi by which a broken promise can be justified. Of course, the coalition always alludes to the fiscal position. But we know too well that this is the standard tory method in Australia for breaking promises. It was patented by Nick Greiner in New South Wales in 1988 and was then tried on in Victoria, Western Australia and South Australia. It is the standard message from the conservatives, who make promises only to break them. They come into government and say that the cupboards are bare.

Tomorrow, we are having the report of the Commission of Audit. It will be bodgied up to try to legitimise things, to try to create the alibi by which this coalition government can break its promises. But the truth has come out: when the member for Higgins, the Treasurer (Mr Costello), made the allegation on 12 March, he said that the parameters had changed and that the problem was that the forecasted growth had slowed. The problem has now been corrected by the March quarter national accounts and, apparently, growth is going gang‐busters. Even the Prime Minister has acknowledged as much in a very open account to the international bankers when he said that the Australian economy was in good shape. Let me quote from that conference in Sydney on 3 June. The member for Bennelong had this to say:

The incoming Government inherited an Australian economy . . . that was a little better than just good in parts . . . We have had 19 quarters of positive economic growth . . . low levels of inflation, and we continue to enjoy the benefits . . .

The Australian people are quite entitled to ask this basic question: if things are so good and the Australian economy is in such good shape, why do the cuts need to be so big? If the Australian economy is in such good shape, why do tax promises need to be broken, and why does the parliament need to consider this new three per cent tax on consumers?

The government is seeking an alibi, an alibi that the Prime Minister has blown with his admission that things are in good shape. There is no reason to break the government's tax promises. We are now to believe that the five minutes of economic sunshine that the Prime Minister spoke of in 1995 have turned into the year's longest day of economic growth, the longest growth cycle in the nation's modern history. We have also had an understanding in recent times of the $3 billion hole that the coalition has dug for itself with its uncosted election promises. So much for transparency on the budget! The government will not release the Department of Finance costings on the $3 billion worth of coalition election commitments made prior to 2 March.

The other interesting thing in relation to the fiscal position is that the coalition itself, throughout the course of 1995, became the poachers in the Senate, knocking $2.3 billion of revenue off the Commonwealth budget. The poachers, of course, have come into this House and said that they are the gamekeepers. But the gamekeepers are the ones trying to bodgie up an alibi by which they can break their promises to the Australian people. It was the member for Bennelong, supported by the member for Higgins, who throughout the election campaign chanted across the nation their mantra of no new taxes and no tax increases. They did everything within their power to chant that mantra—everything, bar asking the Australian people to read their lips.

Indeed, at the Press Club before the election, the member for Higgins said, `It is not our agenda to introduce new taxes. It is not our agenda to bulk up currently existing taxes.' Bulk up? He is a tax hulk, breaking out of his suit with enthusiasm to tax the Australian people. This legislation reveals very starkly one fundamental truth in Australian politics, and that is this: how can anyone take the coalition's mandate seriously, if the coalition does not itself respect it?

If the coalition does not respect its own mandate, its own solemn promise to the Australian people, not to introduce new taxes, such as the one contained in this legislation, how can the Australian people and this parliament respect it when it comes to provisions like the privatisation of Telstra and the labour market deregulation bill? The coalition has always claimed a mandate on those issues, but it has no mandate on any issue unless it is prepared to respect its own promises. It is an absolute act of disrespect to the parliament, to the Australian people, to all the businesses and to all the taxpayers, to introduce this legislation into the House of Representatives.

What we are seeing is broken promise after broken promise. It was very interesting, in relation to this question, to recall the words of the Prime Minister on the John Laws program just before the election. He was asked, `If you were given a choice between keeping all your promises and running down the budget or breaking promises and bringing the budget back into surplus, what would you choose?' The Prime Minister said very clearly that, given that choice, he would keep his promises at any cost to the budget. That proves one basic thing: you cannot trust the Prime Minister on his promise to keep his promises. That is how bad it is. He is breaking his promise to keep his promise on no new taxes. This is a three per cent consumption tax that is being levied across most of the sectors in Australia.

After the election, the Prime Minister said on the John Laws program, `I am desperate to be an honest man.' That is what he said: he is desperate to be an honest man. He can't be too desperate this evening, because as consumers throughout the country pay their three per cent impost they will not think that the Prime Minister is desperate at all; and they certainly will not think that he is honest. They will think that he is a sneak, a welsher, a promise breaker, someone who made all those election promises for one purpose and one purpose only; that is, he made them to be broken. When he put his hand on his heart and said to the Australian people, `There will be no new taxes under a Howard administration,' he made that promise only to break it.

One needs only to recall the debate in the House earlier. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) accurately described this tax as a mystery tax. So much for respect for the parliament ahead of the executive. The parliament does not even have an indication as to which items this tax will be levied on. There is one report in the media that 17,000 consumer items throughout Australia are to be affected by this legislation.

BREAK.PARA: The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism responded to the suggestion of a mystery tax by saying that it is actually a mystery ball, like the Shane Warne ad, where they bowl the mystery ball and it darts through the hotels and the houses and across the sporting arenas of Australia and comes back and bowls Ian Botham. I can appreciate why the minister for industry was saying that it was a mystery ball, because his own delivery on this has bowled the Treasurer middle stump. He has rolled the Treasurer on this measure right through the cabinet process, and bowled him middle stump. He joins a long list of state and territory leaders who have been doing that in recent times. For the poor old Treasurer, it is duck after duck after duck as the middle stump is knocked back.

It is all well and good for the minister for industry to joke about this being the mystery ball that he has bowled to the Treasurer, but I think the comparison runs a bit closer to the bone. In that cricketing commercial the mystery ball starts out by going through the houses of Australia. It is very interesting to note that the mystery tax will be doing exactly the same thing. The mystery tax will be going through the houses—through the windows, through the doors—placing a three per cent consumption tax on all household items. It is a tax on baby walkers, battery operated dolls, bone china goods, can openers, candlesticks, coffee grinders, dolls' shoes, dolls' strollers, food blenders, microwave ovens, electric trains, food processors, knives, lint removers, men's and women's shavers, quilts, rice cookers, squeaky toys, toy music boxes, toy vehicles, toy washing machines, vacuum cleaners, video games and yoghurt makers. They are the sorts of items which will qualify under this three per cent consumption tax; they are the sorts of items that will be affected.

Where does the mystery tax turn to after that? It crosses the sporting and playing fields of the nation. As it does there is a three per cent tax on baseball equipment, basketballs, bicycles, electronic dart boards, exercise cycles, golf club grips, golf club practising machines, gymnastic equipment, ice hockey skates, javelins, discuses, knee guards. All these items are subjected to a three per cent mystery tax. It covers pogo sticks, pool toys, skateboards, skipping ropes, soccer balls, softball bats, table tennis balls. The list goes on. All these basic consumer items used on the playing fields of Australia go up by three per cent.

I know what the impact will be, because the mystery tax will be crossing the electorate of Werriwa. There is no more important activity in the south‐west of Sydney than what happens on the playing fields of Campbelltown and Liverpool. All the families who participate in and love their weekend sport will be affected adversely by this three per cent consumption tax. So the mystery tax will be passing across household items, across the sporting fields and across the sporting arenas.

TALK.START.PARA: —All taxes are going up, up, up!

—As the member for Burke points out, taxes are going up, up, up under this high taxing government with its three per cent consumption tax. Where will the mystery tax turn next? It is just like the mystery ball. It will pass through the pubs and clubs of Australia, smashing its way through as it levies its three per cent impost. The price of billiard balls will go up by three per cent, as will the price of billiard cues, coin‐operated pinball machines, dart flights, dice, steel guitars, synthesisers, and even Christmas decorations. That is how low this government has gone.
—Christmas decorations!

—Yes, even the Christmas decorations will be taxed. Not only in the pubs and sporting clubs but also in the households of Australia, the price of imported Christmas decorations will go up by three per cent under this government, yet it promised no new taxes. `No new taxes' was the Prime Minister's promise to the Australian people at the 2 March election. This legislation goes out of its way to hurt Australian families. This is the legislation that the coalition said it would never introduce to this House. This is evidence that under this government it has become a dog's life for Australian taxpayers and consumers. It has become a dog's life for all Australians affected by this high taxing government.

BREAK.PARA: It is often said—and it is a bit of a cliche—that you cannot teach an old dog new tricks. That is not what they are saying at the Treasury these days. They have been teaching their old dog plenty of new tricks: new tricks like a $1.2 billion GST on the states; new tricks like a consumption tax on the Australian public, as contained in this particular legislation. Speaking of dogs, it is worth quoting what the member for Higgins said on 30 January:
Here is the big difference between us and the government: Mr Willis wants to increase taxes. We don't. That is the big difference between us.

This was not a promise that was sundry to the election campaign. This was not a promise which was a matter of trivia in the public debate. This was a promise that the Treasurer was willing to stake his reputation on during the election campaign. This was a promise not to introduce taxes, not to change the tax rates, a promise upon which Peter Costello was willing to stake his reputation. He made this the defining issue of the 1996 federal campaign. He said that the big difference between Labor and the coalition was that Labor allegedly wanted to increase taxes and the coalition did not.

On that defining issue, on the issue on which the Treasurer has staked his reputation, he stands condemned by this House. He stands condemned for misleading the Australian people on tax policy. They are suffering from tax fraud. They are suffering from the tax grabs of this government. This legislation is only part of the pattern of higher taxes under this Howard‐Fischer government.

For a government that said at the election that it would not introduce taxes, what have the Australian people had to face? They have had to face an increase in the Medicare levy, a $70 per annum impost on taxpayers—a one‐off $500 million tax increase for the coming financial year. Beyond that, they are now facing the prospect of the state Costello taxes. We know they are Costello taxes because Jeff Kennett said he would name his state taxes after his dog, so they are state Costello taxes. That amounts to a $650 million tax grab that will hit the average taxpayer in Australia by $150 per annum. That is a $150 per annum tax grab that the government said would never happen. It promised that these things would not be placed before the parliament at state or federal level.

The impact is severe. The price of beer is going up. Cigarette prices are going up. There will be levies. People in Victoria are now talking about Peter's poll tax as they face the prospect of a land levy to pay for the way in which the Treasurer abused the Premiers Conference process. Beyond that, the Treasurer did not get what he wanted. He really wanted a $1.2 billion GST on the states. So there is an increase in the Medicare levy and there is the state Costello taxes.

Small business and self‐funded retirees have also been affected because they have been swindled on the uplift factor on provisional tax. The coalition promised six per cent but they have legislated a permanent rate of 10 per cent, which is now before the Senate. That is a $540 million tax diddle. It is a $540 million tax grab over the three years of this parliament.

Beyond that, the Treasurer thinks he has got away with imposing a sales tax on government cars—something that will cripple the car industry in Australia. It is a tax grab of $100 million per annum. There have been those four clear areas of broken promises relating to tax. Now there is a fifth, the measure which stands before the House—that is, a tax grab of $500 million per annum.

How do the Australian people come to understand the tax scorecard of the Howard‐Fischer government? How does that scorecard stand tonight, after barely 100 days of this administration? It is the Medicare levy, $500 million; the state Costello taxes, $2,000 million throughout the life of this parliament; the uplift factor on provisional tax, $540 million throughout the life of this parliament; the tax on cars, $300 million. This bill is a startling $1.5 billion over the next three years. The total tax scorecard for the Howard-Fischer government is a startling $5 billion throughout the life of this parliament. For each taxpayer in Australia that equals $625 over the next three years or $210 per annum.

That is the bottom line for all those battlers, all those families, all those taxpayers who put faith and trust in the member for Bennelong, who is now the Prime Minister. The bottom line, barely 100 days into his administration, is they are $210 per annum worse off, including the measures in this bill, than when this government started on 2 March. It is all before this government gets serious with its August budget. It is all before it even gets into the serious debate it wants to have on the GST.

Not so long ago, on 2 May, the Treasurer said in this House: `I must say, there is a lot of economic sense in a GST.' So he is keen, as the coalition has always been keen, on the idea of a goods and services tax. Just this morning, in the national press, in the Sydney Morning Herald there was an article headed `Howard keen to encourage debate on GST'.

So Australian taxpayers are $210 per annum worse off under this government, under the five broken promises on tax that we have seen already. This is before they have even warmed up, before these National Party gentlemen opposite even get keen on tax. This is a big taxing government that has made the average Australian taxpayer $210 worse off per annum after barely 100 days, and the GST is still to come. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —People might wonder why members on this side of the House and I, following the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), are so focused on this issue of imposing new taxes in the Australian economy that flow very directly from the customs legislation that is on the table at the moment. These increases, imposts within the Australian economy, come from changes to the excise and customs legislation. We are so focused on this issue of new costs and impositions in the Australian economy because at every stage of the federal election campaign, held only 100 or so days ago, John Howard and Peter Costello said instantly—
—Order! The honourable member will refer to those gentlemen by their correct titles.
—I understand this, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Don't just understand it, please do it.
—I am very happy, Mr Deputy Speaker, to abide by that ruling. But many times I have heard the so‐called Beazley budget black hole referred to by members on your side of the House, and not once—
—I have no side of the House.

—have I heard you or any other Deputy Speaker drawn from your side of the House raise this question. All of a sudden you are concerned. We use the term `Costello's con'; you use the term `Beazley's black hole'. I wonder why, now, all of a sudden, I am being pulled up and asked to refer to members by their constituency. All right, I will.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Since you are asking the question, I will answer it. I have been in the chair on many occasions when the two phrases—`Beazley's black hole' and `Costello con'—have been used and in a spirit of equity I have allowed them both to be used because they are not referring to the individual. They are referring in a descriptive manner.

INTERJECT.PARA: The reason I asked you to refer to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer by their correct titles was that you did not say `Beazley black hole' or `Costello con'; you referred to John Howard and Peter Costello. I will try not to interrupt you again, but I would be grateful if you would refer to honourable members by their correct title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very happy to, Mr Deputy Speaker. I think the point is well made on both our parts.

BREAK.PARA: The now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the now Treasurer (Mr Costello) constantly referred to their claim that they would bring to Australia `honest government', and that they understood the parameters of the budget process. The opposition leader at the time, the new Prime Minister, many times said that, no matter what Treasury estimates turn out, he would honour his promises to the Australian constituency and work his way through the budget proposals.

Now we have—all this done, of course, under the pretence of bringing to people `honest government'—100 days into the show a litany of broken promises, a litany of taxes and imposts on the Australian community.
