We had at question time here today the rather bizarre notion constantly reinforced by both the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) and the Treasurer that the $1,500 million worth of forced handovers or trade‐offs coughed up last week by the state Premiers was not a new tax from the federal government, that it was not an impost from the federal government. In fact, the Deputy Prime Minister said many times that they are state taxes and they will be responsible for them.

Every state Premier is now out explaining to their people that there is either what they are calling `a Costello tax' or `a new federal government levy'. Never in 13 years of Labor government did we see this process reduced to the farce it was last week, and never did we see the state Premiers, Liberal and Labor, unanimously referring to a process as amateurish.

There is another aspect of this legislation that I want to refer to briefly. One of the subsidiary items in the legislation is the restoration of agricultural use of diesel fuel in the mining of limestone to qualify for the diesel fuel rebate—something which we are quite supportive of. There is no problem there, but it does raise this issue of the diesel fuel rebate. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, you represent a regional or rural electorate, as I do. You well understand that it is not just the farm sector which has received assurances about minimal change to the diesel fuel rebate. That is where they see themselves at the moment.

The fishing industry is still waiting for some assurance and the mining sector is now cranking up its lobbying effort in town because it has not been able to get the same assurances. Of course, the reason limestone mining is suddenly being classified a little bit differently is that it is the farmers who use the lime.

What is it about this government? It seems to have a cabinet that is prepared to make special provisions for farmers but not for miners, has not yet declared itself on fishing, and certainly is not interested in the broader issue of diesel fuel excise in the transport industry. There is something going on over there. I suppose that—as the Deputy Prime Minister, who is the leader of the National Party, said at question time today—all will be revealed on 20 August. We will be waiting, with interest, to see.

I was bemused by the position that came out of the Premiers Conference: bemused by the about‐turn by state Premiers on the issue of general purpose grants versus sales tax on cars, for heaven's sake. I saw the Prime Minister interviewed on the 7.30 Report and observed his comment—which I believe to be true—that, prior to the Premiers Conference, he discussed some of the measures with Premiers and they all indicated to him that they regarded their general purpose untied grants as sacrosanct in the process, saying, `Okay, if you have to do things, we will go with you. But, for heaven's sake, leave us with our untied grants.' That is how the Prime Minister explained it on the 7.30 Report. That is why it appears to be such a dramatic about‐face.

Why is it that the Premiers suddenly regard sales tax on cars as far more significant than untied grants? Look at the proposal as it came from the Treasurer and the Prime Minister. I notice the Premiers have all been very keen to pin the tail on the donkey—in this case, the Treasurer—yet somehow did not really couple the Prime Minister with responsibility for it, but he is in there as well.

I very well understand that they did not understand where this impost bites most. I will tell you where it bites most: it bites most in regional and rural Australia, where there is a list as long as your arm of community based organisations and town operations. For instance, the hospitals, the senior citizens clubs, the councils and the fire authorities—particularly regional fire authorities, such as the CFA in my state, Victoria—all buy cars and vehicles with a sales tax exemption. All of a sudden, all these operations have to pay sales tax. In a party which is in a desperate state over things like the National Party's inability to come to grips with native title—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is their leadership.
—Strong leadership!
—Order! The member for Capricornia will restrain his desire to join the debate when he is out of his place.

—These are two parties forming a coalition government which are, 100 days into their honeymoon, split down the middle. What does the Treasurer turn up with, all of a sudden? He turns up with a sales tax proposal that is going to punch the guts out of every country town in Australia. For the first time, they stood up and fought.

BREAK.PARA: But who stood up and fought? Not the National Party members in here. The National Party members who stood up and fought were those in the state governments, who understood what this meant to the towns. By the time the Premiers arrived in town, they had decided to do a deal to give away $1,500 million of what they had told the Prime Minister was their most sacrosanct fund—untied grants—in return for protecting the car sales tax exemption for these bodies throughout regional and rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—The member for Werriwa says, `Shame!' I say, make those priority judgments but at least be honest in here. Don't stand up in here and say to us that this is not a federal government tax, this is something the states have to deal with. Don't stand up here and say to us that the about‐face was something that the states offered up and don't stand in here and say to us that you understood all the way down the line the implications of what proved to be a hellishly dopey proposal. How do we know it is a hellishly dopey proposal? We know because every year from 1983 Treasury and Finance used to serve up to us stuff like `Let's have a GST', `Let's knock off the diesel fuel rebate', `Let's knock off the sales tax to government and non‐profit organisations who need these things'. They would serve it up every year. Even Peter Walsh, who would certainly be regarded as the toughest Finance Minister Australia has had in the last two decades, would say, `Go away with that.' But who fell for it? The novices.

BREAK.PARA: The bottom line here is this: the government should not expect the opposition to take kindly to a deal where they have wandered around Australia promising honest government, going on national television, pointing to Ralph Willis and ridiculing Ralph Willis for being honest enough to say on national television that no tax mix can remain immune from change, leaping onto that and saying that the former Treasurer has really admitted that there may have to be an increase in taxes, and then so publicly, on every front page, promising right across the nation `No changes to taxes and no new taxes'. They are now wondering why we are going to focus on it.

By gee, we are going to focus on it. We are going to focus on it in every public meeting we go to. We are going to explain the Costello con in every public meeting we go to. We are going to explain how people have been listening to what I call populist cant and they have now been confronted with Liberal‐National reality. That Liberal‐National reality is absolutely no different to 1977 when John Howard as Treasurer gave people tax cuts and three months later introduced legislation to take all the money back off them. Now people are understanding this and we are going to help them understand it a bit further—day by day, week by week, town by town.

I did a radio interview this morning on regional radio in central Victoria and we talked about the changes to education funding in these country towns—which are now represented by Liberals and Nationals—which are suddenly seeing their students facing up to increases in HECS charges and are suddenly seeing their job agencies such as Skillshare being wound back—all in the hundred days of the new honeymoon.

I don't think it is unreasonable to spell out the script. That is the script we will be working to. We will be pinning the government down to its rhetoric of honest government, no changes in taxes and no new taxes. We will be pinning the Prime Minister down to his very public statements that his number one priority is honouring his tax commitments, honouring his promises. We will be pinning them down and we will be following this through, just having people understand what it is they have come to deal with.

It is also important for those of us in this place and the close watchers of politics—the people who sit up in the press gallery and elsewhere—in looking at a situation like last week where the Premiers did a 180‐degree dance around, to ask, `Why is that so? How could that be?' The answer lies deep within—the split between the Nationals and the Liberals and their inability to come to grips with the fact that they represent all of Australia. The Nationals do not just represent country Australia. They have to embrace mainstream responsibilities in their thinking and the Liberals have to understand that their responsibilities are broader.

It is not reasonable for you, after wandering around Australia, to threaten, or promise, in fact, to cut public spending and get rid of public servants. All of a sudden you have landed in the job and have come to face the reality that 85 per cent of public servants do not live and work in Canberra. They live and work in places like Bendigo and Ballarat—in my region—Bathurst, North Queensland and Western Australia. When you make the cuts to all these programs, it is rural and regional Australia that is affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I have been listening to the shadow minister for resources and energy for some time, and I have been waiting to see whether he is going to talk about the bill before the House. I would ask that perhaps he could, in his concluding remarks, at least refer to the bill before the House. He seems to be wide of the discussion.
—I thank the minister, but it has been a very broad ranging debate by speakers from both sides of the House. I certainly hope that future speakers would be more relevant.
—I will humour my colleague on the other side by saying that I have only a couple of minutes to go.
—So make your concluding remarks.

—I will make my concluding remarks. I will end where I started. We are supporting this legislation in the aspects that have been outlined. This is not a major piece of legislation, except for the three per cent across-the-board imposts on the Australian economy that are being denied as tax increases and being denied as the opening gambit in the move to a GST by stealth. That is really what this is all about. This is softening people up for increases in sales tax on Christmas decorations and every other item on the list.
—Christmas decorations; it is shocking.
—And Barbie dolls.

—You guys have covered the list. I do not want to go through it again. I make the point that there is something very instructive about the diesel fuel rebate now being announced as being okay for limestone mining because limestone is a farmer's product, but not okay for other forms of mining. The whole diesel fuel rebate issue exposes a lot about what is going on inside this government and helps us understand their lack of understanding about the task that faces them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The bills which are currently before the House under cognate debate give effect to a press release issued by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) on 8 May entitled `Tariff concession system to continue'. The minister's statement said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has confirmed that it will retain a modified tariff concession system from 1 July 1996. The tariff concession system will operate a concessional rate of duty of three per cent. The TCS will still apply to both consumer goods and business inputs.
The key words, of course, are that the TCS will apply to both consumer goods and business inputs.

PARA.BREAK: That release, put out in the dead of night as it was, was fundamentally a broken promise of a key coalition commitment to the Australian community at the last election: no new taxes, no tax increases. The amendment which the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), the shad ow minister for industry, has foreshadowed in respect of Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1), reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The bill breaches the government's election commitment that it would not increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes and should therefore be withdrawn, redrafted and re‐presented in a form in which:
(1) goods for personal consumption on which tariff concession orders apply continue to enter Australia free of duty; and
(2) no change be made to the duty rate which currently applies to policy by‐laws.

The fundamental issue so far as we on this side of the House are concerned is that the three per cent impost on consumer goods is a fundamental breach of an election commitment and a fundamental breach of the Prime Minister's compact with the Australian people.

The range of consumer items to which this new three per cent tax will apply means that the new consumer tax which this legislation introduces will apply to a range of electrical appliances, to sporting equipment, to musical instruments and to domestic hardware. One estimate has it that there are as many as 17,000 consumer items to which the new three per cent import tax will apply.

Some of the consumer items to which it is thought this new impost applies include baby walkers, basketballs, battery operated dolls, bicycles, can openers, children's playground equipment, children's rides on cars, cot lights, dolls' shoes, dolls' clothes, foam seat cushions, garbage disposal units, juice extractors, men's and women's shavers, rag dolls, rice cookers, skateboards, skipping ropes, soccer balls, softball bats, squeaky toys, table tennis balls, bats and nets, tenpin bowling balls, tennis balls, vacuum cleaners, watchbands and straps and bracelets—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the lint brushes?
—I had to leave some of them off.
—Christmas decorations!

—I can't read all 17,000 out tonight. But what does that tell us? It tells us that this is just another indication of the government's intention to do what it said it wanted to do in the course of the 1993 elec tion but was prevented from doing. What it wants to do in the course of this term of office is to get Fightback in through the back door. This is Fightback by the back door, a GST by stealth, and we have seen with the government's proposed expenditure cuts the slashing and burning that was expressly provided for in the Fightback document. History shows the many references to the reintroduction of a GST in just the short time since the election.

SPEECH.PARA: On 13 March we saw in the Australian `GST architect stages own Fightback'. The report said that a consultant who costed Fightback for the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, had indicated to the Australian that a GST should be back on the public agenda.

That was followed on 30 March by a call for a GST by Mr John Ralph at an Australian Institute of Company Directors forum in Western Australia, my own state. The article was headed `We need a GST: Ralph'. Then we find in the Age on 8 April the article `Business lobbies Howard for a GST'. The article said that the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry was lobbying the Prime Minister for a reintroduction of a GST.

In the Australian Financial Review on 15 April—the articles are now coming thick and fast—was the story headlined `Summit to boost GST campaign'. The report said that an ACCI summit was proposed to be held in September. The report indicated:
While the ACCI proposal did not explicitly mention a broad‐based consumption tax such as a GST, the group has been strongly promoting it since the election.

Just as we have seen members opposite do. At about the same time was the article in the Canberra Times titled `GST back on agenda with tax summit'. That has taken us from March to April. By the time we get to May, we find that some of the close colleagues of those opposite are now publicly advocating looking at a GST.

On 3 May in the West Australian was the report `GST needs another look, says Court'. On 20 May came the story `Now States push for GST'. At the same time was a report in the Canberra Times titled `GST on agenda as bankers join the call'. At the same time in the Financial Review was `Business puts GST on agenda'. Then we get somewhat close to the heart of the matter on 24 May in the Sydney Morning Herald with `Reith plan on the table: GST: the tax that dare not speak its name'. The report said:
Mr Peter Reith, one of the key proponents of the Coalition's goods and services tax in the 1993 election, has raised the prospect of its introduction in the second term of a Howard Government.

In private meetings with several business groups in recent weeks, the Minister for Industrial Relations has asked them not to raise debate about the GST because this might force the Government to rule it out for its second term of office, a concern that indicates the Government wants the option of introducing a GST.

So we have the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) walking around the place telling people to go quiet on the push for the GST for fear that the government would have to rule it out in a second term. But the minister should not have been so concerned.

On the following day in the Sydney Morning Herald was the article `Howard leaves options open for second‐term GST'. So we know that the Prime Minister is keeping plenty of space here for the reintroduction of a GST proposal. That report quotes the Prime Minister as saying:
The introduction of a goods and services tax in the second term of a Howard Government remains a possibility after the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, ruled it out only "for this Government".

Mr Howard was responding to a report in yesterday's Herald which said the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith, . . . had urged business groups not to raise debate about the need for a GST because this might lead to the tax being ruled out for a second term.
Mr Howard is also quoted as saying:

I can tell the Australian public that we went to the last election saying the GST was not part of our policy for this Government and that remains the position and I really can't say any more. There is nothing more to say.
There is nothing more to say because he wants that option left open.

At the same time we see in the Canberra Times `GST is "back on the agenda"'. In the Age on 28 May was `GST could save farmers $1b a year, says paper'. That was a suggestion by the National Farmers Federation that the GST be reintroduced. `Tax groceries' said business leaders in the Sydney Morning Herald of the same day. The ACCI was saying that consumers' groceries ought to be taxed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am reluctant to interrupt the member for Perth and I have deliberately refrained from doing so for some time, but I presume he is planning to tie these remarks into the bill without too much—
—In the same manner that all the speakers have done before me, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—We have already pulled them up on that one, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—As the Deputy Speaker in the chair beforehand made the point quite rightly, this has been a wide‐ranging discussion.
— The member for Perth has the call.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. We find on 3 June `Senator sees GST as a BIT of GAS', referring to Senator Ian Macdonald, a Queensland Liberal. Senator Macdonald is reported as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I really think that we do again have to start debating a proper and sensible indirect taxation system, a proper and sensible consumption tax for Australia.
The Premier of Victoria on 12 June called for a GST, and a report in the Australian on 17 June said `Nats back introduction of GST'. That report stated:
The rising tide of support for a broad‐based goods and services tax swelled at the weekend when a motion for its introduction was carried at the annual conference of the NSW National Party.
The vote followed the fallout from last week's premiers conference in Canberra, in which several State leaders called for the GST issue to be revisited . . .

The GST resolution was passed despite the reservations of the party's elder statesman and former federal parliamentary leader, Mr Ian Sinclair, who said it "ignored the consequences" of the tax debate in the lead‐up to the 1993 election.

I am pleased to see that the right honourable member for New England was at that conference when others were absent. The coup de grace occurred today in the Sydney Morning Herald . The Prime Minister has gone from not wanting to talk about the GST in a second term, but the headline states `Howard keen to encourage debate on GST'. It ties in appropriately with the bill before the House where we find a three per cent tax on all those consumer items. The article states:
Debate on the need for a goods and services tax (GST) is now something that the Prime Minister says he wants to "encourage".
We now find the Prime Minister encouraging an active debate on the GST. The article goes on to say:

But Mr Howard's comments are certain to raise questions about the Government's position on a GST for the second term. A GST has only been ruled out for this term, and the Government has made no comment about next term.

It goes on to refer to the Western Australian member for O'Connor, Mr Wilson Tuckey, confirming with the Herald last night that he would formally raise the issue of tax reform at today's government party meeting.

In the short period since the election we have consistently found that there has been an ongoing effort on the part of those associated with the coalition, members of the coalition and, indeed, the Prime Minister himself, to actively encourage and engage in a debate which would see the reintroduction of a GST. It is appropriate to link that notion with this bill because the key component of this bill, which the opposition opposes, is the extension of the TCS to consumer goods as well as to business inputs.

I referred to the list of consumer items which the TCS will apply to. As I have said previously, one estimate is that as many as 17,000 items could be the subject of the new three per cent impost. In his opening remarks for the opposition on this bill, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) made the point that in addition to this being a breach of promise so far as the coalition's commitment to no new taxes and no tax increases was concerned, in addition to it being effectively part of Fightback by stealth, this can also be regarded as a mystery tax on the basis that the parliament does not have before it a full and proper understanding of all the items which it has proposed will be covered by this particular measure.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not talking on the bill at all, you know.
—We are adroitly on the minister's bill, as he and the Treasurer well know.
—Order! I remind both the minister and the member for Perth that their remarks should be directed through the chair, as they are both well aware.

—There is another side to this particular matter. This bill found its birth in a press release issued by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), who is now at the table, on 8 May. This occurred after a scrap in the cabinet between the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism and the Treasurer. That was a scrap which the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism won. In recent days we saw the Treasurer lose another tax battle—his attempt to increase sales tax so far as the states are concerned.
—And didn't the premiers attack him!

—That is right. A few days ago an article appeared in the Australian headlined `Premiers unite for attack on Costello'. So the attack that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism successfully launched on the Treasurer pales into insignificance given the attack which the premiers have recently launched on the Treasurer. In the Australian on 14 June the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Court, is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: We did not accept being locked into the Federal Government having access to a growth tax—we were never told before the election that they were going to impose this tax on the States.
If you were an Australian consumer you would be excused for having exactly the same response to the legislation before the House. Mr Brown, the Premier of South Australia, is quoted as saying:

"Commonwealth‐State relations have never been as low as they are now" . . . "the Commonwealth Government is trying to impose on the State governments and local governments a GST (goods and services tax) through sales tax".
So we find a consistent theme.

In the Australian at the beginning of this week there was an article titled `Howard moves to back embattled Costello', by the Australian correspondent Glenn Milne. It makes a point of the Treasurer being done in by the state premiers and spends some time going through the member for O'Connor's comprehensive position paper on a consumption tax, which he produced at his party meeting today.

So we find a consistent theme in all these events: a broken election promise so far as this consumer tax is concerned, and no indication to the states so far as sales tax increases are concerned. Both these items are able to be regarded as Fightback through the back door, Fightbackdoor and GST by stealth.

It can be seen as an increasing and growing agenda on the part of the government to encourage a debate on the introduction of a GST, leaving itself the space to introduce a GST in the course of this term or any other term that the Australian community might be unfortunate enough to be lumbered with.

These items are strongly opposed by the opposition. The reason for that is succinctly found in the amendment proposed to be moved by the member for Hotham. The bill breaches the government's election commitment that it would not increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes. It should, therefore, be withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and my other colleagues have spoken at great length and have outlined, quite significantly, the issues related to this customs bill and its implications for Australians as a first step in the road towards a consumption tax. I want to put it in a broader context and look at this bill in terms of its implications for the so‐called rock solid guarantee that no worker would be worse off under the Howard government. For so many reasons that rock solid guarantee is crumbling, and this bill adds to that impression of crumbling. It is just another fissure in that rock on which that so‐called rock solid guarantee is based.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the matters before this parliament at the moment, we find, in the industrial relations arena with the workplace relations bill, proposals that will directly adversely affect the wages and working conditions of workers, particularly those in Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania and, indirectly, throughout Australia through its attack on the three pillars of living standards of Australian workers—the Industrial Relations Commission, the award system and the right of workers to organise in their workplace. There you have one direct, immediate, adverse consequence for Australians in terms of their attempt to cash in on the rock solid guarantee that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) gave before the election—that no Australian worker would be worse off.

It is very hard to convince the people I have met in workplaces, particularly those in Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania, confronting these changes, that they will not be worse off. It is very hard to convince the more than 9,000 Australians in the Public Service who have lost their jobs that they are not worse off under this government. It is a very difficult argument to persuade those individuals, who thought they had a career and now find they are in search of a new career, that they are not worse off under this government. It is very hard to convince those people who will be paying the state taxes and charges flowing from that absolute debacle we had last week which went under the name of the Premiers Conference. It was nothing more than a debacle.

State taxes and charges are flowing from that conference. I noticed the New South Wales Treasurer talking about the Howard and Costello tax that he was introducing, very reluctantly. With similar reluctance, the Premier of Queensland, the governments of Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia and Western Australia will be moving either to introduce new taxes or to cut services.

What we all know is that the taxes available to the states are inherently inequitable and regressive taxes. They do not have available to them the progressive taxes which are constitutionally the right and responsibility of this Commonwealth parliament. When you force the states to move in the direction of increasing their taxes and charges, the burden of that is principally going to fall on ordinary working men and women who are battling to earn an income and support their families. It is very hard to convince those people in those circumstances that they are not going to be worse off under this government—that after 100 days that rock solid guarantee is of much value to them.

Of course, the advocacy of this government is—and some states may respond in this direction if the press reports are correct—that they should not increase their taxes and charges; they should cut their services. All the evidence makes it very clear that the activity which government undertakes which does most to increase the equity in our society—that is the most effectively redistributive—is the way in which the government provides services, the expenditure of money raised on the provision of services. Services, by their very nature, predominantly go to Australians most in need—not everyone.

We have to be rigorous in the review of expenditure and rigorous in our analysis of how revenue should be raised in terms of both efficiency and equity. Essentially, forcing the states to put up charges and to cut services is about making ordinary Australian men and women who depend upon those services to enhance their income, to provide opportunities for their children, health services for their families and support for their ageing parents suffer. Those are the things which are under threat.

When they are under threat those ordinary Australian workers do feel worse off. They do not feel that rock solid guarantee is giving them the security they felt they were guaranteed. All that occurs before we come to terms with this bill. Wages and conditions are under threat; jobs are under threat; state taxes and charges are forced up; services are cut; and the chance of people seeing opportunities for their children, such as getting into universities, is under threat. Against all that background, we now find a $100 million tax on consumer goods—a three per cent tax on consumer goods in blatant breach of the election.

I did hear some very loyal backbench members of the government trying to say that this is not a tax. To the credit of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), he said, `It is unquestionably a tax on business.' So when it was proposed to abolish the tariff concession orders on business the minister for industry said it was a tax on business.

Now it is proposed to abolish the tariff on consumer items. It is very hard to argue that it is not a tax on consumers. The line of logic that would lead from the fact that it could be a tax on business to the fact that it is not a tax on consumers is a very tortured line of logic. If it is to be pursued it will be interesting to watch as a historical phenomenon in terms of tortured logic but not of any other contribution to the debate in this parliament.

All we have to do is look at what are the criteria that any ordinary citizen might say constitutes a tax. They would say, `I went to buy this item and, as a consequence of a decision of the government, the item was more expensive than it might otherwise have been. I had to pay not only money to the person who provided me with the good but also something extra which went to the government. The combined effect of the payment to the provider of the good and the payment to the government made the good more expensive than it otherwise would have been.'

Roughly, most people would say, `If that is the circumstance, we think we have been paying a tax.' It is money compulsorily paid to the government over and above the price of the good which you are receiving. By any reasonable measure, it is a tax. Consistent with the previous description by the minister for industry, it is a tax. So if it is a tax, how then does it not constitute a breach of that other promise about no new taxes, no increase in existing taxes? If something wasn't the subject of any government revenue raising activity before this bill, it is the subject of government revenue raising after this bill.

Whether you want to call it a new tax or whether you want to call it an increase in the existing tax is an interesting semantic point of very little practical significance to the people who are paying the bill. One way or the other, if you have made a promise of no new taxes and no increase in existing taxes, you have broken one or half of one, depending upon how you define the extension of an existing tax to new goods.

More or less we have in that balance of items which affect the rock solid guarantee a very tried and true conservative government formula: you fight unemployment by sacking people and you fight inflation by putting prices up. I have never found either a very compelling argument. In combination they have never worked anywhere in the world, but that is what we have. We have a government saying its primary obligation is about jobs—

TALK.START.PARA: —And what happened under Labor?
—700,000 jobs in three years. If you want to be measured against that as a benchmark, as well as the rock solid guarantee and as well as your promise on no new taxes—
—Order! The member for Canberra knows that his remarks should be addressed through the chair.
—But I am sure you wouldn't want those remarks addressed to you, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The member for Canberra has little choice about where he addresses the remarks.

—I am delighted to have the opportunity to say, through you, that the minister would be very pleased, I am sure, in three years time to face up to these three benchmarks, because he has added a third to the two to which I was referring. One is: how did their job creation over the last three years of their government compare to the job creation of ours? Did they create 700,000 jobs? The minister seems enthusiastic to be tested against that benchmark and we are very pleased to accommodate him.

SPEECH.PARA: The second benchmark is: how have Australian workers gone under the rock solid guarantee that no worker would be worse off under a Howard government? The third benchmark is: how does the promise stand, `No new taxes; no increase in existing taxes?'

I think on those three benchmarks they will be found wanting. But I do thank the minister for his proposal that I should add the third to the list because it is something which, over time, we will regard as important. There are other benchmarks on economic performance and performance of this government which we will put down in time and against which we will want to see the government measured.

Everybody in this place understands, or should understand, that governments need to raise revenue and that there is no popular way to do it. Increasing taxes is one way of increasing national savings to increase government revenue. There is no popular way to do it. No‐one has ever been applauded for raising a tax, for raising a charge or for any other measure for increasing revenue. At least no‐one has ever been applauded by the people who pay. You can sometimes get applauded by the people who do not have to pay if you impose the tax on someone else. I think there was a Queensland premier once upon a time who said the only good tax is a Commonwealth tax. There are many taxpayers who would say the only good tax is one somebody else has to pay. But revenue is important and this is about raising revenue.

The opposition's quibble is not with the fact that the government has an obligation to raise revenue. After all, we made similar proposals which we would have implemented if elected. Our concern is that this is a revenue measure, a significant part of which this government promised it would not take. So this is, unequivocally, a broken promise.

The member for Hotham's second reading amendment to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill has as its fundamental justification that it is a proposal to say that we in the opposition will support the revenue measures that this government put forward in the election campaign as revenue measures they would undertake and not those they did not put forward.

We are saying that there are some unpalatable aspects about this decision for which we could have won applause from business for opposing. On the application of the tariff concession orders to business, we could have done a little cheer chasing, taken the soft option and got some support in the business community for saying we were wrong, we have changed our mind and we are opposed to this.

Having spoken for the former government for three years in the Senate, often on tax and revenue matters, this government when in opposition almost inevitably took the soft option on every occasion. We are saying we will support those parts which went to the people. We work on the starting point presumption, which will not apply on every occasion, that a government is entitled to raise its revenue as it chooses and be tested by the public at the election as to the manner in which it has gone about doing it. That is a fair starting point presumption. Sometimes the taxes proposed and charges and revenue measures are so unfair that one has to qualify that position, and we will reserve the right to do that. On some other occasions, they are so fundamentally, flagrantly in breach of election promises that you cannot support them and you certainly feel free from that general starting point presumption. This is certainly just such a case—`No new taxes; no increases in existing taxes.'

Yet we have this very long list of goods, which is the best list that the opposition can come up with because the government is trying to keep hidden its list of consumer goods that are going to be taxed—thousands and thousands of goods, many of which are bought regularly by ordinary Australians for their children and for themselves for the conduct of their household and their family recreational activities.

They were not taxed before. They are not taxed now. It will make them worse off. They are worse off after the decision than they were before the decision. It is very hard to explain to the working men and women of Australia how that conforms with the contention that no worker will be worse off under a Howard government. Today they do not have to pay tax on these goods. If this bill passes they will have to do so.

So the rock solid guarantee is one benchmark against which this government will ultimately be measured. If you look at the breaches made by that already in people's wages and conditions, in their jobs, in the taxes and charges, in the services and in the opportunities for their children, you could say, `Surely after five strikes the government must be out; you must accept that this bill breaches the election commitment, that this bill breaches the rock solid guarantee that no worker will be worse off and that therefore the second reading amendment to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) moved by the member for Hotham should be supported.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Andrew—
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I draw your attention to the state of the House.

—The member for Werriwa seems to forget that I will not listen to what he has to say until I have recognised him. So, if the member for Werriwa wishes to rise and seek the call, I will happily recognise him.

—I have drawn your attention to the state of the House. I am not seeking the call. I have already spoken on this debate, you have recognised the minister and now I am drawing your attention to the state of the House.
—The member for Werriwa might like to check standing order 59. (Quorum formed)

—Tonight's debate in terms of the Labor Party's response to the government's customs legislation has been quite amazing. There has been one line, and the rest of the speakers have clearly trotted it out. While I thank them for their contribution, it has been a bit hard to warm up to it because there was really not much in it. When we look at the history of this, we find that during the federal election campaign this whacko idea to put on a tax came out of the office of the then Prime Minister.
—Are you saying you're putting on a tax?

—No, I am saying that you were putting on a tax. The reason for it was that someone had been looking at the Treasury figures and knew, as everybody else did, that those opposite were telling lies again. They knew as well as anybody else that the budget deficit was much worse than they were letting on. The former spokesman on finance said he did not know the figures but he was sure they were right. But Keating knew better. He had this new tax. He wanted to take away the concession and so forth, put five per cent on to business and completely eliminate the policy by-law.
—But we quarantined consumers.
—Simon, you in the ACTU probably do not understand much about tariffs.
—Order! The minister will address his remarks through the chair, and the member for Hotham will contain himself.

—I withdraw that. The member for Hotham, coming from the ACTU, would probably not have a great grasp of tariffs. I am surprised to see the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) is here tonight to listen to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Having inherited this problem from the Labor Party after the election, we then found a very considerable reaction from the business community to another five per cent tax on inputs. There was to be a reduction and an add-on to costs. That is what you did for them. Needless to say, the business community had a few words to the government about the inequity of this new position they were in. With our being a reasonable government, we met with various interested business groups and discussed with them the impact of the proposed Labor tax.

In response to that, we met with people across the board and we discussed how much it would have cost business in this area. It would have cost them an enormous amount of money, and I am not surprised they were upset. Individual companies would be forced to bear additional costs—between $10 million and $25 million per firm. So quite naturally we had a look at what was going on.

When they pointed out the implications of how this tax fell, we also found the enormous administrative problem that came with it. At no time in the hustle and bustle of the campaign did you bother to define what a business input was. You wanted to cover up the black hole. You had to get some money in after the election, so you did not define what a business input was and you did not define what a consumer good was. You just announced a broad decision.

When we looked at the administration of this tax, we found that the only way you could bring in the level of business inputs was to spread it across certain areas—not to consumers. As a consequence of that, we found it was necessary to look at how this new tax would be fitted. As a result of consultations with industry, the government introduced a measure which would effectively reduce the government's proposed area by 40 per cent.

We have reintroduced policy by‐laws so that national projects can continue without additional input. These are significant movements. People within the business sector were saying very early in the piece what a great job the government had done because it meant a considerable saving to business in this area.

Tonight people over there have been jumping up and down about consumer goods. I invite them to look at what this really means. The member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), during the debate, alluded to the fact that gym equipment would come under one of the special areas. There are numerous areas which have difficulties—not only mobile telephones, television sets or the various other items that no doubt you would call consumer items. If these items are used within a business context, then they are outside the game. How are you going to define in terms of administrative simplicity a television set that is brought in and used within a motel or taken home for use or something like that? As a consequence, the government's decision to move on and simplify the scheme was the most sensible outcome you could possibly imagine.

TALK.START.PARA: —You broke a promise and slugged consumers.
—There were no broken promises.

—Order! I remind the minister of his obligation to address his remarks through the chair, but I also acknowledge that he has been provoked by members on my left, particularly those on the front bench, and I would ask them to restrain themselves.

—The other proposal does not recognise the fact that special areas of taxation apply to the TCF and car industries. The proposal put forward by Labor in the election campaign would have increased costs in the car industry by up to 15 per cent. In areas of the TCF, costs could have been lifted to 37 per cent. These are the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: The other aspect of the opposition's miscalculation—obviously done in haste during the election campaign, sent by the former Prime Minister down to the member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) to give it the white stamp—was based on the assumption there would be a split of 70:30. The advice that I have is that the split between business inputs and consumer items is closer to 80:20. There is a huge difference between personal consumption and business inputs. The effect of this would be a difference in revenue of the order of $200 million.

I say to the opposition that their whole argument tonight has been one of guilt. I know that they were about causing a considerable amount of trouble to the business community. There has been absolutely no attempt to consider any business costs—the cost to business generally and to individual companies. As a consequence of that, the proposals put forward by the opposition are really quite poor.

I move now to the two‐part amendment that the opposition have put forward. It indicates that goods for personal consumption to which tariff concession orders apply should continue to enter Australia duty free. This takes them back to where they were before—the old five per cent. The coalition government has moved in and reduced that by 40 per cent. The opposition propose to make no changes in the policy by‐law. I remind the opposition that in this case they have absolutely no case because in the election campaign they proposed to abolish it completely.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Moore) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I want to correct a technical point on an answer I gave today about CD price monitoring. Inadvertently in the course of my answer, I said that I understood the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission was carrying out a formal monitoring of sound recording prices. In fact, it is carrying out an informal price monitoring. It is yet to be determined whether it will issue a report. The difference is that it is an informal, not a formal, monitoring. I wanted to correct the answer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"the Bill breaches the government's election commitment that it would not increase existing taxes or introduce new taxes and should therefore be withdrawn, redrafted and re‐presented in a form in which:
(1) goods for personal consumption to which Tariff Concession Orders apply continue to enter Australia free of duty; and
(2) no change be made to the duty rate which currently applies to Policy By‐Laws".

I will not take up too much time of the House on this because I had an opportunity to speak in the cognate debate. This amendment seeks to restore integrity to the coalition government's position of no new taxes. It ensures that this measure does not result in a GST by stealth, which is what will happen if the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 1) goes through.

The policy by-laws comprise the second string in the bow if people fail to secure a tariff concession order. Under us, the policy by‐law could still rate at zero, whereas your proposition can result in circumstances in which a three per cent rating can apply. For you to argue that this is what we proposed in relation to policy by-laws is wrong. We are seeking by way of this amendment to protect consumers yet still give to business a second opportunity to get the concession, the zero rating, through the policy by‐law rating mechanism. It is still possible under certain circumstances for them to get it in your case, but not in every case.

Your going to the election saying that you supported Labor's position is inconsistent with the second string of our amendment. Certainly what you are trying to do by way of imposing a consumption tax via this measure is completely contrary to what you said in opposition, what the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has said, and in particular what the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said, which is that there will be no increase in taxes and no new taxes under a coalition government.

This is a new tax by any definition. It is a tax on consumers. The only person who says that it is not a tax is the Treasurer. The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) is now wagging his head in the negative. He does not believe that it is a tax either. Go and consult the High Court, and talk to the National Farmers Federation and industry. Your senior minister, who has the cabinet ranking, not you, has admitted publicly that it is a tax.

Do not let us have any hogwash about there being no tax here. This is a tax. It is another example of a broken promise. You said that you would not introduce new taxes. Whilst the minister was able to roll the Treasurer in relation to the tariff concession orders, all he did was pave the way for the Premiers to do the same thing last week at the Premiers Conference. That was another example of a broken tax promise.

We are here to hold you accountable. That is why we are moving this amendment and ensuring that the proposal does not extend to consumers. It gives another level of protection to business, which you say you are keen to look after.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

PARA.TAB: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Crean's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I remind the House of the earlier ruling of the Deputy Speaker some 10 days or so ago when he pointed out that the bringing of mobile phones into the chamber could be regarded as disorderly. While not seeking in any way to embarrass the member for Canning, who is a new member and is entitled to some latitude, I remind all members that it is improper to bring a phone into the chamber. If members find themselves doing just that, they should ensure it is switched off or they may find themselves named as being disorderly.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

Mrs Johnston, Mrs Kelly and Mr Sinclair have been nominated by the Chief Govern ment Whip, and Mr Latham and Mr Leo McLeay have been nominated by the Chief Opposition Whip.

That the House:
