DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 May.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this bill is to amend the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995, Act No. 87 of 1995, the CELA Act. The CELA Act made substantial amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 relating to the diesel fuel rebate scheme, to tighten the eligibility criteria for rebates of customs and excise duty paid on purchases of diesel fuel.

In the course of the Senate debate on the CELA Act on 29 and 30 June 1995, 80 amendments were successfully moved to the CELA bill as introduced. In the course of translating those amendments into a final royal assent bill, several substantive problems with the commencement and the application and savings provisions were created which were acknowledged as contrary to the expressed intention of the Senate.

The application and savings provisions problems arose because modifications were not made to these provisions to take account of amendments made by the then opposition and Greens, in particular relating to the law as it applied to quarrying and sand mining prior to 1 July 1995. Also, consequential amendments were not made to the commencement provisions even though it was agreed that particular amendments would commence at particular times. Several minor transcription errors in the CELA Act were also identified.

On 29 August 1995, the then government introduced the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 into the Senate. The purpose of that bill was to amend the CELA Act to correct the transcription errors and the problems with the commencement and the application and savings provisions. However, the bill lapsed upon the prorogation of parliament on 29 January 1996.

With the exception of one proposed addition which I will discuss shortly, this bill is in substantially the same form as the 29 August 1995 bill and is being pursued because the need to correct the problems with the application provisions and restore the Senate's intention still exists, particularly in relation to the law applicable to mining for minerals. The CELA Act amended the definition of minerals by excluding certain materials, with effect from 1 July 1995 only. Any existing rebate applications or any matters before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or the courts that relate to the use of diesel fuel in mining operations prior to 1 July 1995 were intended to be decided in accordance with the law as it existed prior to 1 July 1995.

The CELA Act as passed did not give effect to this intention and without the corrections to the CELA Act proposed in this bill, these applications will be governed by the amended law. The principal effect of the bill is to allow those companies which had lodged applications before 1 July 1995 to have them considered on the basis of the law as it existed prior to 1 July 1995, thereby restoring the original intention of the CELA Act. Passage of this bill will make those essential technical amendments.

The bill as introduced into the other chamber on 6 May proposed to make one minor addition to the CELA Act to restore diesel fuel rebate eligibility for the extraction of limestone for use in the de‐acidification of soil in agriculture, post 1 July 1995. The government's proposal picked up the recommendation of the then opposition senators and the Australian Democrats in October and November of last year concerning this important landcare activity. The result of the restoration of this diesel fuel rebate eligibility would have been to ensure that the cost of lime to farmers would not increase.

During the committee stage of the bill in the Senate, amendments were moved by the WA Greens to remove the items of the bill which proposed to restore this category of rebate eligibility. The Senate agreed to these amendments. The Senate also agreed to amendments moved by the WA Greens to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. This amendment inserted new section 75E into that act to provide for the payment of a cash rebate in respect of activities undertaken to prevent land degradation in years when deductions cannot be made from income due to lack of assessable income.

The government did not support these amendments at the time, and remains of that view now. I foreshadow that the government will be moving amendments during the committee stage of this bill to reverse the Senate's amendments, and effectively restore the bill to its terms as originally introduced into the Senate on 6 May.

The government is proceeding in this way because it is convinced that the limestone amendment it proposed was appropriate and consistent with the other types of diesel fuel rebate eligibility. It costed the proposal and considers it capable of being controlled through the audit mechanisms which accompany the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The same cannot be said, however, of the Income Tax Assessment Act amendment for the payment of cash rebates for landcare activities which replaced the government's proposal in the other place.

BREAK.PARA: The government is advised by the Australian Taxation Office that the Income Tax Assessment Act amendment could cost around $7 million per annum. It is also important to note that the proposed amendment could distort a taxpayer's choice of the most appropriate mix of landcare activities to undertake. The amendment would allow those entitled to the cash rebate a greater benefit—100 per cent of expenditure—than primary producers who are currently claiming deductions under the Income Tax Assessment Act and who receive a tax benefit based only on their marginal tax rate.

The government is also concerned with the precedent that this type of cash rebate scheme would set with calls for similar treatment for other rural expenditure elsewhere in the taxation system being difficult to quarantine.

Finally, the scope for tax abuse in such a cash rebate proposal cannot be ignored. Providing cash rebates through the taxation system would cause significant administrative, compliance and anti‐avoidance issues. The government's opposition to the amendments proposed in the other place, for the reasons I have indicated, should not be seen as a criticism of the rationale behind the amendments.

Indeed, significant government resources are already being diverted towards landcare objectives in one form or another and many of these measures can directly benefit low income farmers. For example, many state governments provide low interest loans or direct subsidies for, or subsidise the cost of, soil conservation works. Similarly, the Commonwealth directs significant outlays into the national landcare program.

This bill, however, is one which has a different focus, the diesel fuel rebate scheme, and it is the government's view that it should remain restricted to that. I table the replacement explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) has said, the main purpose of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 is to correct some technical and drafting errors encount ered in turning the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 into an act. It clarifies that, in relation to rebate claims under the diesel fuel rebate scheme made before 1 July 1995 and court or tribunal proceedings relating to such claims, the relevant law is that applying before that date. That was also the purpose of the predecessor to this bill—that is, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The first 1995 amendment bill introduced by the Labor government implemented changes that we had proposed to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. In effect, the purpose of those changes was to tighten the eligibility criteria under the scheme. That became necessary due to extensions of eligibility over years through litigation and because of the refined definitions of agricultural and mining operations. As a consequence, we inserted a specific list of eligible activities into the legislation. It removed the eligibility for `residential purposes' and it narrowed the definition of minerals to exclude the eligibility for the extraction of certain substances because their extraction was not considered to be mining.

The second bill Labor introduced last year sought to give effect to the will of the Senate when it passed the first bill. It is Labor's intention to support this legislation because, with one exception, it is what we proposed last time. It is in fact the legislation that should have passed the Senate last year. It should have been operational over six months ago. That would have happened but for the interference by the then opposition—the now government, which is bringing it back in—and the minor parties in the Senate.

This was originally, as it should be now, just a correctional bill. However, the opposition and minor parties in the Senate used the opportunity to raise substantive issues of eligibility under the scheme, despite the obvious technical emphasis of the bill. For example, they sought to have the diesel fuel rebate for limestone extraction reinstated. We had removed this in the first 1995 amendment bill.

They also sought to oppose the removal of the offshore petroleum industry's eligibility under the scheme. They sought to oppose new requirements that certain mining activities be conducted solely for mining purposes to qualify for a rebate under the scheme. Due to the hold up in the Senate, including the reference of the bill to the Senate Economics Committee, the bill did not pass. It lapsed when the election was called earlier this year.

The government's new bill before the House now, as it was introduced into the Senate, did contain one difference to our original bill. It sought to reintroduce eligibility under the scheme for limestone extraction—but for agricultural use only, that is, the extraction of limestone for use in the de‐acidification of soil in agriculture. Obviously, this resulted from backbench pressure in the coalition ranks. It will have the effect of adding an additional $620,000 per financial year to Commonwealth outlays.

We took the view that the limestone extraction, for whatever purpose, should be excluded from eligibility under the scheme with effect from 1 July of last year. Essentially, we took the view that limestone extraction was quarrying and not mining. I think that on any sensible reading of the definition that is a legitimate position to take. Given that the rebate under the act is available under the scheme only for mining operations, we thought it appropriate to exclude it.

We moved to close off the expansion of eligibility under the scheme which had been spawned through much litigation associated with the scheme. It had taken the operation of the scheme, in our view, beyond its original intent. The current government now seek to reintroduce eligibility for extraction of agricultural use limestone on top of what we proposed but they opposed last year when we introduced it. It is our intention not to oppose the government on their bill in this House.

In the Senate, the Greens successfully moved amendments opposing the reinsertion of limestone. But their amendments went further because they also provided a new tax rebate for farmers for certain landcare activity. In the Senate, we supported the Greens but have now considered their position more closely. It is not our intention to continue to support them, mainly because their proposal was totally unfunded, it is likely to be a very costly one and tax deductibility for landcare activity is already available to farmers under tax legislation. In any event—and I reiterate what the minister said in his second reading speech—that is not what this legislation is about. This legislation is about correcting technical errors in our first 1995 bill.

The minister has indicated that the government will be moving amendments here restoring the bill to its original position, or at least not accepting that which the Senate has proposed, that is, restoring eligibility under the diesel fuel rebate scheme for extraction of agricultural use limestone and negating the Greens' other amendments. We will support the government's bill with those amendments. We do so because, apart from the limestone provision, the bill will give effect to our 1995 changes. Those changes were important and necessary to ensure that the scheme was more effectively targeted at those the government intended to benefit from it, not others who were able to argue expanded interpretation of eligibility criteria through the courts—a very expensive process in terms of the litigation as well as the impact on outlays.

It is interesting that the government is now supporting the passage of legislation to which it was vigorously opposed last year. It is also interesting that it has picked up only one of the concerns that led it to take that position in the Senate. Those concerns were raised by a number of the government backbench. They identified three areas of concern, and a number of newspaper reports have indicated that some are prepared to cross the floor if the government is not prepared to accede to the three of them. In fact, the government has indicated acceptance of only one of them. It will be interesting to see in this debate how some of those earlier critics respond to the other two areas of change that they proposed but which the government is not, in this legislation, seeking to pick up.

PARA.BREAK: I repeat: Labor is prepared to support this bill. But in supporting the bill, we wish to register our very firm opposition to the government's mooted cuts to the diesel fuel rebate scheme. The coalition went to the election promising to maintain that scheme. The National Party's policy launch on 4 Feb ruary said, in very unequivocal terms, `The diesel fuel rebate scheme will be retained.' That is a very categorical quote. There is no equivocation in that. That was a total commitment to retain the diesel fuel rebate scheme. There were no qualifications in relation to its application to miners versus farmers. It was a commitment to retain that which was in place.

SPEECH.PARA: As a coalition, they went further in the Liberal Party statement that was circulated to Australia's mining industry in the monthly mining magazine just before the last election. The question was asked:
Will the coalition retain the diesel fuel rebate scheme?
The answer:
Yes. The diesel fuel rebate is an essential element of the international competitiveness of Australia's mineral, pastoral and other industries. The coalition will retain the diesel fuel rebate.

These were unequivocal statements of support before the last election. There was no shadow of doubt by any in the mining or farming sectors that the government would retain the scheme in its current form.

Yet since the election there have been endless reports and speculation that the government is proposing to abolish that scheme, either totally or in part. We are not sure what real commitment has been given to the farming sector, but they have been a bit quieter since the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) addressed their national conference.

Certainly nothing approaching that sort of commitment has been given to the mining sector. Indeed, I am aware of the fact that the mining sector is not very happy with the non-statement by the Leader of the National Party, Tim Fischer, who was asked to reaffirm his party's support and that of the coalition to retaining the diesel fuel rebate scheme. All that Mr Fischer's response to the mining sector referred to was a preparedness to fight to retain it for farmers.

Mr Deputy Speaker Vaile, in terms of your position in the parties in this House, I am pleased to see that you are paying attention to this. I know it is of concern to you that in the National Party seats and in many of the regional seats which members of the Liberal Party represent in this House there is real concern, certainly amongst the mining sector—and there is still some concern amongst the farming sector—that this scheme will be cut into significantly despite pre-election promises to the contrary.

We have been trying to expose on a number of occasions the fact that, despite what the government said during the election campaign, it has no intention of honouring those promises. It is trying to argue that the changed financial circumstances mean that it has to take drastic steps. But I tell you this, Mr Deputy Speaker: there is one thing that counts in politics and that is honouring your word—to be prepared to go on the record not just once but on numerous occasions to restate your commitment because you know the importance of that issue to the constituencies concerned. You were not prepared to put in any qualifications during the election campaign. You were making your commitments categorically: you will retain the scheme.
Mr Prosser interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, if you reduce the diesel fuel rebate scheme, you are in effect increasing the tax burden to businesses, which is the same as breaking your promises that there will be no new taxes. So not only have you rejected the specific commitment in terms of the diesel fuel rebate but you are caught on the general application, because it has the effect of lifting the general tax burden.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope there are members on the back bench on your side who do take this issue up. It is a major concern. When I was the minister for primary industries, as well as when I kept an interest in the rural and mining sector while I held other portfolios in government, I took a very strong view that this was a measure fundamentally important to both the rural and the mining sectors.

This measure was about recognising a correction—a correction by way of an input cost associated with the conduct of business in both the farm sector and the mining sector, an input cost that should not have to be borne as a result of a general excise measure. That was the rationale for it being introduced. It always made good economic sense because it was correcting the distortion.

We never treated it from the perspective of it being purely a revenue measure. We understood the importance of it for supporting industry and, importantly, supporting those growth value adding industries that are so fundamental to our economy—industries that do not just extract the ore, do not just extract the mineral, do not just grow the produce, but have led significantly to export growth in not just the commodity but the value added product offered.

This is no small commitment. The diesel fuel rebate scheme is worth in excess of $1 billion to industry. From memory, about 57 per cent goes to the mining sector and the remainder to the agricultural sector. These are big amounts of money to struggling industries. In terms of the farm area and the marginalism associated with risk in the mining sector, these are significant decisions that determine whether or not that investment will continue to be had.

I say to members of the backbench who are participating in this debate: understand that there is no opposition on the point of the bill, but take on board the point that is being made to you in relation to our questions in the parliament, our interventions in the debates. This diesel fuel rebate should stand on its own merits but, more importantly, if you have promised the electorate to retain it, you have to honour it. It makes sense on two counts: integrity as well as good economic sense. Therefore, lobby your side to ensure that they do not, for the sake only of cutting the bottom line, rip this scheme apart.

There has to be an understanding in government as to why you cut things. You do not cut them for the sake of it. You have to understand which schemes contribute to the economic wellbeing of this nation—which contribute to our export growth, which contribute to improving the current account, which contribute to job activity and, most importantly, which contribute to the growth of regions. There is no point pretending in this place that you are committed to regional economic development and diversification if you are going to strip away the very programs that help that. It is not just the diesel fuel rebate scheme, important as that is. It is things like the export market development grants scheme and the DIFF scheme.

From day to day we see all this speculation about programs that are ready for the chop in terms of the ERC. The state premiers did not stand for the stupidity of the Treasurer (Mr Costello). I do not believe that members of the backbench forming part of the government in this parliament, significant in number as they are, should stand for that stupidity either. They should understand the effect of what is proposed in these other areas, take real notice of it and do something about it.

Since the election, as I said, we have seen countless reports of speculation that the government are going to either abolish or restrict this scheme or that it is going to apply to certain groups and not others. Time and again we have had relevant ministers in this House refuse to guarantee the future of the scheme. In fact, a few confusing signals have come out, which ought to give the backbench some heart that they can work on them. You have already had the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) rolling the Treasurer in relation to the tariff concession scheme. If you get your act together, you might be able to get someone else to roll him in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

Interestingly, the minister for industry, Mr Moore, indicated on 30 April that business and industry programs cannot be isolated from budget cuts and that some programs would have to be terminated. That was in the general sense of business programs. From a business perspective, that is laying the way open for some of these programs to be cut.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), who is touted from time to time as a future leader of the National Party and was making something of it last week in Taree in the leader's absence, actually defended the diesel fuel rebate as a non‐application of tax on production—not a subsidy. He is correct in that regard. He said that he would resist proposals to scrap the scheme. `Fuel is the lifeblood of our primary industries,' he said on the Sunday program on 17 March.

BREAK.PARA: He was setting the rationale as to why the rebate should not be cut. He was actually reinforcing the point that I just made in this debate about it being a correction of a distortion, if you like—not a subsidy—effectively neutering the application of a tax because of its general application when it comes to the important component that it plays as an input into the lifeblood of the rural and mining sector.

It is very interesting that since the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy made the statement on the Sunday program—he actually said that the diesel fuel rebate would be retained for farmers—every time he has been asked in this parliament to restate that commitment he has refused. His defence is that he is a member of the Expenditure Review Committee and that, therefore, he should not speculate on what the outcome of that committee might be in putting the budget together. The problem for the minister, though, is that he was a member of the Expenditure Review Committee when he made that statement on the Sunday program. In other words, he was prepared to go on public television and rule out the cut to the rebate—make a big name for himself in terms of the rural sector—as a member of the Expenditure Review Committee, but he will not pay this House the same courtesy.

We have all this pious comment from time to time as to how the government is going to raise the standards of this place, how it is going to make the parliament more accountable, how it is going to be more open with the people through the parliament, how the parliament is going to be supreme and not at the whim of the executive of government, but the first time the minister says it on TV he gets crunched. He comes into this place limply claiming every time he is asked the question that he cannot speculate. But he did speculate when he was a member of the Expenditure Review Committee as far back as 17 March, and he ought to have the decency to come into this House and repeat the commitment that he made, otherwise the farm sector that he represents is entitled to be concerned about what will happen to this scheme when the budget is brought down. But that is only in relation to the farm sector.

What the minister has refused to do, and what the leader of his party has also refused to do, is to reassure the mining industry, the other big recipients of this measure. They will not give the mining industry an indication as to whether they are in there fighting for them or whether they are likely to be exempted. They are just totally blank. They are prepared to take the mining industry for granted.

The Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) wants to parade around the rest of the world saying how Australia is improving international access, how we are going to improve our exports, how we are going to improve our trade position, yet he will not give the reassurance that industry needs either to make new investments or to continue with existing ones and expand them. What sort of minister is he? He seems to think that all he has to do so is masquerade on the international scene and everything will follow.

Labor understood the importance of giving substance to what it was saying on the international scene. It was prepared to back these industries, which are the lifeblood of the nation, with real support. It was prepared to go out to the regions and understand why they needed this additional assistance, and it was prepared to put resources into it.

We have a government that goes to the election saying it will retain the scheme, but at every opportunity it has to defend that position it wimps. It wimps on every count. We will wait and see what happens. But all the signals are very discouraging, certainly for the mining sector and, one would have to argue, for the farm sector as well. The government has repeatedly refused to stand by those sectors. It has repeatedly refused to honour commitments made so forcefully and unequivocally during the election campaign.

At the weekend, whilst he was not at the conference, the Leader of the National Party indicated that one commitment he makes within the budgetary process is that the National Party will fight to ensure that the diesel fuel rebate scheme for farmers is recognised. That is fair enough. That is not saying what the outcome will be. It is saying that he is prepared to fight for farmers. But why is he not prepared to fight for the miners? Why can't he include them in his commitment? This is the sort of reason why the mining sector is so concerned about its future. It is being given no encouragement whatsoever from the National Party and the Minister for Trade. The people who claim to represent these regions and sectors are being given no support. They are getting no other support from anywhere else on the government side.

The reality is that the diesel fuel rebate scheme is the largest of the government industry assistance measures. The year 1994-95, according to an Australian National Audit Office report, saw 213,000 claims approved from 110,000 applicants. The government paid $1.25 million in rebates. As I said before, 57 per cent of the value of the rebates went to the mining industry. The primary producers in agriculture, fishing and forestry received 32 per cent of them.

The value of the scheme to the mining industry cannot be overestimated. For example, it is considered that the mining sector will receive $551.2 million under the scheme in this current financial year. Excise taxes on diesel fuel are one of the mining industry's largest production inputs.

The shadow minister at the table, the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), has brought to my attention the fact that, if the diesel fuel rebate is scrapped, mining costs in Western Australia will increase by 10 per cent for many operations. Total industry costs in WA would rise by about $400 million in 1996-97. Industry profitability would be cut by around 50 per cent and, with this, industry's ability to invest in exploration and new projects. We hear members all the time talking about the importance of these industries to the future economic development of this country.

But there is no point talking rhetorically. There is no point saying you are prepared to support them with the practical programs if you are not. Inevitably, if this cut to the mining sector goes through, it will result in reduced production, in mine closures and in loss of exports and jobs. Exports of minerals and energy resources more than doubled in this country from when Labor took office in 1983 until we lost office. It went from $9.5 billion to almost $20 billion. Investment almost doubled. Industry output was up by 125 per cent.

But it is not just the mining sector that is under threat. The Grains Council of Australia, for example, estimates that removal of this rebate for agriculture will add something like $10,000 per year to the costs of the average grain farmer. I see the member for Murray (Mrs Stone) in the House. I am sure that farmers in her area will also be seriously affected. I know that she takes an interest in support schemes for those industries because she has spoken on previous occasions in this House about the traineeship scheme for dairy farmers. I congratulate her for it. I am very pleased that she is in the House. She should be in her party room asking what is happening to this scheme. Farmers in her area, which has seen a huge growth in agricultural output and value added products, will suffer. They know the importance of living on the margin. They understand fundamentally what impact any cuts to this scheme will have on them.

What the government are seeking to do by this bill is worthy. Essentially, it does what we wanted to do but what they opposed. I did want to take the opportunity in this debate to draw to the attention of the House that there is no point correcting the scheme by way of tightening it and making it more efficient if your hidden agenda is just to emasculate the scheme. There is no point pretending that you are into efficiency and making sure that only the right ones get it if you are then going to strip away the very means, resources and entitlement that many have so often relied upon in the past.

This is a demand-driven scheme, in essence. It is going to increase with expansion in these sectors. It is a necessary consequence of the growth of the agricultural and mining sectors, and it ought to be supported.

I hope that the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who is at the table, takes on board these things. I doubt that he will have much sway in the cabinet room, but I have seen the effectiveness of the government's backbench over the last couple of weeks in this parliament. I urge them to get behind this and reassure the mining and agricultural sectors in this country that they will honour their electoral promise and retain the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin by reminding the previous speaker, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), that we are not debating the emasculation of the diesel rebate scheme or any other particularly skulduggerous attempts to remove it in some way; rather, we are talking about enhancing the effectiveness of the scheme for the benefit of the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: This government was voted into power largely on the rural people's concern and great distress about the way the previous government's business costs rose over the last 13 years so that business found it very difficult to compete internationally. Over the last 13 years there were rising rates of rural youth suicide. In fact, over the last five years those rates of rural youth suicide have doubled. So, far from the previous government enjoying a sense of enormous fellowship and joy when it came to the rural sector, if those in opposition got out there they would find that the rural sector is now enjoying the fact that there is a government that appreciates the costs of doing business and is doing all it can to assist primary industries and mining to be world competitive.

This amendment is all about making sure that farmers can afford to apply lime as an agricultural additive to their land. We have an incredible history in Australia of managing to produce, in particular, crops and pasture from country which is largely not terribly fertile, especially when compared with our competitors in Europe or the USA.

Up to the turn of the century and a little beyond, farmers were trying very hard to compete on international markets, but with very low productivity levels. They tried, therefore, to clear more land to produce crops over a number of years—until the invention of superphosphate. Superphosphate was a miracle for these croppers and pastoralists. When they worked out their equipment so they could spread the superphosphate along with the seed, they found their productivity increasing 10 per cent and more per annum for a number of years.

It meant that we produced a surplus of good quality grain, for example, that helped us to establish ourselves on the international markets as a reliable supplier of high quality cereal. Superphosphate meant that we could start to increase our dairy production to a point where we went well beyond our domestic needs. Again, we could start to develop our processing sector and put our processed product onto international markets.

So superphosphate was a miracle substance. It was not all that expensive because the governments of the day supported farmers by providing subsidies for applying that material. It was used in such a way that some of it entered into the watertables and the nutrient levels went up there and then it flowed into our streams. But that was not the biggest problem. Over a number of years, despite the ongoing application of the superphosphate, it was noticed that fertility levels were again declining. We discovered that we had what we now call soil acidification—a result of long-term use of superphosphate.

As with all things affecting Australia, we take problems in agriculture very seriously. After a period of research it was found that one of the most successful ways to overcome soil acidity was the application of agricultural lime, or calcium carbonate. The trouble with calcium carbonate is that you have to use it in fairly heavy doses—something like four tonnes per hectare—you need to use it over a number of years because it takes a fair time to be watered and absorbed into the soil process, and it costs about $50 per tonne.

As I said, you have to repeat the applications for quite a number of years. Soil fertility does not very rapidly improve but it does over time. Improvement is steady. To ask a farmer who is presently experiencing a downturn in trade to put something worth $50 per tonne onto his property is a big ask.

Because it supports those who are mining the lime product and because they are then able to pass on the saving to the primary producer, this diesel fuel rebate is a very substantial measure assisting the primary producer to restore fertility to the country. It also means that over time the effects of superphosphate are less detrimental. As has been said, superphosphates can end up in our streams, leading to blue‐green algae outbreaks and the other results of nutrient laden waters getting into our major waterways. Fortunately also, the lime can be quarried throughout large areas of the country with fairly low technology.

The amendment to this bill gives us the ability to put back into the system access to calcium carbonate, or agricultural lime, which we believe will be of enormous benefit. In my electorate we produce something like $1.5 billion worth of export product. That product comes from agricultural land all of which over many years has used superphosphate. We also grow cereals. The cost of the diesel rebate for one year—which, as the previous speaker referred to, is something in the order of $2 billion—is not much more than the value of the export production of my electorate. When we look at it in those terms, the value of this diesel rebate overall is an extraordinarily good investment in our agricultural output.

Lime is a natural substance—it is calcium carbonate. When we export products with a clean, green label we are in no way interfering with the concept that our primary production is without chemicals or artificial additives that could be seen to be detrimental, particularly to our Asian food markets. Furthermore, the diesel fuel rebate in no way could be challenged as being GATT inconsistent. It is not a subsidy; we are simply not applying an excise.

So in every way you care to look at this particular amendment, as our previous speaker said, there is a very important outcome. It is an amendment that all of us in this House could readily agree to. It is of great benefit to the environment because agriculture can be sustained as long as we maintain fertility and overcome the major problem of soil acidity.

Our primary producers often have to compete against corrupt markets, in the sense of having to compete against subsidised product. Costs of production in Australia are extraordinarily high. Our farmers need all the help they can get. In my electorate, the dairy farmers are competing against New Zealand to earn the title of the world's most cost efficient dairy producers. The availability of agricultural lime is of enormous value and benefit, so I very strongly support the previous speaker and, of course, my government in endorsing this amendment which will make agricultural lime a part of the diesel rebate scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, in addressing this very important debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996, let me just commence by saying a couple of things. Firstly, I do not support the breaking of election promises. Secondly, I do not support the proposition that two wrongs make a right.

SPEECH.PARA: Having put those two positions in place, let me comment on some of the `pontificating' of the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) in lecturing us on breaking promises—breaking promises, and then starting to talk about fuel tax! I have a reasonably long memory. I reckon that I went around Australia telling people that we had a tax proposal in Fightback that would remove fuel tax but impose a 15 per cent GST. I can remember the member for Hotham, joining with his then Prime Minister and others, saying, `We can do all of that; we can give you personal tax cuts, we can give you everything you want, and we don't intend to raise any taxes at all.' What was the result of that on their re-election? They put 6c a litre on the price of fuel.

Mr Deputy Speaker, when I was putting this proposition around Australia, I painted a little picture. The picture was of the then Prime Minister, Paul Keating, being kidnapped by the KGB as a child and taken over to Russia for the purpose of being brainwashed and sent back to Australia to become a politician and wreck the Australian economy. I was able to point out that, as time went by, the trip was proved not to be necessary. The reality of it all was that, when they gave him his book of instructions to come back to Australia, on the front page they would have written in thick black texta `tax transport'. Why? Because Australia is just so dependent on it.

BREAK.PARA: The previous speaker, the member for Murray (Mrs Stone), was at pains to point out the huge cost of transporting limestone, a product that has almost no value at all as it sits in a quarry somewhere. It is worth only a few dollars a tonne. By the time it is delivered to the property that needs it the freight cost can be 10 times the value of the product in the back of the truck. That freight cost is directly proportionate to the amount of tax we apply to distillate. When the then Keating government, the opposition as it is now, added 6c a litre to the cost of fuel, the effects flowed through the entire economy. It put up the cost of groceries in the supermarket; it put up everybody's operating costs.

I welcome the fact that we have this legislation before us today. This is legislation which originally was aimed at making sure that certain areas of operation liable for fuel excise tax but avoiding it be brought to account. The original legislation, which was passed by the previous government, prevented some loopholes which a former tax avoidance industry was trying to establish. But here we are today making sure that such an essential product as lime, so ably referred to by the previous speaker, will not carry the burden of a fuel tax of 36c a litre—and that is up, as I recollect, from 6c a litre when we lost office back in 1983.

Nevertheless, having said that, we recognise the hypocrisy of these statements—this hand wringing, `Keep your promises.' John Dawkins, the poor old Treasurer who had to implement this thing, left the parliament because he was so ashamed. He had to go before the people and promise a tax regime like `l-a-w and no additional taxes' and then had to present his first and only budget which broke all those promises. So we do not want to hear any more about broken promises from the other side; it is just embarrassing. The reality is that we on this side have to keep our promises, and there is nothing more important to consider than the diesel rebate scheme.

I have been around this parliament long enough to remember its history. In fact, when I first entered the parliament we had a very simple system of tax exemption for all off‐road use of distillate. It was as simple as that. The entitlement was established by the issuing of a number which was quoted on purchase and which in fact applies today in the sales tax system. However—and I do admit it to be true—certain fuel agents, having obtained the number of a particular eligible client, maybe a farmer, started filling up trucks of other ineligible operators and then simply writing in the number that applied to one of their eligible clients.

It was Doug Anthony who, having had this drawn to his attention by the department, introduced the current rebate system. To that point, off‐road distillate attracted no tax. It was not a revenue item; it was not an expenditure item. It just did not exist. I corresponded with Doug at the time, saying I thought there were other administrative alternatives. I argued for a plastic card which could be held at the point of delivery and franked onto the delivery documentation to establish the exemption right of people. It would not be available back at the depot to be used for some truckie. I thought that was administratively better.

But suddenly, 10, 12 or 15 years later, from the moment we established the rebate scheme, which simply said that everybody pays the tax and those eligible get a rebate, we created a revenue item and an expenditure item. Of course, the expenditure item is now referred to by the bureaucracy as an outlay of government. It was never money to which we were entitled; it was never money that we took. We did it for administrative reasons. I felt it was a very complex and unnecessary system. But the bureaucrats knew where they were heading.

I express my concern that in defence of the sorts of cuts that they should take in terms of their administration of our nation, they are saying, `There are other ways.' I do not doubt for a minute that they are coming to my senior colleagues and saying, `You don't need to take my job away, mate. We've got this expenditure item of $1.2 billion and you're committed to cutting expenditure. It's not a tax. The fact that you add 36c a litre to the operating expenses of farmers, fishermen or miners—don't you worry about that. My job will be secure and you can save up to $1.2 billion.'

I have got to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, my view is this: it is not an expenditure cut, if such a decision were taken. I am confident that we will stand by that promise, but if it were taken—and this is a message to the bureaucracy who I know promote these sorts of ideas—it would have a substantial effect on various sectors of our business community. It is the worst form of tax. As I said, it would have been the first one which the KGB would recommend for increase in the context of Australia, with its diversified and distant resource developments, spread all over the place.

It is a huge cost. It must be recognised for what it is. I think the case has been put for farmers. They have a huge cost in cropping today. To be efficient within world markets, they use extremely large equipment. They no longer use horses; they no longer use little equipment. Manpower has been replaced by huge horsepower and large fuel consumption. They should not have to pay that when everything they sell is subject to international competition—often corrupted international competition.

Let us quickly move to the fishing industry. I have a constituent who sends three trawlers from the town of Geraldton to the Gulf of Carpentaria every year. The cheque he writes to fuel up those three trawlers, to get them there to fish for a week or so, is $600,000. If you were to add the 36c a litre to which the opposition raised the diesel fuel tax, you would then see his outlay go to $1.2 million, in order to position his boats and get them fishing for a product. Once, you could sell prawns or shrimps anywhere in the world. Today, there is huge competition from fish farming in Asia. They are no longer in a market where you name the price and someone takes the product. They are now in a market where there is intense price competition and they are only hanging in there by marketing their product as being fresh and from the sea, instead of raised in a mud hole.

We then move to mining. Mining has been transformed. The fundamentals of mining today are no longer burrowing through the earth in narrow tunnels and finding the very high‐grade ores. We have gone back into all of those old workings; today we open‐cut them. That is achieved by shifting huge volumes of earth at very low percentage mineralisation. We have new technology that deals with that.

Whereas the use of diesel fuel was minimal in many mining establishments, today it is one of their principal costs because they are shifting all this dirt—huge quantities. Everything is running around on rubber tyres. I was told the other day—and I will stand corrected if I am wrong—that the major fuel agent in Kalgoorlie now distributes more distillate than is consumed in the whole state of Victoria. I would not be surprised. It is massive—low grade, big volumes and very profitable for the nation. We see it in the massive rise in gold production and exports, paying off that international debt.

When one talks about minerals, the most commonly heard phrase that is greatly misunderstood in the community is `recoverable reserves'. Recoverable reserves are not what someone has established as being the mineral in the ground. It is the amount of mineral you can get out at present day prices and present day costs at a profit. The minute, for instance, someone was to impose that fuel excise tax on the mining industry, every mine in Australia would have to downgrade their recoverable reserves. Salomon Brothers would be on the phone possibly downgrading Australia's credit rating because our assets had been diminished. Those that have a prospectus in the marketplace to start up a new mining venture would have to recall it and rewrite that component. Investors would, in many cases, see that. Every mine in Australia would have its life reduced by the imposition of that tax. These are the reasons why I know we are not going to do it. We have made a promise and we will keep it. Furthermore, it has got to be understood what a negative situation it would be.

There is an argument of simple arithmetic. If you add 36c a litre, which would be a doubling in normal terms of the fuel cost of any business venture, and particularly mining, it is obviously going to have an effect on the bottom line—the taxable profit. So the first thing government would forgo would be the 30c in the dollar company tax. Add to that whatever other rationalisation they attempted to achieve by sacking workers and everything and you would lose some PAYE tax. You would be lucky to recover 50c in the dollar anyway. These are the figures that bureaucrats do not always provide when they come up with these smart ideas.

I stand by our policy. Our policy was that we would not impose or change the arrangements of the diesel fuel rebate. It should not be changed for farmers, fishermen, foresters and miners. We show our credentials in this legislation by making sure that, although it might be perceived as an industry where you mine limestone for the purposes of building blocks, household construction or the creation of cement, there is a component that goes in very large quantities to rural activity. It is ridiculous to add to that cost.

The member for Murray went so far as to point out the huge quantities required. When you are talking about 5,000 acres of land and three or four tonnes to the acre, an extra dollar a tonne is huge money. That is the sort of cost that people in my electorate are confronted with. They also do that with other sites of minerals of that nature. It is an environmentally good practice. It should never be forgotten that, when you apply these sorts of minerals and regenerate soil and its productivity, the soil is not deteriorating; it is not being abandoned. It is as positive a move as you can make.

The other product I was thinking of in that regard—it is now getting huge usage in my electorate—is gypsum. We recently had an argument about accessing a gypsum deposit because it had a few trees on it. My argument was that we are going to save a lot more soil out there than the little we are going to lose here. Again, we have to have a commonsense approach in some of those circumstances.

I welcome this legislation and I welcome the government's accommodation of the arguments that were put in the past parliament and in this one that these areas of taxation should not be applied to business inputs. In fact, it challenges the entire Australian tax system. I say to you, sir—I know that you are a very rational man; a person with whom I had a good friendship when we were overseas on one occasion—that it is time that the Australian parliament asked itself if the Australian tax system is adequate for Australians' needs. Is it servicing our business community? Is it giving state and other governments the opportunity to give decent services to those in need: poor people? My answer to that question is that it does not. But I can give you another answer: until this parliament—both sides of it—agrees that we must make a change, it will never occur.

I was disappointed to hear someone who has the intelligence rating that the one‐time Senate leader is supposed to have brought to this House asking that silly question today: will you guarantee this parliament you will not have a GST until the year 3000? How stupid can you get? That is the greatest description I can give. I will forgive them some of their fibs and their broken promises, but do not come to this place being stupid. The question that should be coming from you people—I say this with respect—is, `Where can we get together on some of these important issues?' Where is the middle ground? Why can't we talk about tax in a sensible way rather than all getting around the corner and saying, `We'll fix them up. We'll start another fear campaign. Get Singleton in. Fifteen per cent.'

It is really silly when you see people wanting for money. We have got ACOSS joining with ACCI now—that is a pretty good quinella—and what are they saying? `For goodness sake, look at your tax base.' We should not be calling the premiers over once a year and saying, `Put your hat out and we'll tell you what you get.' We should give them, firstly, the right and, secondly, the responsibility to raise some money in their own right and be answerable. You could do the same with local government. I have been there; I know how. But we will never do it while one side—whichever it is—decides that the politics are worth more than national responsibility.

Think about it. Go to your boss and say to him, `You could be a statesman. You really and truly could. You could go down in history as a leader who said, "Australia has a problem and I am going to join with the government to try to fix it."' Do not think that is unique. Just think to yourself: how many shares would we have sold in the Commonwealth Bank by now if we had wanted to be mischievous in opposition? We would have had your mob running for cover. We would have only had to say that we were agin it and there would have been riots in caucus. We were the first to raise the issue of privatisation and when it came down to tintacks and you wanted to do it we did not pull out all your old stories.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about airports?

—I will tell you something about airports. Why don't we have some commonsense and a bipartisan approach on them? It is fundamental that Sydney needs a new airport, and the best one should be the one that is built. I am not telling you which one it is—I do not know. I am a Western Australian and our airport is OK. The reality is that they are the issues. If you went for a GST and wanted to impose it at 11c and we wanted it imposed at 12c, I am quite relaxed about that. That is the sort of thing that you can argue in an election. But it is about time some of the fundamentals were addressed. The reality is that if we did it people might remember us and put our position somewhere above that of a second‐hand car salesman.

BREAK.PARA: The problem is that we play politics at times to the damage of the national interest. I invite your party to think about that. I do not mind where the middle ground is, but it has got to be better than what we have got now. Be it diesel fuel taxes, payroll taxes or all these issues, they are extremely bad for the national economy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks, Noel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, particularly in relation to restoring the diesel fuel rebate eligibility for the extraction of limestone for use in the de‐acidification of soil in agriculture. The introduction of this bill has been necessary to clean up a mess created by the Labor government—that is, the problems and anomalies in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amend ment Act 1995 following Labor's failure to implement amendments made by the Senate. I congratulate the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) on his statesman‐like comments in relation to the Australian taxation system.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual additional cost of restoring the diesel fuel rebate eligibility for the extraction of limestone is about $620,000, which, in terms of lost revenue, is negligible when compared with the substantial benefits that would flow from increased agricultural production after the introduction of limestone to reduce soil acidity. I notice that the honourable member for Page (Mr Causley) is in the House at the moment. He was once the minister for agriculture in New South Wales. He would well know the value of adding lime to soil. It is imperative that the government provide incentives to the limestone quarrying industry to extract limestone as economically as possible in order to make its use economically viable and to encourage farmers to use the product in greater quantities as a remedial strategy in the fight against acidity.

The total area of acid soils in Australia, defined as soils with a pH of less than 4.8, is about 29 million hectares, of which some 24 million hectares are used for agriculture. New South Wales, with about 9.5 million hectares of acid soils, is most affected, followed by Victoria—and I notice the honourable member for Murray (Mrs Stone) had a lot to say about this—Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania. These statistics are a stark indication of the full extent of the soil acidity problem and the ongoing need for it to be addressed by the introduction of limestone to the farming cycle.

Accurate diagnosis of acid soil infertility, coupled with sound advice on the need for lime and other fertilisers, is critical if farmers are to obtain the productivity gains needed to offset their costs. Using lime to raise the pH in our fine soils to a pH of around six is essential for optimum plant growth and an important tool in countering the negative impact of acid soils on future farm productivity and profitability.

The process of acidification is a natural one with soils tending to become more acid over a period of time. Australian farmers have started with fairly acid soils and, in a bid for higher productivity through the use of nitrogen fixing legumes and nitrogenous fertilisers, farming practices have hastened this process.

Farmers with a soil acidity problem basically have two choices to maintain productivity. The choice is between having a fairly high productive system and taking lime as an extra cost or taking a low intensive, low yielding system and using no lime, but their income will be reduced because of this. Farmers wanting to maintain the productivity of their land must use lime. The higher the system in terms of yields and inputs, the more lime is needed to maintain an adequate pH level. Lucerne growers, for example, have to look at liming as part of their regular costs because irrigation and high productivity tend to acidify the soil extremely quickly. The higher the returns the more it will pay to lime.

One of the major problems with soil acidification is that the more the pH is allowed to drop the higher the cost will be to rectify the problem. If the problem is allowed to develop to the extent that the subsoil is affected, there is no solution. Once the subsoil goes acid, only the most acid tolerant plants such as oats and sub‐clovers can be grown. Acidification of the subsoil is a form of permanent degradation, leaving a massive problem not only for today's farmers but also for future farmers and the environment.

The big danger is that if farmers with soil acidity and aluminium or manganese problems do not start to use lime the soil will continue to acidify, which means that they will have to put on more lime and it will cost more money to increase the pH level. Soil acidity is an increasingly serious problem affecting a large part of the south‐west slopes of New South Wales, parts of which are in my electorate of Riverina.

In response to this problem the New South Wales Department of Mineral Resources has been actively undertaking a campaign aimed at identifying and assessing potential sources of agricultural limestone in the southern part of the state. This campaign has been in recognition of the need to develop new sources close to areas affected by acidity in order to substantially reduce the cost to farmers because of the lower transport cost component, and thereby encouraging greater use of limestone.

In addition to boosting sustainable agricultural productivity, winning the fight against increasing soil acidity has important ramifications for the environment. Poorer plant growth due to acid soils means less ground cover and the result is increased soil erosion which seriously damages the environment. Combating soil degradation is vital and is an important element of the coalition government's commitment to integrating the joint interests of sustainable development, especially in primary industries, and environmental protection.

Rural industries will be among the main beneficiaries from new environmental initiatives taken by the government to comprehensively tackle the scale of the environmental crisis facing Australia. The environmental crisis we face as a nation has become increasingly stark—and increasingly apparent to all Australians.

Our land and water resources have been degraded over large areas of our continent and the unfortunate result is that the lifeblood of our unique environment is being drained and its productive potential over the long term is being diminished.

The problems are real and they are diverse, with soil acidity a prime concern in a crisis which threatens not only our unique natural and resource assets but also our quality of life, our export potential and the jobs and opportunities for future generations of Australians.

The real concern of Australians about our environment calls for real action that tackles the problems we face head on. The government has initiated that action by promising to establish a historic $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust of Australia, which will be devoted to protecting and rehabilitating the Australian environment.

It will be a trust in perpetuity, held on behalf of all Australians, to enhance the quality of the environment in which they live. The overriding purpose is to ensure a cleaner, greener and more sustainably productive Australia into the next century.

The Australian Democrats, by their continued obstructionist tactics to block the sale of one‐third of Telstra, which will fund the $1 billion Natural Heritage Trust, will stand condemned by the Australian community if the government is unable to deliver on the huge mandate given to the implementation of the environmental package on 2 March.

Increased funding for environmental protection projects could result in the allocation of additional financial resources to enable more research into acid soils and their treatment to prevent further degradation.

The Charles Sturt University at Wagga Wagga in my electorate has been involved in ongoing research into soil acidity and Professor Jim Pratley, Dean of the Science and Agriculture Faculty, deserves special praise for the vital work both he and his team are undertaking in addressing this problem. During a recent visit to the university I saw some of the work they have been doing. It also promotes the importance of regional universities and the need to ensure that funding to those universities is kept at the maximum level possible.

The government, by restoring the diesel fuel rebate eligibility for limestone quarrying operations, has recognised the importance of the mining industry's contribution to the Australian economy. This contribution must be at the forefront of any debate on the future of the diesel fuel rebate and its application to the broader mining industry.

It must be emphasised the diesel fuel rebate scheme is not a subsidy—and we have already heard the member for O'Connor make that statement. It is a legitimate recognition of the fact that the mining and agricultural industries operate in remote areas, off‐road, and is an exemption from an Australian duty to ensure our exporters compete on a level playing field.

Australian miners typically pay 27 or 28c per litre for diesel. This would increase to about 58c per litre if the rebate were abolished. The mining industry's competitors in countries like Indonesia or Chile pay only 20 or 24c per litre.

BREAK.PARA: Both the mining and agricultural industries are the mainstay of the Australian economy and their export capabilities and earning power must be protected in the national interest. In many cases, the mining industry is a price taker and not a price maker, so any new cost imposts simply reduce the industry's global competitiveness and the end result is a detrimental impact on the Australian economy.

A case in point is the Normandy group, one of Australia's largest miners and its biggest gold miner, producing from its mines nearly 20 per cent of the nation's gold production. This company also employs about 5,000 people. The group's mines consume some 100 million litres of diesel fuel per annum and removal of the current exemption from diesel fuel excise would result in an additional direct cost of $30 million per annum. Nearly 100 per cent of mineral production is exported into markets where the price is dictated by global market forces and the seller is unable to pass on cost increases.

It must never be forgotten that the mining industry is the single most important industry contributor to the Australian economy, representing nearly 40 per cent of Australia's total exports and operating in a world market where there are no safety nets. In 1993-94, in current price terms, mining gross product totalled $16.5 billion or 3.9 per cent of total GDP. This compares with 3.1 per cent in the rural sector, including farming, forestry and fishing; 14.5 per cent in manufacturing; and 78.5 per cent for all other industries. The removal of the diesel fuel rebate scheme as it applies to the mining industry would result in a cost impost of $700 million.

PARA.BREAK: Because of the importance of resources to Australia's export trade, policies or actions which damage the international competitiveness of Australia's resource sector can have serious adverse implications for Australia's balance of payments. Increased costs mean higher cut-off grades and, as a result, minerals which at current fuel costs are economic to mine will become uneconomic and the impact will be disastrous in terms of closures of marginal mines, especially those small to medium sized mines which are already suffer ing under different policies of the previous government which we will have to overcome. Job losses will emanate from that, including the impact of a mining employment multiplier of over four to one, reduced export revenue, lower company profits depressing the share market and a reduction in government revenues via corporate and personal income taxes.

BREAK.PARA: We must recognise that fuel substitution will not rectify the situation for mining companies. Most mines are in remote areas and are remote from electricity grids and gas pipelines. So it would be impossible to substitute alternative fuels for diesel even where technically possible.

As I have already stated, almost 100 per cent of mine production is exported. In 1994-95 minerals and energy exports totalled $29.8 billion, representing 50 per cent of merchandise exports—goods only—and 40 per cent of total exports in goods and services. The strong performance of the minerals industry has had important positive implications for regional economies, such as direct employment and the establishment of supporting industries such as geophysical analysis and exploration services. It has also had positive implications for power generation, steel production, ports, shipping and transport services.

The mining and basic metal products industries are major investors in the Australian economy. In 1993-94 capital investments—including plant, equipment and buildings—totalled $7.1 billion, which represents 26 per cent of capital investment by all industries. These statistics serve to graphically highlight the mining industry's significant contribution to the national economy and bring into sharp focus the need for government to pursue policies which protect the viability and future of Australia's largest exporter.

PARA.BREAK: Finally, may I say how important it is to maintain the diesel fuel rebate to the farming and mining sectors and to the fishing and forestry industries to enable them to continue to produce export earnings for Australia. Certainly this bill recognises the importance of one area of mining or quarrying, but iron ically this area is linked to the farming industry. I certainly support the maintenance of the diesel fuel rebate for limestone quarrying operations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marek, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The persistent speculation that the federal government will or will not discontinue or heavily modify the current diesel fuel rebate system needs to be addressed immediately, owing to the continuing uncertainty in the mining, primary producing and fishing sectors. I therefore take great pleasure in having the opportunity to talk on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) as this topic will have strong ramifications to Australia's economic wellbeing, pending the final outcomes. Therefore, as the legislation passes through the Senate, I urge the Senate to take on board the proposed changes to the legislation and to expedite them as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Any piece of legislation has the ability to be refined. It is considered that this government can improve the existing fuel rebate system through the extensive consultation that has been undertaken in an effort to provide a better system. The wealth producing sector of Australia is sick and tired of successive governments whittling away their hard won gains in productivity. It is virtually impossible to win a game where the goalposts and the rules consistently change against them. We cannot afford for that to happen. The mining sector and the farming sector provide the largest percentage of our export earnings. Reduce this and we will continue to have a serious economic problem in this country for a long time to come.

If the Senate refrains from its continual obstructive debate and works with this government to implement its amendments and changes that will refine the diesel fuel rebate system, I am confident that mining and primary producing people will be able to implement their future plans. With this country's currency rising daily and primary produce and commodity prices taking a downward turn, most of these businesses are struggling to make a decent profit.

If those businesses do manage to survive under the current poor economic and climatic conditions, they certainly will be restructuring their commitment and their work force, which will have disastrous consequences on this government's intention to get the nation back working and to reduce the deficit. The crippling of primary production by increased costs is not the way to rein in the country's foreign debt problem. Rural people are looking for assurances that this federal government values primary industry and its role in the future prosperity of Australia.

There are a considerable number of mining industries operating in my electorate of Capricornia covering such sectors as coal, gold, minerals and gemstones. Many cost factors are associated with these industries—transport and electricity generation being two of the major contributors to these costs. Besides the added cost to local business, the flow-on effects of any loss of business will seriously affect all Central Queensland regions. Unemployment will increase to tragic proportions as in all these regions there is no alternative employment opportunities. It will result in the destruction of whole communities and towns in Central Queensland.

The cost of the rebate has risen due to fuel price increases—not usage. Diesel fuel excise rates have increased from 10.437c per litre in 1986 to 34.183c per litre today. This is a 228 per cent increase, whereas the number of litres on which mining has been paid has grown less than 100 per cent over the same period. Just in case the House has forgotten, the most recent review of diesel excise rebate policy by the Industry Commission recommended that the rebate for mining activities be extended—not reduced.

In relation to the mining issue, I recently travelled to meet with concerned constituents at gem fields on the border of my electorate adjoining the division of Maranoa. They provided extensive evidence to prove that the loss of the diesel fuel rebate in their industry would mean an end to an industry that not only employs many people but also promotes tourism and brings great wealth to the gem fields and the Emerald community.

The farming industry in my electorate has been suffering from drought for years. It has also suffered from high interest rates, falling prices and a decline in demand. This week it was declared that the Fairbairn Dam, located just south of Emerald, will cease as at 30 June the allocation of water to primary producers. This specifically extends to the grain and cotton industry.

At present, the sale of a bale of cotton is $150 less than the cost of production. This is a clear indication that these primary producers are struggling, and the loss of the diesel fuel rebate will send these people to the wall and effectively destroy an industry that has already been marred by drought. To them, a reduction in the diesel fuel rebate will be like reducing the Australian dollar to 50c. It will be a knife in their back—just when they thought the worst was over after they elected a coalition government and got rid of the free wheeling, free spending unaccountable Keating government.

Any attempt to remove the diesel fuel rebate scheme will be counterproductive for the economy and will have a profound effect on the community standard of living and quality of life. Removal of the rebate will be totally opposite to the government's stated objectives of value adding for export and making Australia's industry more competitive and efficient on the world stage.

The points I have made here tonight in relation to the diesel fuel rebate scheme are imperative to Australia's economic future and development. I do not intend to build a speech that provides extensive waffle for I think I have made my point on this topic already.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 1.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 4, page 3 (line 22), after "limestone", insert "(other than agricultural use limestone)".
