PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Prosser)—by leave—read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: WORKPLACE RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr McMullan moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Bill should not be proceeded with, for the following reasons:
(1) it breaches the Prime Minister's "rock solid guarantee" that no‐one will be worse off;
(2) it opens the door to cutting youth wages and introducing a $3.00 per hour youth wage;
(3) it removes the fairness which is entrenched in the existing industrial relations system;
(4) it does not recognise the legitimacy and desirability of employees organising and bargaining collectively;
(5) it proceeds from a fundamentally flawed assumption that the parties to the employment relationship have equal bargaining power;
(6) it severely restricts the central role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the industrial relations system;
(7) it undermines the award system as the dynamic framework for the protection and advancement of wages and conditions;
(8) it removes workplace and enterprise bargaining from the protections of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission;
(9) it will aggravate problems of inequality for women, young people and those most vulnerable in the labour market;
(10) it fails to provide a core framework for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes;
(11) it emphasises the punishment of industrial action rather than its resolution; and
(12) it fails to ensure that Australia's labour standards meet our international obligations."

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur, Stewart, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is a historic occasion in the history of Australian industrial relations. The Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill put forward by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) and strongly supported by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) represents a shift from the 100‐year‐old culture of centralised wage fixing and addresses Australia's arthritic labour market structures, dominated by unions and arbitral tribunals resembling the craft based guilds of medieval England.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill shifts the focus away from the adversarial culture of `them and us' which has dominated Australian industrial relations. That culture had its manifestation in the quasi‐ judicial form of the Arbitration Commission and the principles laid down by Justice Higgins in the infamous Harvester judgment of 1907. It was 200 years ago that Adam Smith, in his seminal work, The Wealth of Nations, said:
The demand for those who live by wages naturally increases with the increase of national wealth, and cannot possibly increase without it.
At the turn of the century, Australians were on average the richest people in the world, but today our GDP per capita ranks 15th in the OECD.
We have been overtaken by the first of the Asian tigers, Hong Kong and Singapore, on the international league table of average income. Again, the words of Adam Smith ring true for Australia:
Though the wealth of the country should be very great, yet if it has been long stationary, we must not expect to find the wages of labour very high in it.

A recent article by Mr Michael Warby in the Australian Financial Review reported how one prominent Hong Kong tailor has asserted that he can now get his suits cheaper in Brisbane than he can in Hong Kong, once regarded as the sweat shop of Asia. The article states:
For almost 100 years, Australians have had a vast edifice of arbitration—a regulatory system of Byzantine complexity—to protect us from exploitation.
Meanwhile, Hong Kong operates with no minimum wage or unfair dismissal laws.
The result? Australia has 9% unemployment. Hong Kong is now confronting the scandal of 3% unemployment and Hong Kong is contracting work out to cheap Australian labour.

This is the backdrop to the debate on the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. For a century, Australia's industrial relations system ignored the words of Adam Smith, denying the reality of free market forces and pretending that high incomes could be maintained by judicial decree rather than productivity and economic growth.

The focus of this bill is on altering the culture of workplace relations so that decisions are made increasingly at the enterprise level and due regard is given to productivity and workplace realities. While the traditional centralist award system is based on dispute between an employee and an employer, the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Bill emphasises cooperation and agreement for mutual benefit. This is a cultural shift which will ensure Australia's place in the competitive international economy of the 21st century.

This sea change had its early beginnings in the backbench committee of the coalition opposition in 1986. In this context, I place on the public record the great contribution to the public debate by the honourable member for Barker, the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan). Events like the Dollar Sweets case, Robe River and the landmark Mudginberri dispute drew attention to the reality that unbridled union power was alive and well. But there were other positive forces, such as the member for Barker and his ally Paul Houlihan, Peter Costello, the Treasurer, and Charles Copeman, who sought to find a better industrial relations system.

The backbench industrial relations committee, which I had the honour of chairing during these early debates, developed the early proposals for enterprise bargaining. For his part, John Howard lent his formidable talents to arguing and supporting the case. He has remained one of the strongest advocates for change to the system on the Australian political scene. The ongoing debate was ably assisted by the former shadow minister, the Hon. Neil Brown QC, and the current Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith). In the end, the Hawke government changed its longstanding opposition to enterprise bargaining, albeit a little too late.

Today I feel personally very proud that those strenuous and hard‐fought debates have finally found a more complete manifestation. Big business leaders said it could never be done, living as they did in a cosy system where all workers were paid according to the award no matter what their attitudes, skills and capacities. Today, in 1996, the system of industrial relations remains highly centralised, heavily regulated and dominated by the `Industrial relations club', first talked about by Gerard Henderson in his 1983 Quadrant article.

BREAK.PARA: Awards remain complex and detailed, leaving little scope for enterprises to agree on specific terms and conditions of employment. Enterprise agreements must be approved by the IRC and can be rejected even when a consensus of employees supports the agreement. Union structure is tightly regulated, giving large established unions monopoly rights over workers due to the `conveniently belong' rule. The monopoly position of the union movement is entrenched by preference clauses, which are still prescribed in several awards, giving union members preference in employment over non‐union workers. Laws on unfair dismissals are prescriptive and technical, providing a strong disincentive to small employers to hire new staff.

This centralised and regulated industrial relations system had its advent in the 1907 Harvester judgment delivered by Justice Higgins. It was then that the foundations were laid for the system which has handicapped Australia's economic development for the last 100 years. The background to this case was that a tariff of £12 was charged on imported harvesters and a tax of £6 was charged on Australian produced harvesters. Manufacturers were exempt from the tax if they paid wages which were deemed to be fair and reasonable. So Justice Higgins set about to determine whether the wages paid by one particular manufacturer were fair and reasonable, thus ascertaining whether the company was eligible to have an exemption from the excise.

Rather than relying on the company's capacity to pay or on the productivity of individual employees, Higgins decided wage levels could be determined only on the basis of a crude estimate of the cost of living. There was no suggestion that the price of labour be determined by the realities of supply and demand, as in the case of groceries at the supermarket. Instead, His Honour took expert testimony from a number of housewives on the cost of a number of goods. In the compilation of those goods, His Honour took into account a number of items that were considered to make up the basic wage for the case. In compiling that list, the items added up to the cost of living that was taken into account in drafting his famous Harvester proposal.

Having the Harvester proposal and the tariff regime surrounding that proposal in place meant that from 1907 to 1996 Australian industrial relations were dominated by the feature of a non-market arrangement. So industrial tribunals came down with awards and had arrangements that had no relationship to the marketplace. These awards were prescriptive and had no relationship to the way in which Australians worked in the factories and on the farms.

So the manufacturers were able to live in this protected environment, which meant that the exporters, the farmers and the miners had to compete on the world markets. On the one hand, the farmers were receiving the price for their wool and their grain as the world market might decree. However, other people in the manufacturing area were receiving a price that was largely determined by the cost of labour which, in turn, was arbitrated by the Arbitration Commission.

This process went on and on and on. People in Australia considered that this was the normal order of things, so much so that, until there was a challenge to the award system by the likes of the Minister for Industrial Relations, who is at the table, Ian McLachlan and others, people in Australia thought that there could never be a change to the position that the Harvester award had created—a basic wage for all Australians. From that point on, the changes would take a long while to be introduced.

So big manufacturing companies maintained this ancient system that had no relativity to the genuine marketplace of the productivity and capacities of individual Australians. This wage fixing system developed in those early years by the Harvester judgment led to the H.R. Nicholls Society being formed in the early 1980s.

That society developed a questioning attitude to the current arrangements of Australian industrial relations. The activities of that group challenged the status quo of industrial relations in Australia. I pay tribute to that group. It developed some arguments that were followed up in this parliament and argued in many forums around Australia. I pay tribute to the minister at the table for having reached this landmark decision.

I also pay tribute to the arguments put by a former member of this House, the Hon. Bert Kelly. He had long debates about the tariffs that were related to the Harvester judgment and about the fact that certain industries enjoyed this protection whereas their workers were protected at a level of wages and salaries that had no relativity to the outside marketplace, let alone the Australian marketplace.

The key objectives of the bill are to promote cooperation in the workplace and a world competitive industrial relations system. Awards increasingly will be determined in the enterprise rather than the hearing rooms of the industrial relations system in a quasi‐legal manner. Awards will be simplified. The new awards will deal only with core matters—sick leave, annual leave and jury leave.

Other terms and conditions will be determined at the workplace. The new legislation before the House will require management and employees to discuss and work out their own work conditions rather than rely on comprehensive awards to dictate every last detail.

There will be a new stream of non‐union enterprise bargaining, the very thing that we on this side of the parliament say will put thrust back into enterprise agreements. Workplace agreements will be introduced and made possible without unwanted union interference, and they can proceed without the approval of the Industrial Relations Commission.

As all members of this House would know, Labor's enterprise flexibility agreements, supposedly designed for the non‐union sector, required union involvement and approval by the commission, even when management and work force had agreed on various working conditions. What a strange set of arrangements.

A union with no members at the workplace could argue against an agreement in the Industrial Relations Commission, and the commission could then reject it. We on this side of the House find it amazing that you could have a union member with no connection to the workplace arguing against a set of conditions. The Tweed Heads case regarding sick leave was a classic example of the unions and the Industrial Relations Commission thwarting a legitimate enterprise agreement.

Under coalition policy, approval by the commission will not be required, nor will unions have a guaranteed role. Safeguards will ensure that workers are not exploited and include a guarantee that take‐home pay will not decrease relative to the award. Agreements will be lodged with employee advocates—funded by the government, I might add—who will act for the employees to ensure that they are not being disadvantaged.

I now turn to freedom of association. A key element of the bill before the House is that workers will be able to choose whether they join a union. No more the old story of no ticket‐no start on building sites, which was strictly enforced by the militant BLF in days gone by. Preference clauses, giving union members preference in employment in several industries, will be removed from awards altogether. That in itself will be a major breakthrough for a number of industries where no ticket‐no start has been very much the order of the day and no legal process has been able to overcome that long tradition.

Preference clauses are one of the primary reasons for several industries being characterised as closed shops here in Australia and also in the UK. The coal industry, the oil industry and the waterfront are all characterised by compulsory membership of unions. All members of this House would be very aware of the impact monopoly coverage has had on those industries. It has ensured that they have had more than their fair share of strikes and industrial disputes. The current battle involving the CFMEU and Australian coal ports is a case in point, illustrating the way the union controls the waterfront.

No longer will what was once the only remaining issue—which union will be granted coverage of a particular workplace—be made on high in the Industrial Relations Commission. No longer will the commission or the union dominate over the freedom of choice that workers and management will have under this bill.

There will be no more union monopolies. The `conveniently belong' rule will be done away with, with new unions being able to challenge the position of established unions. Unions will be treated as what they are—service providers which should be exposed to the same competition as anyone else in the industry. No longer will the unions enjoy what union leaders have come to expect as a right—a total monopoly position.

Union bosses will have to serve their members rather than using the union movement as a stepping-stone to a political future with the ALP. Most members opposite have used the union movement and the industrial relations system to further their political careers, as the minister at the table would fully understand.

There will be a return to the secondary boycott provisions. Sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act will return to provide employers with injunctive relief against unions which engage in secondary boycotts. The Prime Minister, in 1974, was instrumental in bringing this measure in. It will provide protection for employers who find themselves the victims of industrial disputes which have nothing to do with them.

Employers will be better equipped to deal with the storemen and packers and transport workers union whose members have often refused to deliver goods on the basis of a totally unrelated dispute. That may seem rather technical to those outside this House. But anyone who has been involved in a secondary boycott dispute where small business was subjected to this sort of treatment will fully understand the impact of this measure.

The unfair dismissal laws will be amended to provide a fair go to employers and employees all round. It seems to me that an unfair dismissal action is about $7,000 a pop at the moment. If you have a problem with an unfair dismissal, as the minister at the table would know, it is hardly worth going through the process because it will cost you a couple of thousand dollars in legal costs and another $5,000 when judgment is awarded against you, so much so that 23,000 applications for unfair dismissal have been filed but only 3,500 have been before the Industrial Relations Commission. With the new bill we will get rid of the unfair dismissal laws, and I think there will be a great sigh of relief around Australia that this terrible provision full of legality has been removed.

I will conclude by making the observation that at long last industrial relations will be related to the marketplace; they will be related to the ability of employees to work hard, to improve their capacities and their skills and be rewarded for merit and effort. No longer will Australian employees be regarded as one with no recognition for performance and no recognition that they might have different skills from their fellow workmates in the workplace. They will be able to be compensated for improving, for doing a better job.

Therefore, with this new bill, productivity and efficiency in Australia will be improved immensely. We will have a highly competitive, export driven economy where workers know that the prosperity of Australia will depend on their efforts—and not on the decisions of the Arbitration Commission or the history of Justice Higgins, who brought down the famous Harvester judgment. This is a historic day in the Australian parliament. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Ms Macklin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Abbott) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House tonight a serious issue of injustice which has been suffered by two constituents of mine who were involved in the lease of a hotel. Patricia Lorraine Williams and Ernest Arthur Wilson were made bankrupt by virtue of sequestration orders made on 17 February 1986 and 23 April 1986 respectively in the Federal Court of Australia in proceedings No. 114 of 1986, No. NB 426 of 1986. They were discharged from their bankruptcy three years later. The Official Trustee in Bankruptcy was appointed their trustee and has administered and continues to administer their bankrupt estate.

SPEECH.PARA: On 10 August 1988 a company, Welona Pty Ltd, lodged a proof of debt with the Official Trustee which resulted in a hearing arising out of the proof of debt taking place in the Federal Court before Sweeney J. on 6, 7 and 8 October 1992. In these proceedings, evidence was given by a director of Welona Pty Ltd, Ronald William Charles Bowen, in relation to certain photographs taken of the Gardeners Inn Hotel around which the dispute revolved. Welona Pty Ltd was the registered proprietor of the hotel. This led to photographs being identified by a witness, Mr Nigel Richmond Bell, and tendered as a result of direct evidence given by Mr Bowen, being exhibits 6, 7 and 8 in the proceedings. These photographs were all said to have been taken on 29 January 1985. An investigation has been carried out by Mr Wilson, Ms Williams and Mr John Whitfield as to the accuracy of the evidence given by Mr Bowen as to the date on which these photographs were taken.

It appears that a substantial number of the photographs could not have been taken on that date. There is one photograph, the subject of evidence given by Mr Bowen, that establishes that the evidence given in these proceedings was untrue. This is evidence given on page 103 of the transcript as to exhibit 8. In short, the evidence is that the photograph was taken in January 1985. From other evidence in the proceedings, the date in January is said to be 29 January 1985. The evidence is that a newspaper bearing the same date as the photographs was placed in the photographs to prove the date on which the photograph was taken, being January 1985. The date of the newspaper in the photograph is 14 March 1985.

There are other photographs tendered in evidence which were definitely taken at a time other than 29 January 1985. Some of these photographs bear dates in 1983 and it is believed they were taken by Ronald Benson, who is deceased. Other photographs were taken later in 1985 after the hotel had been renovated. This can be established by independent evidence.

The other disturbing aspect of this case relating to the photographs is that in 1986 Wilson gave certain photographs which he says were taken earlier in the lease to James Thomas Garrett, an officer of the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia. On his own admission, Mr Garrett has sworn affidavits that these photographs were lost. However, some of these photographs formed part of exhibits 6 and 7 in the proceedings and more than likely exhibit 8, which was supposed to hold one photograph, and were eventually located by the writer with exhibits in the file of Wilson and Williams in the Federal Court, although said to have been missing at the time of the hearing.

There is no explanation from Mr Garrett as to how this occurred and subsequently it is the contention of Wilson and Williams that the photographs were misused. The Official Trustee in Bankruptcy has been most reluctant to allow access to their files to investigate what occurred. They have had an internal investigation without allowing access to files and without interviewing Wilson and Williams. Their only conclusion is that the photographs were mislaid and this would result in updating internal procedures in the department.

Wilson and Williams are requesting investigation into this matter as to the evidence given by Mr Bowen as to the photographs and, in particular, the photograph containing the newspaper and the obvious discrepancy. My constituents are further requesting investigation into the matter of the photographs leaving the possession of the Official Trustee in Bankruptcy and who had access to such photographs. The possible misuse of these photographs is of great concern to my constituents.

I would like to ask the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) to at least meet with the barrister representing Mr Wilson and Ms Williams, as there is a grave allegation of misuse of the positions they hold and the fact that perjury is involved. I believe the Attorney‐General should at least meet with the barrister to clear up what seems to be a terrible injustice to my constituents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise tonight the issue of the formation of the Sydney Airport Community Forum—or, as it will be known from today, the North Shore hockey club. The composition of this committee is an absolute farce. This committee has excluded the area in which Sydney airport is actually located. The local government area of Botany, the state seat of Heffron and the federal seat of Kingsford‐Smith will have no input into the future direction and operations of Sydney airport. Also, the federal seat of Sydney has no representation. The state seat of Marrickville, over which most of the planes fly, has also been excluded from representation, as have the state seats of Drummoyne and Ashfield.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, the local government area of Rockdale, the area most affected by the east‐west runway to the west of that runway, is excluded from representation. Leichhardt Council, South Sydney Council, Drummoyne and Ashfield councils to the north of the airport have also been excluded.

When you look at the community representation this farce is exposed. You have five community representatives. There are three from the North Shore of Sydney. Bennelong is singled out to get a representative. No other electorate, no other local government area, has been singled out to get a community representative but Bennelong once again gets special treatment. The Upper North Shore also gets special treatment. The Liberal front group, the Sydney Airport Forum, also gets representation. There is one representative from Kurnell, and the area around the airport most affected—the inner west, the area within 10 kilometres of which you have to fly before you hit any other area—has just one representative. This shows the North Shore bias in this committee; it is an absolute rort. It exposes the hypocrisy in that this committee is going to be simply concerned with keeping planes away from the North Shore of Sydney and will not really be concerned with genuine representation and community accountability.

BREAK.PARA: The government's attitude today was also exposed. I was suspended from the House for a brief period this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Deservedly.

—I was very angry that when the issue of community consultation was raised with the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) he said, `Oh, but John Howard and I went to a public meeting in Hunters Hill.' Frankly, it is just not good enough for the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to refuse to have any consultation with the residents most affected around areas such as Marrickville, Leichhardt, Sydenham and Rockdale and to ignore those areas and say that representation is solely on the basis of the people in Hunters Hill. They deserve representation. Let me say this: hearing is not equated to income. Working class people in the suburbs of Sydenham deserve exactly the same representation as the people of Hunters Hill.

BREAK.PARA: I will be interested to know whether this committee will have any community meetings, whether it will have any input and whether it will have any accountability. I will be interested to see what happens to the resolutions adopted by the previous Sydney Airport Community Consultative Committee, such as giving compensation to small business in Sydenham—something we hear a lot of rhetoric about from the other side of the House. I will also be interested to know whether this committee takes up cases of insulation and acquisition—the problems that are occurring there—which the previous SACCC did when it made representations to the minister.

The Minister for Transport and Regional Development likes to think of himself as a bit of a doer. He does not seem to have the same zeal for the insulation project. I have written to him about specific constituents and have received no answer. There is a pile of forms on his desk from the department about problems, and they simply remain there—they are all deferred for consideration. Meanwhile people do not know what is going to happen with the insulation project. Some of these people have very young children and families and they are being treated very unfairly.

This committee is a farce. We will be very interested to see exactly how much input and community accountability come from it. Increasing representation for those people on the North Shore and excluding those areas most affected by aircraft noise is a very bad start.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Many grave and sad issues are raised in this House. In the short time available to me I would like to raise one tonight: the increasing break-up of families in this country and the inequities that occur when that happens.

SPEECH.PARA: Last weekend I was placed in a very difficult position. I felt totally inadequate and did not quite know what to do. This is the story: a father, and it could equally have been a mother, had an access order to see his children. He went around to where they were and was denied access. He had a Family Court order and was permitted to see his children between the hours of one o'clock and five o'clock on that Saturday afternoon. He was denied access.

What did he do about it? He was so upset that he went to see the Queensland police. Their response was, `I'm sorry, we have no jurisdiction in the matter.' He said, `I have this Family Court order. I am entitled to have access to my children.' They said, `Sorry.'

On the Monday he went to see the Australian Federal Police to see what they might be able to do about it. Same story: `We can't do anything about it unless it is written on the court order.' I have now found out that the only recourse this father has is to go back to the Family Court. And what happens there the majority of times? It may take up to six months to get a hearing in the Family Court. Once he gets there, what happens? Whoever is in the Family Court probably rules that the other party is in contempt, but there is virtually no penalty. Why put on a penalty? The other party probably cannot afford a penalty anyway. You go around in a circle and six months later the fellow still has not had access to his children.

That is wrong. That is something that the people, the courts and the law‐makers of this nation should be addressing some attention to. Parents absolutely should have right of access to their children. I felt very inadequate last weekend when I saw that occur. I certainly will be doing whatever I can in this place, and I hope that I have the support of all my colleagues here tonight and those who are watching in their offices. We may well be able to change that situation so that parents can have access to their children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to bring to the notice of the parliament this evening the activities of a group called Central Coast‐Newcastle Breast Implant Support Groups. The group is headed up by my constituents Kim and Leah Boyd. Kim is the husband, and Leah is in very poor health and her health is worsening. There are tragic stories when one deals with constituents who have had to suffer the after‐effects of breast implants and when one sees the litigation that has been going on in the United States. The preferential treatment that seems to have been given to American women who have had these implants compared with the great difficulties placed in the way of Australian women who have had exactly the same procedures is to be condemned both in this parliament and from every rostrum when we have the opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: These two volunteers—particularly Kim, the husband—head up this support group, and they work for the Women's Breast Implant Resource Service. They are people who are giving of their time and their feelings and who have given the little bit of resource they had. They are committed to helping and supporting women who have had or are considering the implantation of breast implants. They are committed to giving voice to women's experiences. They give the evidence of experts the same weight as they do the personal experiences of `uneducated women', as they are called: in other words, women who do not have the expertise or the resources available to express themselves as eloquently as do members of the medical fraternity and the legal people that they employ on their behalf.

The key to the people in this group is that they learn from each other and from health care providers, and the health care providers learn from women. It is a situation where women learn from women and share experiences. Their network is completely unfunded. These are people in poor circumstances who are going through a terrible stage in their life—if they have survived. They are unpaid volunteers, all of whom have had personal breast implant experience. They devote their own time and personal resources to helping other women in any situation that they may find themselves in. Their help may involve providing advice or a sympathetic ear or simply a shoulder to lean on. It may involve sharing what is so often the loneliness of this experience and also, in many ways, the stigmatising of the experience.

Amongst some members of the community there is an attitude that, if somebody has had this procedure, that is something they have had done of their own choice. I do not believe that these women really get either the wholehearted community support that they ought to get or the recognition they ought to get in their absolute plight. This network is committed to ensuring that women with breast implants receive appropriate and affordable medical treatment and that the same women receive respect, compassion and full disclosure of medical information from health care providers.

This network is dedicated to ensuring that country and regional women are not disadvantaged in accessing appropriate health services because of distance barriers or communication barriers, in whatever form. They are dedicated to ensuring that health policies and programs are devised to accurately meet their very specific health care needs and the resultant emotional trauma. They are dedicated to ensuring that policies and programs redress the problems that these women are suffering due to the insertion of inadequately tested devices into their bodies without truly informed consent. They want to ensure that women are given enough accurate information now to make a truly informed choice about their own bodies.

This is only the beginning. I hope in the adjournment debates over the next few days to have the opportunity to give a further explanation of the work that is going on and try to seek the support of other members of this parliament and other members of the community in recognising the difficulty and the suffering of so many Australian women.

The group strives to influence public health policy so women are protected from hazardous or inadequately tested medical devices. They want to gather and share information from medical and many other sources and, most importantly, from other women with similar experiences. They want to communicate regularly with health policy makers in government to keep women up to date with the latest developments.

In the few moments that remain, I simply want to say that I commend Kim Boyd for his efforts and I admire the courage of his wife, Leah, in the plight in which they find themselves. Kim is now devoting himself full‐time, using the few resources available to them, to trying to make life more comfortable for Leah. In the sharing of their own agony, they are trying to ensure that other women and families who are in a similar situation get the kind of help that they have not been able to get to date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate this evening to congratulate and encourage the Victorian Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett. I do so for the leadership he has shown in getting the drug debate up and running in Victoria. I think those who have been following the drug debate in Victoria could be forgiven for thinking that it was all about the legalisation of cannabis. In fact, Premier Kennett's Drug Advisory Council, under the chairmanship of the conservative medical academic David Penington, was the response to a series of heroin related deaths and, finally, an incident that was probably too confronting for any political leader and indeed the community.

SPEECH.PARA: In February, Melbourne's Herald‐Sun ran a front page photograph of three kids, 12, 14 and 15 years of age, injecting heroin in a school toilet. They shared a single needle. The sickening image was captured by a surveillance camera secretly placed by the headmaster of the school. I think that issue in itself was unfortunately not the subject of public debate.

Why then did Professor Penington's council head off in the direction of cannabis and recommend liberalisation of cannabis laws to boot? The problem is that in the first instance tobacco—and young people from 12 to 17 years smoke 6½ million cigarettes every week—is the gateway drug that greatly increases the likelihood of young people trying marijuana when it is offered to them. In fact, those who smoke cigarettes are 28 times more likely to say yes to cannabis. Those who sell cannabis invariably have other drugs to peddle, thereby introducing their frequently innocent buyers to a variety of life‐sapping products.

The question I ask—and one I think the Australian community needs to ask—is: are we really listening to young people? I think if we were we would find that they will tell us that drug education is frequently seen as irrelevant, hypocritical and lacking credibility. In the context of the debate which has just occurred in Victoria, and not often enough in other parts of Australia, people ought to remember that the national drug strategy has established that in one year over half of teenagers between the ages of 14 and 19 years will be offered cannabis. A quarter of them would have smoked it in the last 12 months and 40 per cent would have smoked it at some time in the past. The cannabis trade in Australia is estimated to be worth some $2 billion. In the state of Queensland, for example, the CJC estimates its total value at $652 million a year, second only to sugar as a cash crop.

The Victorian government is to be given credit for now putting $25 million into drug education programs in Victoria. Even though we could go a lot further, compared with the national commitment of some $37 million for drug education, it is a substantial move in the right direction.

But what members of this chamber and, I think, Australians generally need to remember is that what we are doing with heroin, speed, cannabis and ecstasy is clearly not working. The legalisation of these drugs is not the answer either and those who think it is need look no further than tobacco for evidence of failure. However, drug users and addicts in particular should be treated as the pitiable people that they are and much less like criminals. Those who peddle drug misery deserve much more attention from the law.

We need to direct our energies to addressing those conditions which breed a disillusionment with the future and a sense of hopelessness about the present. If ever an issue begged leadership—glimpses of which we have seen from the Victorian Premier, Mr Jeff Kennett—it is this one. The Victorian Premier made the Victorian parliament available for discussion of this issue, about which all Australian parents in particular are concerned. It is a model that could be applied to this parliament not only for drug debates but, indeed, for other pressing issues of concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to briefly address the issue of radiation safety. When the subject of radiation is mentioned, most people's first thoughts would be of nuclear fall‐out. In Australia, concern about nuclear fall‐out tends to focus on the after‐effects of the French nuclear tests. Much more potent radiation is present at Maralinga—the site of British atomic bomb tests in the immediate postwar years. After some years of negotiation, the British government have agreed to contribute to the clean‐up of plutonium contamination at Maralinga to make the area safer for human habitation.

SPEECH.PARA: When nuclear energy is used as a fuel, as we saw at Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, there is always the danger of an accident. While there are no nuclear power stations in this country, Australian ports are sometimes visited by nuclear‐powered ships and we do have a reactor at Lucas Heights, so the possibility of some kind of emergency or accident is not totally remote.

PARA.BREAK: In our daily lives we have much greater contact with deadly radiation than many people may be aware. X‐rays are widely used in medicine, but their use is still a fairly imprecise science. More knowledge is needed of the effect of dosages—and about equip ment that provides accurate measurement of doses.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday's papers carried a report that as many as 271 Australians die every year as the direct result of underestimation of the cancer risks of X‐rays. The Royal Australasian College of Radiologists says that there is a potential for harm in even small doses of X‐rays.

A more intangible but strongly felt concern relates to possible harmful radiation from high tension power lines and from mobile phones, both of which are receiving increasing publicity. But what may not be generally appreciated is that Australia is a world leader in the detection of levels of harmful radiation and also in the development of techniques to minimise their danger. This is thanks to the work carried out over many years by the Australian Radiation Laboratory, located in my electorate of Jagajaga in Melbourne.

The Australian Radiation Laboratory has monitoring stations located around the country that are able to instantly detect any radiation that may result from nuclear testing. The effectiveness of the Maralinga clean‐up is also guaranteed by ARL field‐monitoring. If any nuclear incident were to occur in Australia, it would be the emergency preparedness team from ARL that guided emergency service response.

The laboratory is also engaged in cutting edge research that will enable radiologists to exactly determine the amount of radiation that is given to patients, thus making this essential medical treatment that much safer as well as providing a potentially very internationally‐marketable body of expertise.

When parents go to buy sunscreens and UV resistant clothes for themselves and their children, they can do so confident in knowing exactly how protective the garments and creams will be, thanks to the testing and standard setting carried out at the laboratory. This work has lately extended to testing and monitoring the exact effects of radiation from power lines and mobile phones.

The story, of course, does not have a happy ending. This government, as part of its budget cuts, is proposing to subject the Australian Radiation Laboratory to staffing cuts of close to 20 per cent. This is an outrageous and unnecessary action and Australia stands to lose expertise and knowledge built up over decades.

Last week I attended a meeting of the staff at the laboratory. These are eminent scientists, leaders in their fields, who are completely bewildered at this government's actions to cuts that will, of course, force redundancies. Totally out of character, they intend to take strike action on Thursday if some sanity does not return to this situation.

I fear that with ARL we are seeing what will be one of many scenes of unnecessary loss and suffering this government will cause as a result of the wrong‐headed economic policies. I hope it will change for ARL and radiation health safety.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Billson, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I commend you on your razor sharp vision and speak for a few moments on one of Australia's most respected business organisations: Australia Post. Nationally, Australia Post operates 4,300 outlets and handles about 100 million bill‐paying transactions each year, growing by 34 per cent last year, and 3.8 billion mail articles are delivered annually to 7.7 million different points.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1994-95 Australia Post revenue grew by over eight per cent to $2.781 billion. It made a record profit of $331 million before tax, paid $106 million in tax and returned $120 million to the federal government by way of dividend. It also invested $270 million in modernising its retail network and further enhanced its computerised technology, now of such a high standard that other financial institutions such as American Express are clamouring to sign retail and back office agreements with Australia Post to use initiatives such as giropost. Australia Post is anticipating similar results for this financial year.

Australia Post has changed. Its retail shops are a complete redesign of the traditional post office. Its staff are increasingly productive and, as I indicated, Australia Post is ahead of the field in technology. At local post offices such as Frankston, in Dunkley, staff now start work earlier to have most of the mail in private boxes by 8.30 a.m.

Yet, despite these substantial improvements, Australia Post continues to engage the respected corporate design consultants Emery Vincent Associates in what will overall be a multimillion dollar assignment to add the word `post' to Australia Post's corporate identity. Almost two weeks after the Age featured a story on 6 June in which Australia Post said that `no approval has been given for such change; it is still very early days' and talked of the current logo's icon status, Australia Post is yet to clarify the situation.

Australia Post claims that it has been slowly introducing this `post' logo since 1991, that it is merely an evolutionary change and that the recognisable P-shaped logo has been retained in all cases. The organisation's stationery already bears the capitalised word `post' vertically along the right-hand margin and the former Australia Post logo still appears at the top of the letterhead. It is sort of an each‐way bet. So what is the point?

In the corporate design world these sorts of contracts are prized, but opinions differ. One Melbourne based consultant to whom my staff spoke suggested that Australia Post might consider repositioning itself in the marketplace. That might involve changing its logo. But, on its own, changing a logo will not amount to much. A major Sydney design consultancy said that Australia Post's current logo is good and does not jump out as being particularly dated. Ken Cato, Chairman of Cato Design Inc., in the Australian Financial Review on 3 October 1989, said:

Design budgets are massive and many corporates don't understand what is being done . . . they end up spending too much and don't know it—the cost to pull down the old is often as much as the budget for the new identity.

Why Australia Post wants to delete the word `Australia' and reduce its relative significance is difficult to comprehend. Dropping or reducing the relative prominence of the word `Australia' from its well-designed logo goes against the trend. When Ansett last had a logo change they became Ansett Australia. Qantas retained the `Australian airline' motto when it merged with Australian Airlines. By way of example, replacing just one moulded sign at each of the 1,500 major properties Australia Post operates would cost Australia Post $1.5 million, a further $300,000 for the 3,100 licensed post offices and community mail agencies, plus tens of thousands of dollars for internal signage, trucks and delivery vehicles requiring repainting.

Will our international mail go overseas with little or no marking of its country of origin? I thought we would be proudly pushing Australia's good name into the world economies at every opportunity. Australia Post does not need a new logo. The word `post' is in itself meaningless. According to The Oxford English Dictionary, `post' has at least 87 different meanings and several hundred if the many words meaning `after' are included. Does Australia Post plan to market receiving a cheque in the mail as a new age post-post experience? The best explanation I have been able to obtain is that this `drip feed' change is just slowly being introduced—to what end, I am not sure.

I raise these issues because, despite these funds being expended, the plans to resite the Frankston delivery centre are moving very slowly and plans for its future are still uncertain. The majority of local traders, customers of the centre and the council strongly favour a replacement facility located close to Playne Street. I encourage Australia Post to meet with the Frankston City Council to see whether a new delivery centre could be located on the former Frankston police station site.

Committing available resources to continuous improvement in service, new products and service outlets that are responsive to customers' needs and the sensible use of cost-conscious technologies and premises are the way to go—not a needless and half‐hearted corporate image `makeover'. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I would like to speak on a matter which is very important to my electorate, particularly to the regional centre of Midland and the north-east portions of my electorate, and that is local community efforts to establish a university campus at Midland. The provision of a university campus at Midland would provide Midland, the north-east corridor and the Shire of Swan with a massive economic and social boost.

SPEECH.PARA: The preferred local site for a Midland university is the former site of the Midland Westrail railway workshops. In the run‐up to the 1993 state election, the current state coalition government promised the retention of the workshops and its expansion into a modern engineering site. Unfortunately, less than three months after that government's election at the state level, they broke that promise and closed the workshops. Since that time there has been a strong local push to establish a university on the site. This has been led by the Shire of Swan and supported by local members of parliament, state and federal, and the community generally.

In the last couple of years we have seen very many of the necessary building blocks put in place. During the last 12 months, the previous federal Labor government—in particular, the then Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Simon Crean—ensured that funding was made available for 750 extra places for tertiary students in Western Australia over the next three to four years.

As well, very many efforts were made at the local level urging the state government to adopt Midland campus as a priority for the state so far as capital development program funds were concerned. Members may be aware that Commonwealth capital development funds are accorded priority at the state level and that that guides the Commonwealth in its determination of grants from the capital development pool. More recently, we have seen in the last week or so Edith Cowan University initiate and launch university classes to be conducted by Edith Cowan University in conjunction with Midland TAFE at the site of the old Midland Westrail workshops.

All these building blocks and the prospect of a full university campus in Midland are now at risk. That has arisen from two matters. Firstly, at the federal level we have the mooted education cuts—as high as $600 million—and a failure on the part of the current federal government to guarantee the funding for the 750 extra places required in Western Australia—not just for a Midland campus but to cater for the growth which is occurring in my own state. Secondly, at the state level the state government has refused to give any indication as to its order of priority for capital development funds. A number of competing bids are in at the moment, including those for a Mandurah/Rockingham campus of Murdoch University and a Kalgoorlie campus of Curtin University. But there has been a deafening silence on the part of the state government as to its intentions in respect of the priority for capital development funds for a Midland university campus.

Requests for guarantees in respect of funding for the extra places and priority for capital development grants at the state level have fallen on deaf ears. Indeed, the federal member for Pearce, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), has been deafening in her silence in response to requests from me to guarantee funding. As well, her state colleague the member for Swan Hills, Mrs June van de Klashorst, has also been deafening by her silence in her failure or refusal to give any indication as to her government's priorities in the allocation of capital development grants.

The prospect of a boost to Midland and the prospect of the provision of a university campus for the north‐east corridor of the metropolitan area are all now at risk and in jeopardy. The prospects are bleak as a consequence of mooted cuts at the federal level and the failure of the state government to accord priority for a Midland campus. What is required is the full commitment at the state and federal level to ensure a university is committed to a growth area of Western Australia.

Midland is very well situated for a campus of a university, sitting as it does at the end of the metropolitan railway line, with good transport links in addition to railway. It is now the centre of a growing hub, particularly with developments in Stratton and Ellenbrook. That area of the north‐east corridor has major growth prospects over the next decade. I again call upon the state and federal governments to accord priority to the provision of a Midland campus of a university.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mutch, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently, in the adjournment debate, the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) launched a broadside against my illustrious ancestor, the Hon. T.D. Mutch, a former minister in successive Labor governments in New South Wales. The member was responding to a comment in my maiden speech where I said that the ALP ratted on a good man when they deserted Tom Mutch.

SPEECH.PARA: This simple but true comment attracted a vigorous response from the member for Werriwa, who sought to turn around my allegation and himself alleged that `for no good reason, he'—Tom Mutch—`became a Labor rat; he deserted the Labor cause'. My ancestor would probably turn in his grave just a little at this allegation. Having heard it all before from those ignorant of those turbulent days, he would be satisfied with me taking up the challenge of the member for Werriwa to give the House a full account of Tom Mutch's decision to leave the ALP or, rather, the decision of the ALP to leave him.
I refer to the character of Tom Mutch. I cite no less than Henry Lawson in his defence. In a letter to the electors of Botany, Henry Lawson said of Tom Mutch:

I don't suppose that Tom could possibly have an opinion but I'd hold the opposite. But he has carried his swag with me and was, and is, the straightest mate I or anyone else ever had, and if he says he's going to do a thing, he's going to do it all right.

And so, in 1927, when Tom Mutch and other good men in cabinet opposed on principle the notorious conference `red rules' where Lang assumed dictatorial powers, sacked his cabinet and appointed bootlickers, known as the `scabinet', Tom Mutch could do no other than to fight for principle.

As a consequence of this upheaval where Tom Mutch was elected leader of the Labor caucus opposed to Lang, a number of good men, including Mutch, lost fraudulent and rigged preselections—nothing much has changed I can see in the Labor Party—to the Lang forces, where longstanding league members who were Mutch supporters were struck from the roll of preselectors and new members who were not even on the Botany electoral roll were validated.

A number of sitting members contested the 1927 election. Mutch and Evatt were elected as independent Labor members, vindicating their stand but ensuring automatic expulsion from the ALP. Evatt's readmission and subsequent career in the ALP are ample acknowledgment of the fact that the stand taken by these men was acknowledged as one of principle. To condemn Tom Mutch is to also condemn Doc Evatt. At the time of his decision to stand as independent Labor, Tom Mutch addressed a public rally at the Mascot Town Hall. I quote from an unpublished biography by his niece Grace Doughty:

The Labor Party to which I have given a lifetime's loyalty has recently, and I hope temporarily, fallen under the control of a group whose principles and methods are foreign to my conception of the aims and ideals of Australian democracy. I am an uncompromising opponent of communism, and because of that, I am being fought with unparalleled unscrupulousness.

In an MA thesis, G.E. Lewis says that `Mutch was prepared to sacrifice all for an important matter of principle' and that by 1930 he `had found himself in the position where the Labor Party had moved away from him'. Indeed, I think the ALP revealed its true colours and reverence for thuggery and other bastardry when, at the 1971 New South Wales conference, Paul Keating had a motion carried readmitting Lang to the ALP, which I think says it all about Paul Keating.
The poet should have the last word. In a poem dedicated to Tom Mutch entitled `To Tom', Lawson said:
Life is like when we were rowing home
between the channel stakes.
Politics are but the joggle
when the wind blows on the lakes.
But the lantern on the boatshed
by the shore that we came from
Leads to rest, and the forgetting
- never mind the joggle, Tom!

I see that the honourable member for Werriwa has appeared in the chamber. I want to clarify the record. When I said in my maiden speech that the shadow minister for competition policy knew all about cronyism and nepotism, I thought I was addressing my remarks to the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). But a little collateral damage will not do him any damage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As our country concentrates its response to the Port Arthur tragedy in debating new gun laws, the question of mental health care has been mentioned but not deeply enough analysed to date as we seek answers to avoiding a repetition of the massacre of 28 April. I spoke last night in the Medicare levy amendment debate on the need to include a comprehensive review of our video violence, television coverage and mental health support programs in any serious attempt to stem the violence in our society. We not only need gun laws; we should be contemplating a total package of violence‐reducing reform.

SPEECH.PARA: I will include in Hansard a copy of a letter from a constituent of mine concerned at the apparent lessening of care for the mentally disabled, which is almost in direct proportion to the gradual deinstitutionalisation of many mental care patients:

We have just witnessed a human catastrophe with the taking of innocent lives in Port Arthur. But what were the consequences prevailing in the mind of the perpetrator before he took these lives? He was allegedly diagnosed as suffering from Paranoid Schizophrenia and his life riddled with mental anxiety, much of which may have been caused by his family dilemma. His intellect was allegedly that of an eight year old, as quoted by his friend. His friend also added that maybe if this fellow had received more substantial help with his mental trauma, this devastation may have not taken place.

There are many things which contribute to the balance of life. In this instance, not only the issue of Gun Laws should be addressed, but the immediate and direct help that is needed for those who are mentally incapable of caring for themselves.
The letter goes on:

I speak from experience. My younger sister, age 39 years, is also a sufferer of Paranoid Schizophrenia but with the added complexity of an intellectual disability. Sadly, she has been filed in the `too hard' basket in the eyes of the Mental Health Department. Dual diagnosis is very common. She had been institutionalised for a great many years. In the late 1980s, through the pros and cons of the Richmond Report and society's `Do-Gooders', my sister and many hundreds of mentally ill‐equipped people were `set free' from institutions to be taken to half‐way or boarding houses. These lodgings were no more than business orientated fire traps. No supervision prevailed, medical help was scant, personal security and living conditions were appalling. My sister was indecently assaulted twice whilst in these lodgings. This is not the proper care that should be offered. She was shuttled to more than fifteen of these places. She never `fitted in'. I was told there was nowhere else for her in Sydney, so my husband, another sister and myself were asked to bring her here to Orange, which we did in January 1993. After months of trying several Group Homes, the same problems arose. Those in charge of my sister's well‐being again said she did not fit into the system. They explained that the only option left was private accommodation with the help of social workers, Meals‐On‐Wheels and Home Help. Unfortunately, the help promised from the Mental Health team and Community Services was not consistent and did not last for long. More and more my sister became dependent on my help for her day to day requirements. This finally became a burden too heavy for my young family to carry. In January 1996, my sister was asked to leave her accommodation. The reason given was that she was very disruptive to the other private tenants.
It goes on to say:
People with similar complexities as my sister need permanent supervision . . .

I am not an advocate of permanent institutionalisation for people with mental disabilities. I realise that there is a fine path between mental health and mental instability that many tread in this increasingly stressful world. But I firmly believe that governments have largely reneged on many of their responsibilities in the mental health area by too easily embracing the deinstitutionalisation philosophy. It clearly has not worked in many cases. The letter I just read proves it. I urge the government to seriously seek national consensus on uniform video and mental health laws as they have on gun laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Southcott, Andrew, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last sitting week the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) and the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) made an allegation that `tories signed up for a bit of fascism in the 1930s' and that `your mob were supportive of Mussolini and Co.' These allegations are offensive, typical Labor revisionism and a distortion of the historical record. In fact, on substantive issues of foreign policy, the United Australia Party in the 1930s did oppose Mussolini and Hitler and revealed a profound distrust for these fascist dictators.

SPEECH.PARA: In his book Isolationism and appeasement in Australia, E.M. Andrews has shown that in Australia defenders of the Axis powers were mainly limited to certain Catholic commentators, the Bulletin, and small groups and individuals in the lunatic fringe such as the New Guard. The UAP does not get a mention.

In 1933 Robert Menzies publicly defended parliamentary democracy, which he distinguished from dictatorial control. When Mussolini invaded Abyssinia in 1935, Joseph Lyons and his Attorney-General, Robert Menzies, imposed sanctions on Italy. Do you know who opposed them? Lang Labor and then subsequently the ALP. In fact, the ALP was the only Labor organisation in the world to oppose those sanctions. For the member for Werriwa's information, things have not changed all that much. During that parliamentary debate there were seven quorums called. To quote E.M. Andrews, `The Labor Party stressed past League failures as an excuse for backing Mussolini.'

In 1936, when Hitler occupied the Rhineland, several cabinet ministers were very bitter about the Germans. Their suspicion of Hitler was shown when Sir George Pearce, the Minister for External Affairs, rejected German arguments for the return of Australia's mandate in New Guinea. That rejection was reaffirmed by Lyons in 1938. Even after the fall of Abyssinia, Menzies gave Anthony Eden the impression that he wished to continue sanctions against Italy.

Rather than supporting Mussolini, the imposition of sanctions made an enemy of him and led to the formation of the Axis between Italy and Germany. During the Spanish Civil War the Australian government was worried about Franco's methods of warfare and supported appeals to Franco to desist from bombing towns.

In 1937, the Australian government and the Department of External Affairs were suspicious of fascist influence in the Mediterranean, Australia's trade and defence lifeline at that time. In 1939 Australia, along with many other countries, guaranteed support for Poland if invaded by Hitler. At that time there were cabinet ministers such as Gullett who said the Nazi regime was predatory and aggressive and Sir Charles Marr pointed to atrocities inside Germany. Just remember, in 1940, after the fall of France, Australia was the third major country in the alliance against fascism.

In another Commonwealth country, South Africa, there was a relatively narrow parliamentary vote in favour of South Africa joining the Allies as opposed to remaining neutral. Many subsequent leaders of that country were Nazi sympathisers and actively worked during the war to hinder the Allied effort. To suggest that Australia has a tradition like that is wrong. In Australia there were no quislings. To suggest that Menzies and Lyons would have been happy to set up a Vichy-style government is wrong.

What about the ALP when they were in government? In 1943, Arthur Calwell, when a minister, called for Italia Libera, an anti-fascist organisation, to go out of existence. He also appointed a leading fascist to be the unofficial Italian liaison officer in Australia.

I do not suggest Calwell and the ALP supported the fascists. They did not. But if banning anti-Nazi plays indicated fascist support, then the Labor controlled Collingwood Council was also guilty. If administering that infamous Gaelic test to Egon Kisch was tacit fascist support, then it is worth remembering that that movement against war and fascism was also opposed by the Melbourne Trades Hall Council and the Victorian Labor Party.

Lyons was determined to avoid another world war. In following appeasement they were sensitive to the criticism of dictators. But look at the sort of people who were criticising the dictators. Eric Baume, who is an uncle of a current Liberal senator, was a fierce critic of the Nazis. He was such a strong critic that he was taken off 2GB.

My contention is that it is drawing a long bow to confuse appeasement with supporting fascism. Lyons and Menzies put sanctions on Mussolini, would not give New Guinea back to Hitler and by the end of the decade were at war with the fascists. They were not supporters of the fascists.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his race through the history books, the member for Boothby (Dr Southcott) has overlooked a very important historical fact: where was Bob Menzies at the end of 1938? He was on a study tour of Hitler's Germany. As Humphrey McQueen has pointed out, he came back suitably impressed.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted and the House stands adjourned until 9.30 a.m. tomorrow.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notices were given:
Mr Cadman to move:
That the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996 be referred to the Main Committee for consideration.
Mr Anderson to present a Bill for an Act a Bill for an Act to establish the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve, and for related purposes.
Mr Filing to move:
That this House:

PARA.TAB: (1) acknowledges the appointment of the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, and the Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, as Vice‐Patrons of the HMAS Sydney Foundation Trust;
(2) notes recent media reports about new technology which could assist in locating the sunken HMAS Sydney and other submerged vessels; and
(3) therefore calls on the Government to actively support moves by the HMAS Sydney Foundation Trust to locate the sunken vessel HMAS Sydney by:

TAB.TAB: (a) accepting that, regardless of the outcome, surviving family members of those who lost their lives on HMAS Sydney are owed the consideration of a full‐scale public search for the vessel;
(b) supporting public efforts to raise money to assist locating the wreck;
(c) funding and coordinating a suitable commemorative service for those who lost their lives on HMAS Sydney should the vessel be located; and
(d) erecting a suitable memorial in Canberra to commemorate the loss of HMAS Sydney in accordance with the wishes of surviving family members.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following papers were deemed to have been presented on 18 June 1996:
Acts Interpretation Act—Statement relating to failure to furnish report within specified period— Northern Territory Fisheries Joint Authority—Reports for 1993 and 1994.
Census and Statistics Act—Australian Bureau of Statistics—Statement 1996 No. 1.
Export Control Act—Export Control (Orders) Regulations—Orders 1996 No. 3.
Public Service Act—Determinations 1996 Nos. 32, 33, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 42, 70, 71, 72, 73, LES 12.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government reintroduce the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1995 which lapsed at the prorogation of the previous Parliament; if so, (a) why and (b) within what timeframe.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.5) 1995 (TLAB (No.5) 1995), will not be reintroduced as an entire Bill. The Government is considering all of the measures in that bill and decisions will be made in respect of each measure contained in TLAB (No.5) 1995 as to whether it will be introduced.

(b) The amendments to the income tax law relating to donations to certain gift funds and the provisions relating to off market share buy backs that were in TLAB (No.5) 1995, have been reintroduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What total revenue from capital gains tax was collected from (a) businesses and (b) individuals in (i) 1992‐93, (ii) 1993‐94 and (iii) 1994‐95.

(2) What proportion of the total revenue from capital gains tax collected from (a) businesses and (b) individuals in (i) 1992‐93, (ii) 1993‐94 and (iii) 1994‐95 was attributed to (A) profits on trading in listed shares and (B) other capital profits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a‐b)(i‐iii) It is not possible to provide a distinction between capital gains collected from individuals in business and other individuals as gains for all individuals are grouped together. The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) does not collect data on whether the capital gain for each taxpayer relates to business or other activities.

The following table shows data for tax collected on capital gains for individuals, companies and superannuation funds. The data relates to tax on gains included in income tax returns lodged in respect of that year. Generally this tax is collected in the following year hence figures are not yet available for 1994‐95.
Individuals 244 312 711
Companies 94 212 620
Superannuation Funds 35 67 479
Total Revenue 373 591 1810
(2) Data providing details of capital gains from listed shares are not collected by the ATO.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Qantas and Australia Post: Minority Shareholdings

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister able to say who are the minority shareholders in (a) Australian Air Express, (b) Uni‐net SP.ZO.0, (c) QPSX Communications Pty Ltd, (d) Lawpoint Pty Ltd, (e) Telstra Systems Pty Ltd and (f) Telecom Messagetech Pty Ltd.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia Post advises that:
(a) There is no minority shareholder in Australian Air Express as Qantas and Australia Post each hold a 50 per cent share.
Telstra advises that:
(b) It is not aware of minority holdings in Uni‐Net SP.ZO.0. Telstra sold its interests prior to 30 June 1994.
(c) There are no minority holdings in QPSX as Telstra acquired 100 per cent during the September 1995 quarter. Prior to this QPSX employees held a minority shareholding.
(d) Alloway Investments Pty Ltd, Ariglen Pty Ltd and Sir David Griffin hold minority interests in Lawpoint Pty Ltd.
(e) Lockheed Missiles and Space Company Inc hold a minority interest in Telstar Systems Pty Ltd.
(f) Matrix Telecommunications Ltd holds a minority interest in Telecom Messagetech Pty Ltd.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Indemnity of Claims: Optus Communications Pty Ltd

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the expiry date of Commonwealth indemnity of claims arising from promissory notes issued by Optus Communications Pty Ltd.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
