QUESTION.SPEAKER: Taylor, Bill, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What percentage of ABC TV programming is Australian.
(2) Is there evidence that ABC TV's viewer ratings fall with local content.
(3) Has the national format of the 7.30 Report received public criticism; if so, what is the strength of that criticism.
(4) Will the ABC review the matter referred to in part (3) and consider returning to a State‐based format.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the financial year 1995/96 (10 months up to April 1996) as a percentage of transmission hours the ABC has transmitted 50.6% Australian content between the hours of 6am to midnight. This is based on material transmitted from Sydney, and does not take account of any locally produced news and sport in other States and Territories. Levels of Australian content for the full year have yet to be determined.
A copy of the breakdown of Australian content, giving first run and repeat percentages has been provided separately to the honourable member.
(2) The ABC is not able to identify Australian content in itself as the predominant reason for viewing a particular program.
A copy of the top rating ABC programs from 1991 to 1995 has been provided separately to the honourable member.

The 1990 survey by ANOP on community attitudes to the ABC's role, image and position, showed that 60‐70% of the population rated the ABC as being very good or quite good for being distinctively Australian and contributing to Australia's national identity.

(3) There was significant public criticism of the ABC Board's decision to replace the state based 7.30 Report with a national 7.30 Report . This criticism was at its most vocal between the time of the announcement on 27 September 1995 and the broadcast of the first edition of the new national program on 4 December 1995.
The criticism was expressed in the national and local press, letters and telephone calls.

In October and November 1995 the ABC received approximately 250 letters of complaint as well as petitions from Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory containing 1487 signatures complaining about the Board's decision. However, there was little criticism from NSW, Victoria or the ACT.
Since the national 7.30 Report began on Monday 4 December 1995 the complaints have substantially reduced with the major area of complaint being Western Australia.

(4) The ABC continues to receive letters and telephone calls in support of the national 7.30 Report . In addition, analysis of the ratings indicates that the popularity of the program is increasing each month and that a comparison of figures for the five cities combined for the period December, January, February (the period when most complaints were received) with the corresponding period last year shows the national 7.30 Report has a greater share of the audience than in the same months in 1995.

On the basis of audience research and ratings analysis and following the introduction of the state based current affairs program, Stateline, the ABC is not considering the reintroduction of a state based format for the 7.30 Report .

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

BREAK.PARA: Which—(a) local government authorities or (b) community‐based organisations has Telstra advised of its plans for local broadband cabling.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Telstra advises that the following local government authorities and community‐based organisations have been advised of its plans for local broadband cabling:
(a) Local Government Authorities (Councils)
New South Wales

Ashfield, Auburn, Bankstown, Baulkham Hills, Blacktown, Botany, Burwood, Campbelltown, Canterbury, Concord, Drummoyne, Fairfield, Hawkesbury, Holroyd, Hornsby, Hunters Hill, Hurstville, Kogarah, Ku‐Ring‐Gai, Lane Cove, Leichhardt, Liverpool, Manly, Marrickville, Mosman, Newcastle, North Sydney, Parramatta, Penrith, Pittwater, Randwick, Rockdale, Ryde, Shoalhaven, South Sydney, Strathfield, Sutherland, Sydney City, Warringah, Waverley, Willoughby and Woollahra;
Queensland
Brisbane, Gold Coast, Ipswich, Logan, Pine Rivers and Redlands;
South Australia

Adelaide, Brighton, Burnside, Campbelltown, East Torrens, Elizabeth, Enfield, Gawler, Glenelg, Happy Valley, Henley and Grange, Hindmarsh and Woodville, Kensington and Norwood, Marion, Mitcham, Mount Barker, Munno Para, Noarlunga, Payneham, Port Adelaide, Prospect, Salisbury, Stirling, St Peters, Tea Tree Gully, Thebarton, Unley, Walkerville and West Torrens;
Victoria

Banyule, Bayside, Boroondara, Brimbank, Casey, Darebin, Glen Eira, Greater Dandenong, Hobsons Bay, Kingston, Knox, Manningham, Maribyrnong, Maroondah, Melbourne, Melton, Monash, Moonee Valley, Nullumbik Shire, Port Phillip, Stonnington, Whitehorse, Wyndham and Yarra;
Western Australia

Armadale, Bassendean, Bayswater, Belmont, Cambridge, Canning, Claremont, Cockburn, Cottesloe, East Fremantle, Fremantle, Gosnells, Kalamunda, Kwinana, Melville, Mosman Park, Mundaring, Nedlands, Perth, Rockingham, Serpentine‐Jarrahdale, South Perth, Stirling, Subiaco and Vincent.

Telstra further advises that the type of information it provides to councils on broadband cabling is dependent on its planned rollout schedule i.e. the information will vary from an overview, which could be presented up to twelve months prior to the commencement of any work, to a more detailed prescribed activity notice, which the Telecommunications National Code requires telecommunications carriers to submit to relevant authorities (including affected councils) formally notifying them of their intention to proceed with cable rollout.
(b) Community‐based organisations

Telstra advises that it has contacted a wide range of community‐based organisations in the above Council areas regarding its plans for local broadband cabling. This contact may have taken the form of attendance at meetings by Telstra representatives, or the provision of written material.

Telstra further advises that throughout its broadband cable rollout project it has maintained a strong commitment to dialogue with local communities. This includes briefing sessions, meetings, presentations and letter box drops to ensure full disclosure and comprehension of its plans as well as providing opportunities for consultation to take place.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: On most recent data, how many Family Allowance Supplement recipients reside in (a) Victoria and (b) the postcode areas of (i) 3074, (ii) 3075, (iii) 3076, (iv) 3082, (v) 3083, (vi) 3087, (vii) 3088, (viii) 3089 and (ix) 3090.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Family Allowance Supplement no longer exists. That payment has been subsumed by Family Payment.

The Department of Social Security (DSS) produces data on recipients of all DSS pension, benefits and family payments by postcode. The publication titled `Recipients of Pensions, Benefits and Family Payments in Postcode Districts' is produced on a quarterly basis and is publicly available. It is also available through the Parliamentary Library.
A copy of the publication and a diskette has also been forwarded separately to the honourable member.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What percentage of Medicare services was provided at or below the schedule fee (a) in 1994‐95 and (b) between 1 July 1995 and 1 May 1996 in (i) Victoria and (ii) the electoral division of Scullin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In 1994‐95, 80.0 per cent of services provided in Victoria, and 89.4 per cent of services provided in the electoral division of Scullin were billed at or below the Medicare schedule fee.

(b) In the nine months July 1995 to March 1996 (the latest period for which data are available), 80.9 per cent of services provided in Victoria, and 90.7 per cent of services provided in the electoral division of Scullin were billed at or below the Medicare schedule fee.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 1 May 1966:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In 1994‐95, 67.5 per cent of services provided in Victoria, and 86.9 per cent of services provided in the electoral division of Scullin were direct billed.

(b) In the nine months July 1995 to March 1996 (the latest period for which data are available), 68.8 per cent of services provided in (i) Victoria and 88.0 per cent of services provided in (ii) the electoral division of Scullin were direct billed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) In 1994‐95, 10.3 services per capita were provided in Victoria and 7.4 services per capita were provided in the electoral division of Scullin.

(b) In the nine months July 1995 to March 1996 (the latest period for which data are available), 8.0 services per capita were provided in Victoria and 5.6 services per capita were provided in the electoral division of Scullin.
The latest ABS population estimates by electoral division, covering the 12 months to June 1994 were used in computing services per capita in both years (including services per capita for Victoria).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Civil Aviation Organisation Conventions and Protocols

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: To which International Civil Aviation Organisation conventions and protocols has Australia not yet become a party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is not a party to the following International Civil Aviation Organisation conventions and protocols:

ROW.ENTRY: International Air Transport (Five Freedoms) Agreement, done at Chicago on 7 December 1944

Protocol relating to an amendment introducing Article 93 bis (termination of membership) to the Convention on International Civil Aviation of 7 December 1944 (the Chicago Convention), done at Montreal on 27 May 1947
Convention on the International Recognition of Rights in Aircraft, done at Geneva on 19 June 1948
Protocol to Amend the Convention on Damage caused by Foreign Aircraft to Third Parties on the Surface of 7 October 1952 (the Rome Convention), done at Montreal on 23 September 1978
Convention on the Marking of Plastic Explosives for the Purpose of Detection (the MARPLEX Convention), done at Montreal on 1 March 1991
Protocol on the Authentic Quinquelingual Text of the Convention on International Civil Aviation (relating to the Arabic text of the Chicago Convention), done at Montreal on 29 September 1995
Protocol relating to an amendment to the Convention on International Civil Aviation (relating to the Arabic text of the Chicago Convention), done at Montreal on 29 September 1995

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, Australia has not ratified the following protocols of the Warsaw System relating to the liability of air carriers engaged in international carriage of passengers, baggage and cargo:

ROW.ENTRY: Protocol to amend the Convention for the Unification of Certain Rules relating to International Carriage by Air signed at Warsaw on 12 October 1929 (the Warsaw Convention) as Amended by Protocol done at The Hague on 28 September 1955, done at Guatemala City on 8 March 1971
Additional Protocol No. 1 to Amend the Warsaw Convention of 12 October 1929, done at Montreal on 25 September 1975
Additional Protocol No. 2 to Amend the Warsaw Convention of 12 October 1929 as Amended by the Protocol done at The Hague on 28 September 1955, done at Montreal on 25 September 1975.

Additional Protocol No. 3 to Amend the Warsaw Convention of 12 October 1929 as Amended by the Protocols done at The Hague on 28 September 1955 and at Guatemala City on 8 March 1971, done at Montreal on 25 September 1975
Montreal Protocol No. 4 to Amend the Warsaw Convention of 12 October 1929 as Amended by the Protocols done at The Hague on 28 September, done at Montreal on 25 September 1975

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Brereton, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Which countries and international organisations recognise the authorities on Taiwan as the "Republic of China".

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Countries:

According to information currently available, the thirty‐one countries which recognise Taiwan as the "Republic of China" are: Bahamas; Belize; Burkino‐Faso; Central African Republic; Commonwealth of Dominica; Costa Rica; Dominican Republic; El Salvador; Gambia; Grenada; Guatemala; Guinea‐Bissau; Haiti; Holy See; Honduras; Liberia (claimed by both PRC and Taiwan); Malawi; Nauru; Nicaragua; Niger; Panama; Paraguay; Senegal; Solomon Islands; South Africa; St Christopher‐Nevis; St Lucia; St Vincent and the Grenadines; Swaziland; Tonga; Tuvalu.
International Organisations:

Australia is not currently a member of any international organisation which recognises Taiwan as the "Republic of China". I am advised, however, that there are five organisations of which Taiwan is a member as the "Republic of China". These are: Asian Productivity Organisation; Afro‐Asian Rural Reconstruction Organisation; Food and Fertiliser Technology Centre for the Asian and Pacific Region; Central American Bank for Economic Integration; Asian Vegetable Research and Development Centre.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australia Post and Telstra Staff: Electoral Division of Newcastle

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

(b) Telstra regrets that it is unable to provide the number of staff employed in the electoral division of Newcastle as at 1 March 1996. Telstra advises that 681 staff were employed as at 15 May 1996.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 7 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government legislate to enable local government to have the power of consent over the erection of equipment by telecommunications carriers.
(2) Is it a fact that local governments are best able to determine the environmental suitability of telecommunications facilities erected within their boundaries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Telecommunications (Exempt Activities) Regulations made under the Telecommunications Act 1991 allow carriers to engage in specified activities without being subject to certain State and Territory laws. These laws include environmental, heritage, town planning, powers and functions of a local government body, use of land, tenancy and the supply of fuel and power. The carriers must comply with the Telecommunications National Code when undertaking activities exempt from certain State and Territory laws.

The current regime does not provide for local government to give consent in the normal sense of planning authorisations. However, it does require consultation between the carrier and the local government, and other relevant authorities.

The Government intends to introduce a new Code which will require carriers to undertake stricter notification and consultation procedures to enable meaningful consultation with local government authorities about proposals to erect telecommunications facilities.

This framework, operating in lieu of normal State and Territory planning laws, will continue until replaced by a scheme of proper planning processes, preferably from 1 July 1997, which will be developed in consultation with States, Territories and Local Government.

(2) The Government is mindful of the important role local government can play in assessing any proposal relating to the erection of telecommunications facilities and therefore it is intended to continue and strengthen the requirements relating to consultation with local government in relation to proposals to erect facilities within their boundaries. As noted above, the Government will also, in consultation with States, Territories and Local Government be considering what scheme should replace the current scheme in the longer term.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the Army's intentions with respect to its facilities at Ingleburn, NSW.
(2) Has the Army examined alternative land use strategies for the Ingleburn site; if so, (a) what strategies have been examined and (b) when will they be finalised.
(3) Has the Army been informed of proposals by the Campbelltown City Council to preserve the site as a memorial forest and museum to commemorate all who served in Australia's armed forces.

(4) What action has been taken to identify the heritage significance of the site, particularly the theatre, chapel and hospital, with a view to the buildings being retained as a museum dealing with the service of personnel at Ingleburn army camp.
(5) Will the Army liaise with Campbelltown City Council to develop an acceptable land use strategy.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Ingleburn site has been identified for disposal, following relocation of activities.

(2) A number of inconclusive studies have been undertaken in recent years in regard to the future use of the site. Further examination will be undertaken in the context of planning for the second Sydney Airport.
(3) Yes.

(4) A number of isolated studies have been undertaken of the facilities on the site which have resulted in the decision to retain the Area Theatre for the benefit of the surrounding community. Consideration is presently being given to the implications of re‐opening the Church, `Our Lady Help of Christians', which is owned by the Catholic Church. A plan to determine the future use of the hospital, its structural integrity, furniture, fixtures, stores and equipment is expected to be completed before the end of 1996.

(5) The review to be undertaken during 1996/97 will examine future land use options in close collaboration with the Campbelltown City Council, Liverpool City Council and will consult widely and proactively with the community. The further examination of land use strategies will be undertaken in consultation with Campbelltown City Council and other planning authorities such as Liverpool City Council and the Department of Urban Affairs and Planning.

The Department of Social Security (DSS) produces data on recipients of all DSS pension, benefits and family payments by postcode. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that recently officers of his Department removed from computer systems which had been operated by electorate officers and former shadow ministerial staff the "Junkie" virus unintentionally spread by the staff of the Hon. T.A. Fischer and the Hon. J.W. Howard; if so, what action is he taking to prevent the Coalition partners from engaging in further unsafe practices which could infect floppies as well as hard disks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Computer viruses have been removed from thirteen electorate and Opposition Office‐holder offices this year with possible infections occurring in a further six offices. The infections have occurred in offices of all parties.

(b) Virus detection and removal software is incorporated into all electorate office computers as a safeguard. Also, Ministerial, Opposition Office‐holder and electorate staff who attend training conducted by my Department are advised on procedures to minimise the risk of virus infection and spread.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the existing system under which no documentary identification is required by polling booth workers of prospective voters provide adequate validation before votes are cast.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The issue of voter identification at polling booths was examined by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its enquiry into the conduct of the 1993 federal election. In its November 1994 Report to the Parliament entitled "The 1993 Federal Election" the Committee concluded that all objective evidence indicated that fraud was not a significant occurrence and did not influence any result at the 1993 federal election. The Committee did not support a requirement for proof of identity at polling booths.

However, in a dissenting report by Mr David Connolly MP, Senator Nicholas Minchin, Senator John Tierney, and Mr Michael Cobb MP, it was stated that the conclusion of the majority was too complacent. The dissenting report recommended a number of measures to tighten up electoral procedures, including the trial of voter identification cards at a by‐election.

In the light of the dissenting report, the Government will be giving further consideration to this issue. In addition, it is likely that the issue of electoral fraud will be further examined when the newly‐convened Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters enquires into the conduct of the 1996 federal election.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: What sum will be spent on the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme in (a) 1995‐96, (b) 1996‐97, (c) 1997‐98, (d) 1998‐99, (e) 1999‐2000 and (f) 2000‐2001.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sharp, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme (TFES) is a demand driven program so the amount spent in each of the years will depend on the level of claims submitted.
The 1995 Budget Papers estimated spending on the program of $43m for 1995‐96, $43m for 1996‐97, $42m for 1997‐98, and $42.4m for 1998‐99.
Actual expenditure for 1995‐96 will not be available until mid July 1996.
Updated estimates for the years 1996‐97 to 1999‐2000 will be provided in the 1996 Budget papers.
It is not standard practice to make estimates beyond the horizon of the three year forward estimates.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: UN International Year for the Eradication of World Poverty

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Government committed to the goals of the UN International Year for the Eradication of World Poverty; if so, what initiatives has it taken to reduce poverty in Australia and overseas in 1996.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: This Government is committed to the goals of the UN International Year for the Eradication of World Poverty. This commitment was reconfirmed in a speech given by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security at an ACFOA/ACOSS Seminar on the International Year on 3 June 1996.

The Government believes that the single most important anti‐poverty strategy is the creation of real jobs. To achieve this we are making the labour market more flexible and improving the regulatory environment for small business. These measures will stimulate the economy and enable businesses to expand. Other priority areas are support and assistance for families with children, and the introduction of the Family Tax Initiative is a major commitment in this area; sole parent pensioners; women; carers; the aged; and indigenous Australians. You have also directed questions to the respective individual Ministers, who will be responding separately on their own area of responsibility.

Australia's aid program is the Government's principal contribution to the direct alleviation of poverty in developing countries. The Government is committed to helping developing countries meet the basic needs of their people and intends to strengthen the focus of the aid program on humanitarian activities with tangible benefits for the poor. The Government believes that it is particularly timely in the International Year for the Eradication of Poverty for the priorities, objectives and focus of the aid program to be re‐examined. Accordingly the Minister for Foreign Affairs has recently commissioned an independent review of the aid program which will examine how the program can best contribute to lasting poverty reduction in developing countries.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: International Year for the Eradication of World Poverty

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 21 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is being taken in his portfolio in relation to the goals of the International Year for the Eradication of World Poverty.
(2) What programs have been initiated in 1996 to achieve the goals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) No specific programs have been initiated in response to International Year for the Eradication of World Poverty, nor were any planned by the previous Government.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Government Publishing Service: Qantas Printing Business

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hardgrave, Gary, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 22 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Australian Government Publishing Service (AGPS) taking over Qantas' printing business; if so, (a) what will happen to Qantas' existing printing staff and (b) why is AGPS competing with private printing businesses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In response to a public call by Qantas in early 1995 for Expressions of Interest for the Supply of Printed Matter, the AGPS Information Solutions Group submitted a proposal to provide an information management and print procurement service to Qantas. This includes ISG management of the Qantas internal printing facilities. Negotiation of an agreement between Qantas and AGPS for the provision of these services is yet to be finalised; (a) This is subject to the current negotiations with Qantas; (b) The main component of the AGPS proposal is the provision of information management and print procurement services not printing services. Under the proposal it is envisaged that a greater percentage of Qantas' print requirements will be sourced from private sector print suppliers than is currently the case.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Baring Brothers Burrows and Co. Ltd: Consultancy

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 30 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to a question without notice about the employment by the Government of consultants (Hansard , 2 May, page 277), is he employing Baring Brothers of Sydney as consultants to conduct a review of DASFLEET; if so, what is the cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jull, David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My department engaged Baring Brothers Burrows and Co., Limited to conduct a review of DASFLEET. The cost of the consultancy was $166 000.00.
